CHAPTER [I]0-i THE ONE THING NEEDFUL ‘ NOW , what [I]234-the speaker want is , Facts . Teach [these boys]2708-these boys and [girls]2709-girls nothing but Facts . Facts alone are wanted in life . Plant nothing else , and root out everything else . [You]2710-you can only form the minds of reasoning animals upon Facts : nothing else will ever be of any service to [them]2708-these boys . This is the principle on which [I]234-the speaker bring up [[my]234-the speaker own children]2711-my own children , and this is the principle on which [I]234-the speaker bring up [these children]2712-these children . Stick to Facts , [sir]2713-sir ! ’[234-the speaker] The scene was [a plain , bare , monotonous vault of [a school - room]233-a school - room]232-a plain , bare , monotonous vault of a school - room , and [the speaker]234-the speaker ’s square forefinger emphasized [his]234-the speaker observations by underscoring every sentence with a line on [the schoolmaster]235-the schoolmaster ’s sleeve . The emphasis was helped by [the speaker]234-the speaker ’s square wall of a forehead , which had [his]234-the speaker eyebrows for its base , while [his]234-the speaker eyes found commodious cellarage in [two dark caves]237-two dark caves , overshadowed by the wall . The emphasis was helped by [the speaker]234-the speaker ’s mouth , which was wide , thin , and hard set . The emphasis was helped by [the speaker]234-the speaker ’s voice , which was inflexible , dry , and dictatorial . The emphasis was helped by [the speaker]234-the speaker ’s hair , which bristled on the skirts of [his]234-the speaker bald head , a plantation of firs to keep the wind from its shining surface , all covered with knobs , like the crust of a plum pie , as if the head had scarcely warehouse - room for the hard facts stored inside . [The speaker]234-the speaker ’s obstinate carriage , square coat , square legs , square shoulders,—nay , [his]234-the speaker very neckcloth , trained to take [him]234-the speaker by the throat with an unaccommodating grasp , like a stubborn fact , as it was,—all helped the emphasis . ‘ In this life , [we]2714-we want nothing but Facts , [sir]2713-sir ; nothing but Facts ! ’[234-the speaker] [The speaker]234-the speaker , and [the schoolmaster]235-the schoolmaster , and [the third grown person present]244-the third grown person present , all backed a little , and swept with [their]245-their eyes the inclined plane of little vessels then and there arranged in order , ready to have imperial gallons of facts poured into them until they were full to the brim . CHAPTER II [MURDERING THE INNOCENTS THOMAS GRADGRIND]70-thomas gradgrind , [sir]2713-sir . [A man of realities]247-a man of realities . [A man of facts and calculations]248-a man of facts and calculations . [A man who proceeds upon the principle that two and two are four , and nothing over , and who is not to be talked into allowing for anything over]249-a man who proceeds upon the principle that two and two are four , and nothing over , and who is not to be talked into allowing for anything over . [Thomas Gradgrind]70-thomas gradgrind , [sir]2713-sir — peremptorily [Thomas]70-thomas gradgrind — [Thomas Gradgrind]70-thomas gradgrind . With a rule and a pair of scales , and the multiplication table always in [his]70-thomas gradgrind pocket , [sir]2713-sir , ready to weigh and measure any parcel of human nature , and tell [you]252-you exactly what it comes to . It is a mere question of figures , a case of simple arithmetic . [You]252-you might hope to get some other nonsensical belief into the head of [George Gradgrind]71-george , or [Augustus Gradgrind]72-augustus gradgrind , or [John Gradgrind]73-john gradgrind , or [Joseph Gradgrind]74-joseph gradgrind ( [all supposititious , non - existent persons]253-all supposititious , non - existent persons ) , but into the head of [Thomas Gradgrind]70-thomas gradgrind — no , [sir]2713-sir ! In such terms [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom always mentally introduced [himself]75-tom , whether to [his]75-tom private circle of acquaintance , or to [the public]255-the public in general . In such terms , no doubt , substituting the words ‘ [boys]2716-boys and [girls]2709-girls , ’[75-tom] for ‘ [sir]2713-sir , ’[75-tom] [Thomas Gradgrind]75-tom now presented [Thomas Gradgrind]75-tom to [the little pitchers before [him]75-tom]256-the little pitchers before him , [who were to be filled so full of facts]257-who were to be filled so full of facts . Indeed , as [he]75-tom eagerly sparkled at [them]257-who were to be filled so full of facts from the cellarage before mentioned , [he]75-tom seemed a kind of cannon loaded to the muzzle with facts , and prepared to blow them clean out of the regions of childhood at one discharge . [He]75-tom seemed a galvanizing apparatus , too , charged with a grim mechanical substitute for the tender young imaginations that were to be stormed away . ‘ [Girl number twenty]2719-girl number twenty , ’[75-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom , squarely pointing with [his]75-tom square forefinger , ‘ [I]75-tom do n’t know [that girl]2720-that girl . Who is [that girl]2720-that girl ? ’[75-tom] ‘ [Sissy Jupe]76-sissy , [sir]2713-sir , ’[258-number twenty] explained [number twenty]258-number twenty , blushing , standing up , and curtseying . ‘ [Sissy]76-sissy is not a name , ’[75-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom . ‘ Do n’t call [yourself]76-sissy [Sissy]76-sissy . Call [yourself]76-sissy [Cecilia]76-sissy . ’[75-tom] ‘ It ’s [father]2723-father as calls [me]259-the young girl [Sissy]76-sissy , [sir]2713-sir , ’[259-the young girl] returned [the young girl]259-the young girl in a trembling voice , and with another curtsey . ‘ Then [he]2723-father has no business to do it , ’[75-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom . ‘ Tell [him]2723-father [he]2723-father must n’t . [Cecilia Jupe]76-sissy . Let [me]75-tom see . What is [[your]76-sissy father]2725-your father ? ’[75-tom] ‘ [He]2723-father belongs to the horse - riding , if [you]2713-sir please , [sir]2713-sir . ’[75-tom] [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom frowned , and waved off the objectionable calling with [his]75-tom hand . ‘ [We]2727-us do n’t want to know anything about that , here . [You]2713-sir must n’t tell [us]2727-us about that , here . [[Your]76-sissy father]2725-your father breaks horses , do n’t [he]2725-your father ? ’[75-tom] ‘ If [you]2713-sir please , [sir]2713-sir , when [they]2730-they can get any to break , [they]2730-they do break horses in the ring , [sir]2713-sir . ’[75-tom] ‘ [You]2713-sir must n’t tell [us]2727-us about the ring , here . Very well , then . Describe [[your]76-sissy father]2725-your father as [a horsebreaker]2733-a horsebreaker . [He]2725-your father doctors sick horses , [I]75-tom dare say ? ’[75-tom] ‘ Oh yes , [sir]2713-sir . ’[75-tom] ‘ Very well , then . [He]2725-your father is [a veterinary surgeon]2735-a veterinary surgeon , [a farrier]2736-a farrier , and [horsebreaker]2737-horsebreaker . Give [me]75-tom [your]2713-sir definition of a horse . ’[75-tom] ( [Sissy Jupe]76-sissy thrown into the greatest alarm by this demand . ) ‘ Girl number twenty unable to define a horse ! ’[75-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom , for the general behoof of [all the little pitchers]260-all the little pitchers . ‘ [Girl number twenty]2719-girl number twenty possessed of no facts , in reference to one of the commonest of animals ! [Some boy]2739-some boy ’s definition of a horse . [Bitzer]77-bitzer , [yours]2713-sir . ’[75-tom] The square finger , moving here and there , lighted suddenly on [Bitzer]77-bitzer , perhaps because [he]77-bitzer chanced to sit in the same ray of sunlight which , darting in at one of the bare windows of [the intensely white - washed room]261-the intensely white - washed room , irradiated [Sissy]76-sissy . For , [the boys]262-the boys and [girls]2709-girls sat on the face of the inclined plane in two compact bodies , divided up the centre by a narrow interval ; and [Sissy]76-sissy , being at the corner of a row on the sunny side , came in for the beginning of a sunbeam , of which [Bitzer]77-bitzer , being at the corner of [a row on the other side]264-a row on the other side , a few rows in advance , caught the end . But , whereas [the girl]265-the girl was so dark - eyed and dark - haired , that [she]265-the girl seemed to receive a deeper and more lustrous colour from the sun , when it shone upon [her]265-the girl , [the boy]266-the boy was so light - eyed and light - haired that the self - same rays appeared to draw out of [him]266-the boy what little colour [he]266-the boy ever possessed . [His]266-the boy cold eyes would hardly have been eyes , but for the short ends of lashes which , by bringing them into immediate contrast with something paler than [themselves]267-themselves , expressed [their]267-themselves form . [His]266-the boy short - cropped hair might have been a mere continuation of the sandy freckles on [his]266-the boy forehead and face . [His]266-the boy skin was so unwholesomely deficient in the natural tinge , that [he]266-the boy looked as though , if [he]266-the boy were cut , [he]266-the boy would bleed white . ‘ [Bitzer]77-bitzer , ’[75-tom] said [Thomas Gradgrind]75-tom . ‘ [Your]77-bitzer definition of a horse . ’[75-tom] ‘ Quadruped . Graminivorous . Forty teeth , namely twenty - four grinders , four eye - teeth , and twelve incisive . Sheds coat in the spring ; in [marshy countries]2740-marshy countries , [sheds hoofs]2741-sheds hoofs , too . Hoofs hard , but requiring to be shod with iron . Age known by marks in mouth . ’[77-bitzer] Thus ( and much more ) [Bitzer]77-bitzer . ‘ Now [girl]2742-girl number twenty , ’[75-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom . ‘ [You]77-bitzer know what a horse is . ’[75-tom] [She]268-she curtseyed again , and would have blushed deeper , if [she]268-she could have blushed deeper than [she]268-she had blushed all this time . [Bitzer]77-bitzer , after rapidly blinking at [Thomas Gradgrind]75-tom with both eyes at once , and so catching the light upon [his]266-the boy quivering ends of lashes that they looked like the antennæ of busy insects , put [his]266-the boy knuckles to [his]266-the boy freckled forehead , and sat down again . [The third gentleman]269-the third gentleman now stepped forth . [A mighty man at cutting and drying]270-a mighty man at cutting and drying , [he]269-the third gentleman was ; [a government officer]271-a government officer ; in [his]269-the third gentleman way ( and in [most other people]272-most other people ’s too ) , [a professed pugilist]273-a professed pugilist ; always in training , always with a system to force down the general throat like a bolus , always to be heard of at the bar of [[his]269-the third gentleman little Public - office]274-his little public - office , ready to fight all [England]1-england . To continue in fistic phraseology , [he]269-the third gentleman had a genius for coming up to the scratch , wherever and whatever it was , and proving [himself]269-the third gentleman [an ugly customer]275-an ugly customer . [He]269-the third gentleman would go in and damage any subject whatever with [his]269-the third gentleman right , follow up with [his]269-the third gentleman left , stop , exchange , counter , bore [[his]269-the third gentleman opponent]276-his opponent ( [he]269-the third gentleman always fought All [England]1-england ) to the ropes , and fall upon [him]276-his opponent neatly . [He]269-the third gentleman was certain to knock the wind out of common sense , and render [that unlucky adversary]277-that unlucky adversary deaf to the call of time . And [he]269-the third gentleman had it in charge from high authority to bring about the great public - office Millennium , when [Commissioners]278-commissioners should reign upon [earth]279-earth . ‘ Very well , ’[280-this gentleman] said [this gentleman]280-this gentleman , briskly smiling , and folding [his]280-this gentleman arms . ‘ That ’s a horse . Now , let [me]280-this gentleman ask [you]282-the children [girls]2709-girls and [boys]2716-boys , Would [you]282-the children paper [a room with representations of horses]2745-a room with representations of horses ? ’[280-this gentleman] After a pause , [one half of [the children]282-the children]281-one half of the children cried in chorus , ‘ Yes , [sir]2713-sir ! ’[281-one half of the children] Upon which [the other half]283-the other half , seeing in [the gentleman]284-the gentleman ’s face that Yes was wrong , cried out in chorus , ‘ No , [sir!’—as]2747-sir!’—as the custom is , in these examinations . ‘[283-the other half] Of course , No . Why would n’t [you]280-this gentleman ? ’ A pause . [One corpulent slow boy]2748-one corpulent slow boy , with a wheezy manner of breathing , ventured the answer , Because [he]2748-one corpulent slow boy would n’t paper [a room]2749-a room at all , but would paint it . ‘[280-this gentleman] [You]280-this gentleman _ must _ paper it , ’ said [the gentleman]284-the gentleman , rather warmly . ‘[280-this gentleman] [You]280-this gentleman must paper it , ’ said [Thomas Gradgrind]75-tom , ‘[280-this gentleman] whether [you]280-this gentleman like it or not . Do n’t tell _ [us]285-us _ [you]280-this gentleman would n’t paper it . What do [you]280-this gentleman mean , [boy]286-boy ? ’ ‘[280-this gentleman] [I]0-i ’ll explain to [you]280-this gentleman , then , ’ said [the gentleman]284-the gentleman , after another and a dismal pause , ‘[0-i] why [you]280-this gentleman would n’t paper [a room with representations of horses]2745-a room with representations of horses . Do [you]280-this gentleman ever see horses walking up and down the sides of [rooms]288-rooms in reality — in fact ? Do [you]280-this gentleman ? ’ ‘[2713-sir] Yes , [sir]2713-sir ! ’ from [one half]2752-one half . ‘[2713-sir] No , [sir]2713-sir ! ’ from the other . ‘[2713-sir] Of course no , ’ said [the gentleman]284-the gentleman , with an indignant look at [the wrong half]2754-the wrong half . ‘[2713-sir] Why , then , [you]280-this gentleman are not to see anywhere , what [you]280-this gentleman do n’t see in fact ; [you]280-this gentleman are not to have anywhere , what [you]280-this gentleman do n’t have in fact . What is called Taste , is only another name for Fact . ’ [Thomas Gradgrind]75-tom nodded [his]75-tom approbation . ‘[2713-sir] This is a new principle , a discovery , a great discovery , ’ said [the gentleman]284-the gentleman . ‘[2713-sir] Now , [I]0-i ’ll try [you]280-this gentleman again . Suppose [you]280-this gentleman were going to carpet [a room]2749-a room . Would [you]280-this gentleman use a carpet having a representation of flowers upon it ? ’ There being a general conviction by this time that ‘[280-this gentleman] No , [sir]2713-sir ! ’ was always the right answer to [this gentleman]280-this gentleman , the chorus of NO was very strong . [Only a few feeble stragglers]2757-only a few feeble stragglers said Yes : among [them]2757-only a few feeble stragglers [Sissy Jupe]76-sissy . ‘[280-this gentleman] [Girl]2742-girl number twenty , ’ said [the gentleman]284-the gentleman , smiling in the calm strength of knowledge . [Sissy]76-sissy blushed , and stood up . ‘[2742-girl] So [you]280-this gentleman would carpet [[your]280-this gentleman room]294-your room — or [[[your]280-this gentleman husband]295-your husband ’s room]296-your husband ’s room , if [you]280-this gentleman were [a grown woman]297-a grown woman , and had [a husband]298-a husband — with representations of flowers , would [you]280-this gentleman ? ’ said [the gentleman]284-the gentleman . ‘[280-this gentleman] Why would [you]280-this gentleman ? ’ ‘[280-this gentleman] If [you]2713-sir please , [sir]2713-sir , [I]0-i am very fond of flowers , ’ returned [the girl]265-the girl . ‘[0-i] And is that why [you]2713-sir would put tables and chairs upon them , and have [people]300-people walking over [them]301-them with heavy boots ? ’ ‘[2713-sir] It would n’t hurt [them]301-them , [sir]2713-sir . [They]301-them would n’t crush and wither , if [you]2713-sir please , [sir]2713-sir . [They]301-them would be the pictures of what was very pretty and pleasant , and [I]0-i would fancy — ’ ‘[0-i] Ay , ay , ay ! But [you]2713-sir must n’t fancy , ’ cried [the gentleman]284-the gentleman , quite elated by coming so happily to [his]284-the gentleman point . ‘[2713-sir] That ’s it ! [You]2713-sir are never to fancy . ’ ‘[2713-sir] [You]2713-sir are not , [Cecilia Jupe]76-sissy , ’ [Thomas Gradgrind]75-tom solemnly repeated , ‘[2713-sir] to do anything of that kind . ’ ‘[2713-sir] Fact , fact , fact ! ’ said [the gentleman]284-the gentleman . And ‘[2713-sir] Fact , fact , fact ! ’ repeated [Thomas Gradgrind]75-tom . ‘[2713-sir] [You]2713-sir are to be in all things regulated and governed , ’ said [the gentleman]284-the gentleman , ‘[2713-sir] by fact . [We]304-we hope to have , before long , [a board of fact]305-a board of fact , composed of [commissioners of fact]306-commissioners of fact , who will force [the people]307-the people to be [a people of fact , and of nothing but fact]308-a people of fact , and of nothing but fact . [You]2713-sir must discard the word Fancy altogether . [You]2713-sir have nothing to do with it . [You]2713-sir are not to have , in any object of use or ornament , what would be a contradiction in fact . [You]2713-sir do n’t walk upon flowers in fact ; [you]2713-sir can not be allowed to walk upon flowers in carpets . [You]2713-sir do n’t find that foreign birds and butterflies come and perch upon [your]2713-sir crockery ; [you]2713-sir can not be permitted to paint foreign birds and butterflies upon [your]2713-sir crockery . [You]2713-sir never meet with quadrupeds going up and down walls ; [you]2713-sir must not have quadrupeds represented upon walls . [You]2713-sir must use , ’ said [the gentleman]284-the gentleman , ‘[2713-sir] for all these purposes , combinations and modifications ( in primary colours ) of mathematical figures which are susceptible of proof and demonstration . This is the new discovery . This is fact . This is taste . ’ [The girl]265-the girl curtseyed , and sat down . [She]265-the girl was very young , and [she]265-the girl looked as if [she]265-the girl were frightened by the matter - of - fact prospect [the world]2766-the world afforded . ‘[78-mr. m’choakumchild] Now , if [Mr. M’Choakumchild]78-mr. m’choakumchild , ’ said [the gentleman]284-the gentleman , ‘[78-mr. m’choakumchild] will proceed to give [his]78-mr. m’choakumchild first lesson here , [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom , [I]0-i shall be happy , at [your]2713-sir request , to observe [his]78-mr. m’choakumchild mode of procedure . ’ [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom was much obliged . ‘[78-mr. m’choakumchild] [Mr. M’Choakumchild]78-mr. m’choakumchild , [we]309-we only wait for [you]78-mr. m’choakumchild . ’ So , [Mr. M’Choakumchild]78-mr. m’choakumchild began in [his]78-mr. m’choakumchild best manner . [He]78-mr. m’choakumchild and [some one hundred and forty other schoolmasters]2768-some one hundred and forty other schoolmasters , had been lately turned at the same time , in [the same factory]2769-the same factory , on the same principles , like so many pianoforte legs . [He]78-mr. m’choakumchild had been put through an immense variety of paces , and had answered volumes of head - breaking questions . Orthography , etymology , syntax , and prosody , biography , astronomy , geography , and general cosmography , the sciences of compound proportion , algebra , land - surveying and levelling , vocal music , and drawing from models , were all at the ends of [his]78-mr. m’choakumchild ten chilled fingers . [He]78-mr. m’choakumchild had worked [his]78-mr. m’choakumchild stony way into [[Her]2770-her Majesty ’s most Honourable Privy Council ’s Schedule B]2-her majesty ’s most honourable privy council ’s schedule b , and had taken the bloom off the higher branches of mathematics and physical science , French , German , Latin , and Greek . [He]78-mr. m’choakumchild knew all about [all the Water Sheds of all [the world]2766-the world]2771-all the water sheds of all the world ( whatever [they]2771-all the water sheds of all the world are ) , and all the histories of [all the peoples]2773-all the peoples , and all the names of all [the rivers and mountains]2774-the rivers and mountains , and all the productions , manners , and customs of [all the countries]2775-all the countries , and all [their]2771-all the water sheds of all the world boundaries and bearings on the two and thirty points of the compass . Ah , rather overdone , M’Choakumchild . If [he]78-mr. m’choakumchild had only learnt a little less , how infinitely better [he]78-mr. m’choakumchild might have taught much more ! [He]78-mr. m’choakumchild went to work in this preparatory lesson , not unlike [Morgiana]79-morgiana in [the Forty Thieves]2776-the forty thieves : looking into all the vessels ranged before [him]78-mr. m’choakumchild , one after another , to see what they contained . Say , [good M’Choakumchild]78-mr. m’choakumchild . When from [[thy]78-mr. m’choakumchild boiling store]2777-thy boiling store , [thou]78-mr. m’choakumchild shalt fill each jar brim full by - and - by , dost [thou]78-mr. m’choakumchild think that [thou]78-mr. m’choakumchild wilt always kill outright the robber Fancy lurking within — or sometimes only maim [him]78-mr. m’choakumchild and distort [him]78-mr. m’choakumchild ! CHAPTER III A LOOPHOLE [MR . GRADGRIND]75-tom walked homeward from [the school]2778-the school , in a state of considerable satisfaction . It was [[his]75-tom school]2779-his school , and [he]75-tom intended it to be [a model]2780-a model . [He]75-tom intended [every child in]2781-every child in [it]2779-his school to be [a model]2780-a model — just as [the young Gradgrinds]2783-the young gradgrinds were [all models]2784-all models . There were [five young Gradgrinds]2785-five young gradgrinds , and [they]2785-five young gradgrinds were [models every one]2786-models every one . [They]2785-five young gradgrinds had been lectured at , from [their]2785-five young gradgrinds tenderest years ; coursed , like little hares . Almost as soon as [they]2785-five young gradgrinds could run alone , [they]2785-five young gradgrinds had been made to run to [the lecture - room]2787-the lecture - room . The first object with which [they]2785-five young gradgrinds had an association , or of which [they]2785-five young gradgrinds had a remembrance , was a large black board with a dry Ogre chalking ghastly white figures on it . Not that [they]2785-five young gradgrinds knew , by name or nature , anything about [an Ogre Fact forbid]2788-an ogre fact forbid ! [I]78-mr. m’choakumchild only use the word to express a monster in [a lecturing castle]2789-a lecturing castle , with [Heaven]80-heaven knows how many heads manipulated into one , taking [childhood captive]2790-childhood captive , and dragging it into gloomy statistical dens by the hair . [No little Gradgrind]75-tom had ever seen a face in the moon ; it was up in the moon before it could speak distinctly . [No little Gradgrind]75-tom had ever learnt the silly jingle , Twinkle , twinkle , little star ; how [I]78-mr. m’choakumchild wonder what [you]2791-you are ! [No little Gradgrind]2792-no little gradgrind had ever known wonder on the subject , [each little Gradgrind]2793-each little gradgrind having at five years old dissected [the Great Bear]81-the great bear like [a Professor Owen]82-a professor owen , and driven [Charles]83-charles ’s Wain like [a locomotive engine - driver]2794-a locomotive engine - driver . [No little Gradgrind]75-tom had ever associated a cow in [a field]2795-a field with that famous cow with the crumpled horn who tossed the dog who worried the cat who killed the rat who ate the malt , or with [that yet more famous cow who swallowed [Tom Thumb]84-tom thumb]2796-that yet more famous cow who swallowed tom thumb : it had never heard of [those celebrities]2797-those celebrities , and had only been introduced to a cow as a graminivorous ruminating quadruped with several stomachs . To [[his]2792-no little gradgrind matter - of - fact home]2798-his matter - of - fact home , which was called [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge , [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom directed [his]2792-no little gradgrind steps . [He]2792-no little gradgrind had virtually retired from the wholesale hardware trade before [he]2792-no little gradgrind built [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge , and was now looking about for a suitable opportunity of making [an arithmetical figure in Parliament]2799-an arithmetical figure in parliament . [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge was situated on [a moor within a mile or two of [a great town]2801-a great town]2800-a moor within a mile or two of a great town — called [Coketown]4-coketown in the present faithful guide - book . A very regular feature on the face of [the country]2802-the country , [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge was . Not the least disguise toned down or shaded off that uncompromising fact in [the landscape]2803-the landscape . [A great square house]2804-a great square house , with a heavy portico darkening the principal windows , as [its]2804-a great square house master ’s heavy brows overshadowed [his]2792-no little gradgrind eyes . A calculated , cast up , balanced , and [proved house]2805-proved house . Six windows on this side of the door , six on that side ; a total of twelve in [this wing]2806-this wing , a total of twelve in [the other wing]2807-the other wing ; four - and - twenty carried over to [the back wings]2808-the back wings . [A lawn and garden]2809-a lawn and garden and [an infant avenue]2810-an infant avenue , all ruled straight like a botanical account - book . Gas and ventilation , drainage and water - service , all of the primest quality . Iron clamps and girders , fire - proof from top to bottom ; mechanical lifts for [the housemaids]2811-the housemaids , with all [their]2811-the housemaids brushes and brooms ; everything that heart could desire . Everything ? Well , [I]78-mr. m’choakumchild suppose so . [The little Gradgrinds]85-the little gradgrinds had cabinets in various departments of science too . [They]85-the little gradgrinds had a little conchological cabinet , and a little metallurgical cabinet , and a little mineralogical cabinet ; and the specimens were all arranged and labelled , and the bits of stone and ore looked as though they might have been broken from the parent substances by those tremendously hard instruments [their]85-the little gradgrinds own names ; and , to paraphrase the idle legend of [Peter Piper]86-peter piper , who had never found [his]86-peter piper way into [[their]2813-the greedy little gradgrinds nursery]2812-their nursery , If [the greedy little Gradgrinds]2813-the greedy little gradgrinds grasped at more than this , what was it for good gracious goodness ’[78-mr. m’choakumchild] sake , that [the greedy little Gradgrinds]2813-the greedy little gradgrinds grasped it ! [[Their]2813-the greedy little gradgrinds father]311-their father walked on in a hopeful and satisfied frame of mind . [He]311-their father was [an affectionate father]312-an affectionate father , after [his]311-their father manner ; but [he]311-their father would probably have described [himself]311-their father ( if [he]311-their father had been put , like [Sissy Jupe]76-sissy , upon a definition ) as ‘ [an eminently practical ’[311-their father] father]2814-an eminently practical ’ father . [He]311-their father had a particular pride in the phrase eminently practical , which was considered to have a special application to [him]311-their father . Whatsoever the public meeting held in [Coketown]4-coketown , and whatsoever the subject of such meeting , [some Coketowner]313-some coketowner was sure to seize the occasion of alluding to [[his]313-some coketowner eminently practical friend]314-his eminently practical friend [Gradgrind]75-tom . This always pleased [the eminently practical friend]315-the eminently practical friend . [He]311-their father knew it to be [his]311-their father due , but [his]311-their father due was acceptable . [He]311-their father had reached the neutral ground upon [the outskirts of [the town]317-the town]316-the outskirts of the town , which was neither [town nor country]318-town nor country , and yet was either spoiled , when [his]311-their father ears were invaded by the sound of music . The clashing and banging band attached to the horse - riding establishment , which had there set up [its]319-its rest in [a wooden pavilion]320-a wooden pavilion , was in full bray . A flag , floating from the summit of [the temple]321-the temple , proclaimed to [mankind]322-mankind that it was ‘ Sleary ’s Horse - riding ’[87-mr. sleary] which claimed [their]322-mankind suffrages . [Sleary]87-mr. sleary [himself]87-mr. sleary , a stout modern statue with a money - box at its elbow , in an ecclesiastical niche of [early Gothic architecture]323-early gothic architecture , took the money . [Miss Josephine Sleary]88-josephine , as some very long and very narrow strips of printed bill announced , was then inaugurating the entertainments with [her]88-josephine graceful equestrian Tyrolean flower - act . Among the other pleasing but always strictly moral wonders which must be seen to be believed , [Signor Jupe]89-signor jupe was that afternoon to ‘ elucidate the diverting accomplishments of [his]89-signor jupe highly trained performing dog Merrylegs . ’[89-signor jupe] [He]89-signor jupe was also to exhibit ‘ [his]89-signor jupe astounding feat of throwing seventy - five hundred - weight in rapid succession backhanded over [his]89-signor jupe head , thus forming a fountain of solid iron in mid - air , a feat never before attempted in this or [any other country]2815-any other country , and which having elicited such rapturous plaudits from [enthusiastic throngs]2816-enthusiastic throngs it can not be withdrawn . ’[89-signor jupe] The same [Signor Jupe]89-signor jupe was to ‘ enliven the varied performances at frequent intervals with [his]89-signor jupe chaste Shaksperean quips and retorts . ’[89-signor jupe] Lastly , [he]89-signor jupe was to wind them up by appearing in [his]89-signor jupe favourite character of [Mr. William Button]90-mr. william button , of [Tooley Street]5-tooley street , in ‘ the highly novel and laughable hippo - comedietta of [The Tailor]2817-the tailor ’s Journey to [Brentford]6-brentford . ’[89-signor jupe] [Thomas Gradgrind]75-tom took no heed of these trivialities of course , but passed on as [a practical man]324-a practical man ought to pass on , either brushing the noisy insects from [his]75-tom thoughts , or consigning them to [the House of Correction]325-the house of correction . But , the turning of [the road]326-the road took [him]75-tom by the back of the booth , and at the back of [the booth]327-the booth [a number of children]328-a number of children were congregated in a number of stealthy attitudes , striving to peep in at the hidden glories of [the place]329-the place . This brought [him]75-tom to a stop . ‘ Now , to think of [these vagabonds]2818-these vagabonds , ’[75-tom] said [he]75-tom , ‘ attracting [the young rabble]2819-the young rabble from [a model school]2820-a model school . ’[75-tom] A space of stunted grass and dry rubbish being between [him]75-tom and [the young rabble]2819-the young rabble , [he]75-tom took [his]75-tom eyeglass out of [his]75-tom waistcoat to look for [any child [he]75-tom knew by name]331-any child he knew by name , and might order off . Phenomenon almost incredible though distinctly seen , what did [he]75-tom then behold but [his]75-tom own metallurgical [Louisa]91-louisa , peeping with all [her]91-louisa might through a hole in a deal board , and [his]75-tom own mathematical [Thomas]75-tom abasing [himself]75-tom on the ground to catch but a hoof of the graceful equestrian Tyrolean flower - act ! Dumb with amazement , [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom crossed to the spot where [[his]75-tom family]332-his family was thus disgraced , laid [his]75-tom hand upon [each erring child]333-each erring child , and said : ‘ [Louisa]91-louisa ! ! [Thomas]75-tom ! ! ’[75-tom] [Both]334-both rose , red and disconcerted . But , [Louisa]91-louisa looked at [[her]91-louisa father]335-her father with more boldness than [Thomas]75-tom did . Indeed , [Thomas]75-tom did not look at [him]335-her father , but gave [himself]75-tom up to be taken [home]336-home like a machine . ‘ In the name of wonder , idleness , and folly ! ’[75-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom , leading [each]337-each away by a hand ; ‘ what do [you]91-louisa do here ? ’[75-tom] ‘ Wanted to see what it was like , ’[91-louisa] returned [Louisa]91-louisa , shortly . ‘ What it was like ? ’[91-louisa] ‘ Yes , [father]2723-father . ’[75-tom] There was an air of jaded sullenness in [them]334-both both , and particularly in [the girl]265-the girl : yet , struggling through the dissatisfaction of [her]265-the girl face , there was a light with nothing to rest upon , a fire with nothing to burn , a starved imagination keeping life in itself somehow , which brightened its expression . Not with the brightness natural to cheerful youth , but with uncertain , eager , doubtful flashes , which had something painful in them , analogous to the changes on a blind face groping its way . [She]265-the girl was [a child]339-a child now , of fifteen or sixteen ; but at no distant day would seem to become [a woman all at once]340-a woman all at once . [[Her]265-the girl father]335-her father thought so as [he]335-her father looked at [her]265-the girl . [She]265-the girl was pretty . CHAPTER IV [MR . BOUNDERBY NOT]92-mr. bounderby being [Mrs. Grundy]93-mrs. grundy , who _ was _ [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ? [He]92-mr. bounderby was [a rich man]2830-a rich man : [banker]2831-banker , [merchant]2832-merchant , [manufacturer]2833-manufacturer , and what not . [A big , loud man , with a stare , and a metallic laugh]2834-a big , loud man , with a stare , and a metallic laugh . [One]2846-one might have fancied [he]92-mr. bounderby had talked it off ; and that what was left , all standing up in disorder , was in that condition from being constantly blown about by [his]92-mr. bounderby windy boastfulness . In [the formal drawing - room of [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge]2847-the formal drawing - room of stone lodge , standing on the hearthrug , warming [himself]92-mr. bounderby before the fire , [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby delivered some observations to [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind on the circumstance of its being [his]92-mr. bounderby birthday . [He]92-mr. bounderby stood before the fire , partly because it was a cool spring afternoon , though the sun shone ; partly because the shade of [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge was always haunted by the ghost of damp mortar ; partly because [he]92-mr. bounderby thus took up a commanding position , from which to subdue [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind . ‘[343-the astonished father] [I]0-i had n’t a shoe to [my]0-i foot . Not that a ditch was new to [me]0-i , for [I]0-i was born in a ditch . ’ [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind , [a little , thin , white , pink - eyed bundle of shawls , of surpassing feebleness , mental and bodily]2848-a little , thin , white , pink - eyed bundle of shawls , of surpassing feebleness , mental and bodily ; [who was always taking physic without any effect]2849-who was always taking physic without any effect , and who , whenever [she]94-mrs. gradgrind showed a symptom of coming to life , was invariably stunned by some weighty piece of fact tumbling on [her]94-mrs. gradgrind ; [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind hoped it was [a dry ditch]2850-a dry ditch ? ‘[0-i] No ! Why , [I]0-i have known [that grandmother of [mine]0-i]361-that grandmother of mine lie in [her]358-my grandmother bed and drink [her]358-my grandmother four - teen glasses of liquor before breakfast ! ’ [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind , weakly smiling , and giving no other sign of vitality , looked ( as [she]94-mrs. gradgrind always did ) like an indifferently executed transparency of [a small female figure]2853-a small female figure , without enough light behind it . ‘[358-my grandmother] [She]358-my grandmother kept [[a chandler]362-a chandler ’s shop]363-a chandler ’s shop , ’ pursued [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[358-my grandmother] and kept [me]0-i in an egg - box . That was the cot of _ [my]0-i _ infancy ; an old egg - box . As soon as [I]0-i was big enough to run away , of course [I]0-i ran away . Then [I]0-i became [a young vagabond]364-a young vagabond ; and instead of [one old woman]365-one old woman knocking [me]0-i about and starving [me]0-i , [everybody of all ages]366-everybody of all ages knocked [me]0-i about and starved [me]0-i . [I]0-i would n’t cry ! ’ CHAPTER V THE KEYNOTE [COKETOWN]4-coketown , to which [Messrs. Bounderby and Gradgrind]101-messrs. bounderby and gradgrind now walked , was a triumph of fact ; it had no greater taint of fancy in it than [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind [herself]94-mrs. gradgrind . Let [us]2890-us strike the key - note , [Coketown]4-coketown , before pursuing [our]2890-us tune . [It]4-coketown was [a town of red brick]2891-a town of red brick , or [of brick that would have been red if the smoke and ashes had allowed]2892-of brick that would have been red if the smoke and ashes had allowed [it]4-coketown ; but as matters stood , [it]4-coketown was [a town of unnatural red and black like the painted face of a savage]2893-a town of unnatural red and black like the painted face of a savage . [It]4-coketown was [a town of machinery]2894-a town of machinery and tall chimneys , out of which interminable serpents of smoke trailed themselves for ever and ever , and never got uncoiled . [It]4-coketown had [a black canal]2895-a black canal in [it]4-coketown , and [a river that ran purple with ill - smelling dye]2896-a river that ran purple with ill - smelling dye , and vast piles of building full of windows where there was a rattling and a trembling all day long , and where the piston of the steam - engine worked monotonously up and down , like the head of an elephant in a state of melancholy madness . [It]4-coketown contained [several large streets]2897-several large streets all very like [one another]2898-one another , and [many small streets]2899-many small streets still more like one another , inhabited by [people equally like one another]2900-people equally like one another , who [all went in and out at the same hours , with the same sound upon the same pavements , to do the same work , and to whom every day was the same as yesterday and to - morrow]2901-all went in and out at the same hours , with the same sound upon the same pavements , to do the same work , and to whom every day was the same as yesterday and to - morrow , and every year the counterpart of the last and the next . These attributes of [Coketown]4-coketown were in the main inseparable from the work by which it was sustained ; against them were to be set off , comforts of life which found their way all over [the world]2766-the world , and elegancies of life which made , [we]2903-we will not ask how much of [the fine lady]2904-the fine lady , who could scarcely bear to hear [the place]329-the place mentioned . The rest of [its]4-coketown features were voluntary , and they were these . [You]2906-you saw nothing in [Coketown]4-coketown but what was severely workful . If [the members of a religious persuasion]2907-the members of a religious persuasion built [a chapel]2908-a chapel [there]412-there — as [the members of eighteen religious persuasions]2910-the members of eighteen religious persuasions had done — [they]2907-the members of a religious persuasion made [it]412-there [a pious warehouse of red brick]2911-a pious warehouse of red brick , with sometimes ( but this is only in highly ornamental examples ) a bell in a birdcage on the top of it . The solitary exception was [the New Church]2912-the new church ; [a stuccoed edifice with a square steeple over the door , terminating in four short pinnacles like florid wooden legs]2913-a stuccoed edifice with a square steeple over the door , terminating in four short pinnacles like florid wooden legs . All the public inscriptions in [the town]317-the town were painted alike , in severe characters of black and white . [The jail]2915-the jail might have been [the infirmary]2916-the infirmary , [the infirmary]2916-the infirmary might have been [the jail]2915-the jail , [the town - hall]2919-the town - hall might have been either , or both , or anything else , for anything that appeared to the contrary in the graces of [their]2919-the town - hall construction . Fact , fact , fact , everywhere in the material aspect of [the town]317-the town ; fact , fact , fact , everywhere in the immaterial . [The M’Choakumchild school]2921-the m’choakumchild school was all fact , and the school of design was all fact , and the relations between [master]2922-master and [man]2923-man were all fact , and everything was fact between [the lying - in hospital]2924-the lying - in hospital and [the cemetery]2925-the cemetery , and what [you]2926-you could n’t state in figures , or show to be purchaseable in the cheapest market and saleable in the dearest , was not , and never should be , world without end , Amen . [A town so sacred to fact , and so triumphant in [its]2927-a town so sacred to fact , and so triumphant in its assertion assertion]2927-a town so sacred to fact , and so triumphant in its assertion , of course got on well ? Why no , not quite well . No ? Dear [me]0-i ! No . [Coketown]4-coketown did not come out of [its]4-coketown own furnaces , in all respects like gold that had stood the fire . First , the perplexing mystery of [the place]329-the place was , Who belonged to [the eighteen denominations]2929-the eighteen denominations ? Because , whoever did , [the labouring people]2930-the labouring people did not . It was very strange to walk through [the streets]2931-the streets on a Sunday morning , and note how few of _ [them]2930-the labouring people _ the barbarous jangling of bells that was driving [the sick and nervous mad]2932-the sick and nervous mad , called away from [[their]2930-the labouring people own quarter]2933-their own quarter , from [[their]2930-the labouring people own close rooms]2934-their own close rooms , from the corners of [[their]2930-the labouring people own streets]2935-their own streets , where [they]2930-the labouring people lounged listlessly , gazing at all [the church]2936-the church and [chapel going]2937-chapel going , as at a thing with which [they]2930-the labouring people had no manner of concern . Nor was it merely [the stranger who noticed this]2938-the stranger who noticed this , because there was [a native organization in [Coketown]4-coketown [itself]4-coketown , whose members]2939-a native organization in coketown itself , whose members were to be heard of in [the House of Commons]2940-the house of commons every session , indignantly petitioning for acts of parliament that should make [these people religious by main force]2941-these people religious by main force . Then came [the Teetotal Society]2942-the teetotal society , who complained that [these same people]2943-these same people _ would _ get drunk , and showed in tabular statements that [they]2943-these same people did get drunk , and proved at tea parties that no inducement , human or Divine ( except a medal ) , would induce [them]2943-these same people to forego [their]2943-these same people custom of getting drunk . Then came [the chemist]2944-the chemist and [druggist]2945-druggist , with other tabular statements , showing that when [they]2943-these same people did n’t get drunk , [they]2943-these same people took opium . Then came [the experienced chaplain of [the jail]2915-the jail]2946-the experienced chaplain of the jail , with more tabular statements , outdoing all the previous tabular statements , and showing that [the same people]2948-the same people _ would _ resort to low haunts , hidden from the public eye , where [they]2948-the same people heard low singing and saw low dancing , and mayhap joined in it ; and where [A. B.]102-a. b. , aged twenty - four next birthday , and committed for eighteen months ’[0-i] solitary , had [himself]431-he said ( not that [he]431-he had ever shown [himself]431-he particularly worthy of belief ) [his]431-he ruin began , as [he]431-he was perfectly sure and confident that otherwise [he]431-he would have been [a tip - top moral specimen]432-a tip - top moral specimen . Then came [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom and [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , [the two gentlemen at this present moment walking through [Coketown]4-coketown , and both eminently practical , who could , on occasion , furnish more tabular statements derived from [their]434-their own personal experience , and illustrated by cases [they]434-their had known and seen , from which it clearly appeared — in short , it was the only clear thing in the case]433-the two gentlemen at this present moment walking through coketown , and both eminently practical , who could , on occasion , furnish more tabular statements derived from their own personal experience , and illustrated by cases they had known and seen , from which it clearly appeared — in short , it was the only clear thing in the case — that [these same people were a bad lot altogether]435-these same people were a bad lot altogether , [gentlemen]436-gentlemen ; that do what [you]437-you would for [them]435-these same people were a bad lot altogether [they]435-these same people were a bad lot altogether were never thankful for it , [gentlemen]436-gentlemen ; that [they]435-these same people were a bad lot altogether were restless , [gentlemen]436-gentlemen ; that [they]435-these same people were a bad lot altogether never knew what [they]435-these same people were a bad lot altogether wanted ; that [they]435-these same people were a bad lot altogether lived upon the best , and bought fresh butter ; and insisted on Mocha coffee , and rejected all but prime parts of meat , and yet were eternally dissatisfied and unmanageable . In short , it was the moral of the old nursery fable : There was [an old woman]440-an old woman , and what do [you]437-you think ? [She]440-an old woman lived upon nothing but victuals and drink ; Victuals and drink were the whole of [her]440-an old woman diet , And yet [this old woman]441-this old woman would NEVER be quiet . Is it possible , [I]0-i wonder , that there was any analogy between the case of [the Coketown population]442-the coketown population and the case of [the little Gradgrinds]85-the little gradgrinds ? Surely , none of [us]443-us in [our]443-us sober senses and acquainted with [figures]444-figures , are to be told at this time of day , that one of the foremost elements in the existence of [the Coketown working - people]445-the coketown working - people had been for scores of years , deliberately set at nought ? That there was any Fancy in [them]435-these same people were a bad lot altogether demanding to be brought into healthy existence instead of struggling on in convulsions ? That exactly in the ratio as [they]435-these same people were a bad lot altogether worked long and monotonously , the craving grew within [them]435-these same people were a bad lot altogether for some physical relief — some relaxation , encouraging good humour and good spirits , and giving [them]435-these same people were a bad lot altogether a vent — some recognized holiday , though it were but for an honest dance to a stirring band of music — some occasional light pie in which even [M’Choakumchild]78-mr. m’choakumchild had no finger — which craving must and would be satisfied aright , or must and would inevitably go wrong , until the laws of the Creation were repealed ? ‘ [This man]2949-this man lives at [Pod ’s End]9-pod ’s end , and [I]75-tom do n’t quite know [Pod ’s End]9-pod ’s end , ’[75-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom . ‘ Which is it , [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ? ’[75-tom] [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby knew it was [somewhere down [town]427-town]446-somewhere down town , but knew no more respecting [it]446-somewhere down town . [The Pegasus]105-the pegasus ’s legs might have been more to the purpose ; but , underneath the winged horse upon the sign - board , [the Pegasus]105-the pegasus ’s Arms was inscribed in Roman letters . Beneath that inscription again , in a flowing scroll , [the painter]2989-the painter had touched off the lines : Good malt makes good beer , Walk in , and [they]2990-they ’ll draw it here ; Good wine makes good brandy , Give [us]2991-us a call , and [you]2713-sir ’ll find it handy . Framed and glazed upon the wall behind the dingy little bar , was another Pegasus — a theatrical one — with real gauze let in for [his]105-the pegasus wings , golden stars stuck on all over [him]105-the pegasus , and [his]105-the pegasus ethereal harness made of red silk . As it had grown too dusky without , to see the sign , and as it had not grown light enough within to see the picture , [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom and [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby received no offence from these idealities . [They]478-they followed [the girl]265-the girl up [some steep corner - stairs]2993-some steep corner - stairs without meeting [any one]2994-any one , and stopped in the dark while [she]265-the girl went on for a candle . [They]478-they expected every moment to hear [Merrylegs]104-merrylegs give tongue , but the highly trained performing dog had not barked when [the girl]265-the girl and the candle appeared together . ‘[92-mr. bounderby] [Father]106-father is not in [[our]478-they room]479-our room , [sir]2713-sir , ’ [she]265-the girl said , with a face of great surprise . ‘[2713-sir] If [you]2713-sir would n’t mind walking in , [I]0-i ’ll find [him]106-father directly . ’ [They]478-they walked in ; and [Sissy]76-sissy , having set two chairs for [them]478-they , sped away with a quick light step . The white night - cap , embellished with two peacock ’s feathers and a pigtail bolt upright , in which [Signor Jupe]89-signor jupe had that very afternoon enlivened the varied performances with [his]89-signor jupe chaste Shaksperean quips and retorts , hung upon a nail ; but no other portion of [his]89-signor jupe wardrobe , or other token of [himself]89-signor jupe or [his]89-signor jupe pursuits , was to be seen anywhere . [His]3001-a young man legs were very robust , but shorter than legs of good proportions should have been . [He]3001-a young man was dressed in a Newmarket coat and tight - fitting trousers ; wore a shawl round [his]3001-a young man neck ; smelt of lamp - oil , straw , orange - peel , horses ’[485-she] provender , and sawdust ; and looked a most remarkable sort of Centaur , compounded of [the stable]487-the stable and [the play - house]488-the play - house . Where the one began , and the other ended , [nobody]353-nobody could have told with any precision . [This gentleman]280-this gentleman was mentioned in the bills of the day as [Mr. E. W. B. [[Your]3073-my dear father father]2725-your father has absconded — deserted [you]3073-my dear father — and [you]3073-my dear father must n’t expect to see [him]2725-your father again as long as [you]3073-my dear father live . ’[92-mr. bounderby] [They]546-they cared so little for plain Fact , [these people]3064-these people , and were in that advanced state of degeneracy on the subject , that instead of being impressed by [the speaker]234-the speaker ’s strong common sense , [they]546-they took it in extraordinary dudgeon . [The men]549-the men muttered ‘ Shame ! ’[549-the men] and [the women]550-the women ‘ Brute ! ’[87-mr. sleary] and [Sleary]87-mr. sleary , in some haste , communicated the following hint , apart to [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby tell [you]3073-my dear father what , [Thquire]115-thquire . To thpeak plain to [you]3073-my dear father , [my]92-mr. bounderby opinion ith that [you]3073-my dear father had better cut it thort , and drop it . [They]551-a very good natur’d people ’re[92-mr. bounderby] [a very good natur’d people]551-a very good natur’d people , [[my]0-i people]552-my people , but [they]551-a very good natur’d people ’re accuthtomed to be quick in [their]551-a very good natur’d people movementh ; and if [you]3073-my dear father do n’t act upon [my]92-mr. bounderby advithe , [I]92-mr. bounderby ’m[92-mr. bounderby] damned if [I]0-i do n’t believe [they]551-a very good natur’d people ’ll pith [you]92-mr. bounderby out o ’ winder . ’[92-mr. bounderby] [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby being restrained by this mild suggestion , [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom found an opening for [his]75-tom eminently practical exposition of the subject . ‘ It is of no moment , ’[75-tom] said [he]75-tom , ‘ whether [this person]3079-this person is to be expected back at any time , or the contrary . [He]3079-this person is gone away , and there is no present expectation of [his]3079-this person return . That , [I]75-tom believe , is agreed on all hands . ’[75-tom] ‘ Thath agreed , Thquire . Thick to that ! ’[87-mr. sleary] From [Sleary]87-mr. sleary . ‘ Well then . [I]87-mr. sleary , who came here to inform [the father of [the poor girl]535-the poor girl]3080-the father of the poor girl , [Jupe]76-sissy , that [she]535-the poor girl could not be received at [the school]2778-the school any more , in consequence of there being practical objections , into which [I]87-mr. sleary need not enter , to the reception there of [the children of [persons so employed]3084-persons so employed]3083-the children of persons so employed , am prepared in these altered circumstances to make a proposal . [I]87-mr. sleary am willing to take charge of [you]92-mr. bounderby , [Jupe]76-sissy , and to educate [you]92-mr. bounderby , and provide for [you]92-mr. bounderby . The only condition ( over and above [your]92-mr. bounderby good behaviour ) [I]87-mr. sleary make is , that [you]92-mr. bounderby decide now , at once , whether to accompany [me]87-mr. sleary or remain [here]354-here . Also , that if [you]92-mr. bounderby accompany [me]87-mr. sleary now , it is understood that [you]92-mr. bounderby communicate no more with any of [[your]92-mr. bounderby friends]3086-your friends who are here present . These observations comprise the whole of the case . ’[87-mr. sleary] ‘ At the thame time , ’[87-mr. sleary] said [Sleary]87-mr. sleary , ‘ [I]87-mr. sleary mutht put in [my]87-mr. sleary word , Thquire , tho that both thides of the banner may be equally theen . If [you]92-mr. bounderby like , [Thethilia]117-thethilia , to be prentitht , [you]92-mr. bounderby know the natur of the work and [you]92-mr. bounderby know [your]92-mr. bounderby companionth . [Emma Gordon]118-emma gordon , in whothe lap [you]554-you ’re[87-mr. sleary] a lying at prethent , would be [a mother]553-a mother to [you]554-you , and [Joth’phine]119-joth’phine would be a thithter to [you]554-you . [I]0-i do n’t pretend to be of [the angel breed]555-the angel breed [myself]0-i , and [I]0-i do n’t thay but what , when [you]554-you mith’d [your]554-you tip , [you]554-you ’d find [me]0-i cut up rough , and thwear an oath or two at [you]554-you . But what [I]0-i thay , Thquire , ith , [that good tempered or bad tempered]556-that good tempered or bad tempered , [I]0-i never did a horthe a injury yet , no more than thwearing at [him]557-him went , and that [I]0-i do n’t expect [I]0-i thall begin otherwithe at [my]0-i time of life , with [a rider]558-a rider . [I]0-i never wath much of [a Cackler , Thquire]559-a cackler , thquire , and [I]0-i have thed [my]0-i thay . ’ The latter part of this speech was addressed to [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom , who received it with a grave inclination of [his]75-tom head , and then remarked : ‘[0-i] The only observation [I]0-i will make to [you]554-you , [Jupe]76-sissy , in the way of influencing [your]554-you decision , is , that it is highly desirable to have a sound practical education , and that even [[your]554-you father]2725-your father [himself]2725-your father ( from what [I]0-i understand ) appears , on [your]554-you behalf , to have known and felt that much . ’ The last words had a visible effect upon [her]554-you . [She]554-you stopped in [her]554-you wild crying , a little detached [herself]554-you from [Emma Gordon]118-emma gordon , and turned [her]554-you face full upon [[her]554-you patron]3087-her patron . [The whole company]3063-the whole company perceived the force of the change , and drew a long breath together , that plainly said , ‘[76-sissy] [she]561-she will go ! ’ ‘[554-you] Be sure [you]554-you know [your]554-you own mind , [Jupe]76-sissy , ’ [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom cautioned [her]554-you ; ‘[0-i] [I]0-i say no more . Be sure [you]554-you know [your]554-you own mind ! ’ ‘[554-you] When [father]2723-father comes back , ’ cried [the girl]265-the girl , bursting into tears again after a minute ’s silence , ‘[2723-father] how will [he]2723-father ever find [me]0-i if [I]0-i go away ! ’ ‘[2723-father] [You]554-you may be quite at ease , ’ said [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom , calmly ; [he]75-tom worked out the whole matter like a sum : ‘[554-you] [you]554-you may be quite at ease , [Jupe]76-sissy , on that score . Not athamed of it . [I]0-i should have no power of keeping [you]554-you against [his]87-mr. sleary wish , and [he]87-mr. sleary would have no difficulty , at any time , in finding [Mr. Thomas Gradgrind]75-tom of [Coketown]4-coketown . [I]0-i am well known . ’ ‘[0-i] Well known , ’ assented [Mr. Sleary]87-mr. sleary , rolling [his]87-mr. sleary loose eye . ‘[554-you] [You]554-you ’re one of the thort , Thquire , that keepth a prethiouth thight of money out of the houthe . But never mind that at prethent . ’[554-you] There was another silence ; and then [she]554-you exclaimed , sobbing with [her]554-you hands before [her]554-you face , ‘ Oh , give [me]554-you [my]554-you clothes , give [me]554-you [my]554-you clothes , and let [me]554-you go away before [I]554-you break [my]554-you heart ! ’[554-you] [The women]550-the women sadly bestirred [themselves]550-the women to get the clothes together — it was soon done , for [they]550-the women were not many — and to pack them in a basket which had often travelled with [them]550-the women . [Sissy]76-sissy sat all the time upon the ground , still sobbing , and covering [her]76-sissy eyes . [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom and [[his]75-tom friend]2878-his friend [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby stood near the door , ready to take [her]76-sissy away . [Mr. Sleary]87-mr. sleary stood in the middle of [the room]2859-the room , with [the male members of [the company]570-the company]569-the male members of the company about [him]87-mr. sleary , exactly as [he]87-mr. sleary would have stood in the centre of the ring during [[his]87-mr. sleary daughter]345-his daughter [Josephine]88-josephine ’s performance . [He]87-mr. sleary wanted nothing but [his]87-mr. sleary whip . The basket packed in silence , [they]569-the male members of the company brought [her]76-sissy bonnet to [her]76-sissy , and smoothed [her]76-sissy disordered hair , and put it on . Then [they]569-the male members of the company pressed about [her]76-sissy , and bent over [her]76-sissy in very natural attitudes , kissing and embracing [her]76-sissy : and brought [the children]282-the children to take leave of [her]76-sissy ; and were [a tender - hearted , simple , foolish set of [women]574-women]573-a tender - hearted , simple , foolish set of women altogether . ‘ Now , [Jupe]76-sissy , ’[75-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom . ‘ If [you]76-sissy are quite determined , come ! ’[75-tom] But [she]76-sissy had to take [her]76-sissy farewell of [the male part of the company]575-the male part of the company yet , and [every one of [them]569-the male members of the company]576-every one of them had to unfold [his]576-every one of them arms ( for [they]569-the male members of the company all assumed the professional attitude when [they]569-the male members of the company found [themselves]569-the male members of the company near [Sleary]87-mr. sleary ) , and give [her]76-sissy a parting kiss — [Master Kidderminster]109-master kidderminster excepted , in whose young nature there was an original flavour of the misanthrope , who was also known to have harboured matrimonial views , and who moodily withdrew . [Mr. Sleary]87-mr. sleary was reserved until the last . Opening [his]87-mr. sleary arms wide [he]87-mr. sleary took [her]76-sissy by both [her]76-sissy hands , and would have sprung [her]76-sissy up and down , after the riding - master manner of congratulating [young ladies]577-young ladies on [their]577-young ladies dismounting from a rapid act ; but there was no rebound in [Sissy]76-sissy , and [she]76-sissy only stood before [him]87-mr. sleary crying . ‘ Good - bye , [[my]87-mr. sleary dear]3090-my dear ! ’[87-mr. sleary] said [Sleary]87-mr. sleary . ‘ [You]3090-my dear ’ll make [your]3090-my dear fortun , [I]87-mr. sleary hope , and [none of [[our]3092-our poor folkth]3093-our poor folkth]3091-none of our poor folkth will ever trouble [you]3090-my dear , [I]87-mr. sleary ’ll pound it . [I]87-mr. sleary with [[your]3090-my dear father]2725-your father had n’t taken [hith]3095-hith dog with [him]87-mr. sleary ; ith a ill - conwenienth to have the dog out of the billth . But on thecond thoughth , [he]87-mr. sleary would n’t have performed without [hith mathter]121-hith mathter , tho ith ath broad ath ith long ! ’[87-mr. sleary] With that [he]87-mr. sleary regarded [her]578-her attentively with [his]87-mr. sleary fixed eye , surveyed [his]87-mr. sleary company with [his]87-mr. sleary loose one , kissed [her]578-her , shook [his]87-mr. sleary head , and handed [her]578-her to [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom as to a horse . ‘ There the ith , Thquire , ’[87-mr. sleary] [he]87-mr. sleary said , sweeping [her]578-her with a professional glance as if [she]578-her were being adjusted in [her]578-her seat , ‘ and the’ll do [you]578-her juthtithe . Good - bye , [Thethilia]117-thethilia ! ’[87-mr. sleary] ‘ Good - bye , [Cecilia]76-sissy ! ’[87-mr. sleary] ‘ Good - bye , [Sissy]76-sissy ! ’[87-mr. sleary] ‘ God bless [you]578-her , [dear]2972-dear ! ’[87-mr. sleary] In a variety of voices from all [the room]2859-the room . But [the riding - master eye]580-the riding - master eye had observed the bottle of the nine oils in [her]578-her bosom , and [he]87-mr. sleary now interposed with ‘ Leave the bottle , [[my]87-mr. sleary dear]3090-my dear ; ith large to carry ; it will be of no uthe to [you]578-her now . Give it to [me]87-mr. sleary ! ’[87-mr. sleary] ‘ No , no ! ’[578-her] [she]578-her said , in another burst of tears . ‘ Oh , no ! Pray let [me]578-her keep it for [father]2723-father till [he]2723-father comes back ! [He]2723-father will want it when [he]2723-father comes back . [He]2723-father had never thought of going away , when [he]2723-father sent [me]578-her for it . ( [You]578-her [thee]578-her how it ith , [Thquire]115-thquire ! ) Farewell , [Thethilia]117-thethilia ! [My]87-mr. sleary latht wordth to [you]578-her ith thith , Thtick to the termth of [your]578-her engagement , be obedient to [the Thquire]3100-the thquire , and forget uth . But if , when [you]581-you ’re[87-mr. sleary] grown up and married and well off , [you]581-you come upon any horthe - riding ever , do n’t be hard upon it , do n’t be croth with it , give it a Bethpeak if [you]581-you can , and think [you]581-you might do wurth . [People]300-people mutht be amuthed , Thquire , thomehow , ’ continued [Sleary]87-mr. sleary , rendered more pursy than ever , by so much talking ; ‘[300-people] [they]300-people ca n’t be alwayth a working , nor yet [they]300-people ca n’t be alwayth a learning . Make the betht of uth ; not the wurtht . [I]0-i ’ve got [my]0-i living out of the horthe - riding all [my]0-i life , [I]0-i know ; but [I]0-i conthider that [I]0-i lay down [the philothophy of the thubject]583-the philothophy of the thubject when [I]0-i thay to [you]581-you , Thquire , make the betht of uth : not the wurtht ! ’ The Sleary philosophy was propounded as [they]300-people went [downstairs]3101-downstairs and the fixed eye of Philosophy — and its rolling eye , too — soon lost the three figures and the basket in the darkness of [the street]448-the street . CHAPTER VII [MRS . SPARSIT MR . BOUNDERBY]92-mr. bounderby being [a bachelor]3103-a bachelor , [an elderly lady]3104-an elderly lady presided over [[his]3103-a bachelor establishment]3105-his establishment , in consideration of a certain annual stipend . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was [this lady]3106-this lady ’s name ; and [she]3104-an elderly lady was [a prominent figure in attendance on [[Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s car]3108-mr. bounderby ’s car]3107-a prominent figure in attendance on mr. bounderby ’s car , as [it]3108-mr. bounderby ’s car rolled along in triumph with the Bully of humility inside . For , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby had not only seen different days , but was highly connected . [She]3104-an elderly lady had [a great aunt]3109-a great aunt living in these very times called [Lady Scadgers]122-lady scadgers . [Mr. Sparsit]3110-mr. sparsit , deceased , of whom [she]3104-an elderly lady was [the relict]3111-the relict , had been by [the mother]3112-the mother ’s side what [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby still called ‘[584-a powler] [a Powler]584-a powler . ’ [Strangers of limited information and dull apprehension]3113-strangers of limited information and dull apprehension were sometimes observed not to know what [a Powler]584-a powler was , and even to appear uncertain whether it might be a business , or [a political party]3115-a political party , or a profession of faith . [The better class of minds]3116-the better class of minds , however , did not need to be informed that [the Powlers]3117-the powlers were an ancient stock , who could trace [themselves]3117-the powlers so exceedingly far back that it was not surprising if [they]3117-the powlers sometimes lost [themselves]3117-the powlers — which [they]3117-the powlers had rather frequently done , as [respected horse - flesh , blind - hookey , Hebrew monetary transactions]3118-respected horse - flesh , blind - hookey , hebrew monetary transactions , and [the Insolvent Debtors ’[584-a powler] Court]3119-the insolvent debtors ’ court . [The late Mr. Sparsit]585-the late mr. sparsit , being by [the mother]3112-the mother ’s side [a Powler]584-a powler , married [this lady]3106-this lady , being by [the father]426-the father ’s side [a Scadgers]590-a scadgers . [Lady Scadgers]122-lady scadgers ( [an immensely fat old woman , with an inordinate appetite for butcher ’s meat , and a mysterious leg which had now refused to get out of bed for fourteen years]591-an immensely fat old woman , with an inordinate appetite for butcher ’s meat , and a mysterious leg which had now refused to get out of bed for fourteen years ) contrived the marriage , at a period when [Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was just of age , and chiefly noticeable for a slender body , weakly supported on two long slim props , and surmounted by no head worth mentioning . [He]92-mr. bounderby inherited a fair fortune from [[his]92-mr. bounderby uncle]592-his uncle , but owed it all before [he]92-mr. bounderby came into it , and spent it twice over immediately afterwards . Thus , when [he]92-mr. bounderby died , at twenty - four ( the scene of [his]92-mr. bounderby decease , [Calais]123-calais , and the cause , brandy ) , [he]92-mr. bounderby did not leave [[his]92-mr. bounderby widow]593-his widow , from whom [he]92-mr. bounderby had been separated soon after the honeymoon , in affluent circumstances . [That bereaved lady]594-that bereaved lady , fifteen years older than [he]92-mr. bounderby , fell presently at deadly feud with [[her]594-that bereaved lady only relative]595-her only relative , [Lady Scadgers]122-lady scadgers ; and , partly to spite [her]594-that bereaved lady ladyship , and partly to maintain [herself]594-that bereaved lady , went out at a salary . And here [she]594-that bereaved lady was now , in [her]594-that bereaved lady elderly days , with the Coriolanian style of nose and the dense black eyebrows which had captivated [Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , making [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s tea as [he]92-mr. bounderby took [his]92-mr. bounderby breakfast . If [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby had been [a Conqueror]596-a conqueror , and [Mrs. Sparsit]597-mrs. sparsit [a captive Princess whom [he]92-mr. bounderby took about as a feature in [his]92-mr. bounderby state - processions]598-a captive princess whom he took about as a feature in his state - processions , [he]92-mr. bounderby could not have made a greater flourish with [her]597-mrs. sparsit than [he]92-mr. bounderby habitually did . Just as it belonged to [his]92-mr. bounderby boastfulness to depreciate [his]92-mr. bounderby own extraction , so it belonged to [it]599-it to exalt [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s . In the measure that [he]92-mr. bounderby would not allow [his]92-mr. bounderby own youth to have been attended by a single favourable circumstance , [he]92-mr. bounderby brightened [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s juvenile career with every possible advantage , and showered waggon - loads of early roses all over [that lady]600-that lady ’s path . ‘ And yet , [sir]2713-sir , ’[92-mr. bounderby] [he]92-mr. bounderby would say , ‘ how does it turn out after all ? Why here [she]600-that lady is at a hundred a year ( [I]92-mr. bounderby give [her]600-that lady a hundred , which [she]600-that lady is pleased to term handsome ) , keeping [the house of [Josiah Bounderby]96-josiah bounderby of [Coketown]4-coketown]3121-the house of josiah bounderby of coketown ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] Nay , [he]92-mr. bounderby made this foil of [his]92-mr. bounderby so very widely known , that [third parties]601-third parties took it up , and handled it on some occasions with considerable briskness . It was one of the most exasperating attributes of [Bounderby]96-josiah bounderby , that [he]96-josiah bounderby not only sang [his]96-josiah bounderby own praises but stimulated [other men]602-other men to sing them . There was a moral infection of clap - trap in [him]96-josiah bounderby . [Strangers]603-strangers , modest enough elsewhere , started up at dinners in [Coketown]4-coketown , and boasted , in quite a rampant way , of [Bounderby]96-josiah bounderby . [They]603-strangers made [him]96-josiah bounderby out to be [the Royal arms]604-the royal arms , [the Union - Jack]605-the union - jack , [Magna Charta]124-magna charta , [John Bull]125-john bull , [Habeas Corpus]15-habeas corpus , the Bill of Rights , [[An Englishman]606-an englishman ’s house]607-an englishman ’s house is [[his]606-an englishman castle]608-his castle , Church and State , and [God]126-god save [the Queen]609-the queen , all put together . And as often ( and it was very often ) as [an orator of this kind]610-an orator of this kind brought into [his]96-josiah bounderby peroration , ‘ [Princes]3122-princes and [lords]3123-lords may flourish or may fade , A breath can make [them]3124-them , as a breath has made , ’[610-an orator of this kind] — it was , for certain , more or less understood among [the company]570-the company that [he]96-josiah bounderby had heard of [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ [you]92-mr. bounderby are unusually slow , [sir]2713-sir , with [your]92-mr. bounderby breakfast this morning . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Why , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[96-josiah bounderby] [he]96-josiah bounderby returned , ‘ [I]96-josiah bounderby am thinking about [Tom Gradgrind]75-tom ’s whim ; ’[96-josiah bounderby] [Tom Gradgrind]75-tom , for a bluff independent manner of speaking — as if [somebody]612-somebody were always endeavouring to bribe [him]96-josiah bounderby with immense sums to say [Thomas]75-tom , and [he]96-josiah bounderby would n’t ; ‘ [Tom Gradgrind]75-tom ’s whim , [ma’am]350-ma’am , of bringing up [the tumbling - girl]3128-the tumbling - girl . ’[96-josiah bounderby] ‘ [The girl]265-the girl is now waiting to know , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ whether [she]265-the girl is to go straight to [the school]2778-the school , or up to [the Lodge]16-the lodge . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ [She]265-the girl must wait , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[92-mr. bounderby] answered [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ till [I]92-mr. bounderby know [myself]92-mr. bounderby . [We]3132-we shall have [Tom Gradgrind]75-tom down here presently , [I]92-mr. bounderby suppose . If [he]75-tom should wish [her]265-the girl to remain [here]354-here a day or two longer , of course [she]265-the girl can , [ma’am]350-ma’am . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Of course [she]265-the girl can if [you]92-mr. bounderby wish it , [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ’[96-josiah bounderby] ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby told [him]75-tom [I]92-mr. bounderby would give [her]265-the girl a shake - down here , last night , in order that [he]75-tom might sleep on it before [he]75-tom decided to let [her]265-the girl have any association with [Louisa]91-louisa . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Indeed , [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ? [He]75-tom ’d open [his]75-tom eyes , [that boy]3137-that boy would , if [he]75-tom knew how empty of learning _ [[my]92-mr. bounderby _ young maw]3138-my _ young maw was , at [his]75-tom time of life . ’[92-mr. bounderby] Which , by the by , [he]2713-sir probably did know , for [he]2713-sir had heard of it often enough . ‘ But it ’s extraordinary the difficulty [I]92-mr. bounderby have on scores of such subjects , in speaking to [any one]2994-any one on equal terms . Here , for example , [I]92-mr. bounderby have been speaking to [you]3140-you this morning about tumblers . Why , what do _ [you]3140-you _ know about tumblers ? [Mr.]625-mr. and [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind being then announced , [he]92-mr. bounderby received [the former]626-the former with a shake of the hand , and the latter with a kiss . ‘ Can [Jupe]76-sissy be sent [here]354-here , [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ? ’[75-tom] asked [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom . [They]3187-they were the happiest — O , of all the happy times [we]3188-we had together , [sir]2713-sir ! ’[75-tom] It was only now when [her]633-her sorrow broke out , that [Louisa]91-louisa looked at [her]91-louisa . ‘ And what , ’[75-tom] asked [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom , in a still lower voice , ‘ did [you]91-louisa read to [[your]91-louisa father]2725-your father , [Jupe]76-sissy ? ’[75-tom] ‘ About [the Fairies]3191-the fairies , [sir]2713-sir , and [the Dwarf]3193-the dwarf , and [the Hunchback]129-the hunchback , and [the Genies]130-the genies , ’[633-her] [she]633-her sobbed out ; ‘ and about — ’[633-her] ‘ Hush ! ’[75-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom , ‘ that is enough .
