Otherwise , [I]0-i know it is one of those subjects [I]0-i shall never hear the last of . ’ When [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom had presented [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , [Sissy]76-sissy had suddenly turned [her]76-sissy head , and looked , in wonder , in pity , in sorrow , in doubt , in a multitude of emotions , towards [Louisa]91-louisa . [Louisa]91-louisa had known it , and seen it , without looking at [her]76-sissy . From that moment [she]91-louisa was impassive , proud and cold — held [Sissy]76-sissy at a distance — changed to [her]91-louisa altogether . CHAPTER XVI HUSBAND AND WIFE [MR . BOUNDERBY]92-mr. bounderby ’S[0-i] first disquietude on hearing of [his]0-i happiness , was occasioned by the necessity of imparting it to [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . [He]0-i could not make up [his]0-i mind how to do that , or what the consequences of the step might be . Whether [she]1075-she would instantly depart , bag and baggage , to [Lady Scadgers]122-lady scadgers , or would positively refuse to budge from [the premises]3248-the premises ; whether [she]1075-she would be plaintive or abusive , tearful or tearing ; whether [she]1075-she would break [her]1075-she heart , or break the looking - glass ; [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby could not all foresee . However , as it must be done , [he]0-i had no choice but to do it ; so , after attempting several letters , and failing in them all , [he]0-i resolved to do it by word of mouth . On [his]0-i way [home]336-home , on the evening [he]0-i set aside for this momentous purpose , [he]0-i took the precaution of stepping into [a chemist ’s shop]1078-a chemist ’s shop and buying a bottle of the very strongest smelling - salts . ‘ By [George]71-george ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ if [she]1075-she takes it in the fainting way , [I]92-mr. bounderby ’ll have the skin off [her]1075-she nose , at all events ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] But , in spite of being thus forearmed , [he]0-i entered [[his]0-i own house]1079-his own house with anything but a courageous air ; and appeared before the object of [his]0-i misgivings , like a dog who was conscious of coming direct from [the pantry]1080-the pantry . ‘ Good evening , [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ! ’[0-i] ‘ Good evening , [ma’am]350-ma’am , good evening . ’[92-mr. bounderby] [He]92-mr. bounderby drew up [his]92-mr. bounderby chair , and [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby drew back [hers]92-mr. bounderby , as who should say , ‘ [Your]92-mr. bounderby fireside , [sir]2713-sir . [I]92-mr. bounderby freely admit it . It is for [you]2713-sir to occupy it all , if [you]2713-sir think proper . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Do n’t go to [the North Pole]27-the north pole , [ma’am]350-ma’am ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ Thank [you]92-mr. bounderby , [sir]2713-sir , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , and returned , though short of [her]1081-her former position . [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby sat looking at [her]1081-her , as , with the points of a stiff , sharp pair of scissors , [she]1081-her picked out holes for some inscrutable ornamental purpose , in a piece of cambric . An operation which , taken in connexion with the bushy eyebrows and the Roman nose , suggested with some liveliness the idea of a hawk engaged upon the eyes of a tough little bird . [She]1081-her was so steadfastly occupied , that many minutes elapsed before [she]1081-her looked up from [her]1081-her work ; when [she]1081-her did so [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby bespoke [her]1081-her attention with a hitch of [his]92-mr. bounderby head . ‘ [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , putting [his]92-mr. bounderby hands in [his]92-mr. bounderby pockets , and assuring [himself]92-mr. bounderby with [his]92-mr. bounderby right hand that the cork of the little bottle was ready for use , ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby have no occasion to say to [you]92-mr. bounderby , that [you]92-mr. bounderby are not only [a lady born and bred]3549-a lady born and bred , but [a devilish sensible woman]3550-a devilish sensible woman . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ [Sir]2713-sir , ’[730-the lady] returned [the lady]730-the lady , ‘ this is indeed not the first time that [you]2713-sir have honoured [me]730-the lady with similar expressions of [your]2713-sir good opinion . ’[730-the lady] ‘ [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby am going to astonish [you]92-mr. bounderby . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Yes , [sir]2713-sir ? ’[92-mr. bounderby] returned [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , interrogatively , and in the most tranquil manner possible . [She]730-the lady generally wore mittens , and [she]730-the lady now laid down [her]730-the lady work , and smoothed those mittens . ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby am going , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ to marry [[Tom Gradgrind]75-tom ’s daughter]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Yes , [sir]2713-sir , ’[92-mr. bounderby] returned [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ [I]730-the lady hope [you]2713-sir may be happy , [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . Oh , indeed [I]730-the lady hope [you]2713-sir may be happy , [sir]2713-sir ! ’[730-the lady] And [she]730-the lady said it with such great condescension as well as with such great compassion for [him]92-mr. bounderby , that [Bounderby,—far]150-bounderby,—far more disconcerted than if [she]730-the lady had thrown [her]730-the lady workbox at the mirror , or swooned on the hearthrug,—corked up the smelling - salts tight in [his]92-mr. bounderby pocket , and thought , ‘ Now confound [this woman]3336-this woman , who could have even guessed that [she]3336-this woman would take it in this way ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby wish with all [my]92-mr. bounderby heart , [sir]2713-sir , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , in a highly superior manner ; somehow [she]730-the lady seemed , in a moment , to have established a right to pity [him]92-mr. bounderby ever afterwards ; ‘ that [you]92-mr. bounderby may be in all respects very happy . ’[730-the lady] ‘ Well , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[92-mr. bounderby] returned [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , with some resentment in [his]92-mr. bounderby tone : which was clearly lowered , though in spite of [himself]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby am obliged to [you]350-ma’am . [I]92-mr. bounderby hope [I]92-mr. bounderby shall be . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ _ Do _ [you]2713-sir , [sir]2713-sir ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , with great affability . ‘ But naturally [you]2713-sir do ; of course [you]2713-sir do . ’[92-mr. bounderby] A very awkward pause on [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s part , succeeded . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby sedately resumed [her]730-the lady work and occasionally gave a small cough , which sounded like the cough of conscious strength and forbearance . ‘ Well , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[92-mr. bounderby] resumed [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ under these circumstances , [I]92-mr. bounderby imagine it would not be agreeable to a character like [yours]350-ma’am to remain [here]354-here , though [you]350-ma’am would be very welcome here . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Oh , dear no , [sir]2713-sir , [I]92-mr. bounderby could on no account think of that ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby shook [her]730-the lady head , still in [her]730-the lady highly superior manner , and a little changed the small cough — coughing now , as if the spirit of prophecy rose within [her]730-the lady , but had better be coughed down . ‘ However , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ there are apartments at [the Bank]3460-the bank , where [a born and bred lady]3567-a born and bred lady , as [keeper of [the place]329-the place]3568-keeper of the place , would be rather a catch than otherwise ; and if the same terms — ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ [I]730-the lady beg [your]2713-sir pardon , [sir]2713-sir . [You]2713-sir were so good as to promise that [you]2713-sir would always substitute the phrase , annual compliment . ’[730-the lady] ‘ Well , [ma’am]350-ma’am , annual compliment . If the same annual compliment would be acceptable [there]412-there , why , [I]730-the lady see nothing to part [us]3573-us , unless [you]2713-sir do . ’[730-the lady] ‘ [Sir]2713-sir , ’[92-mr. bounderby] returned [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ The proposal is like [yourself]2713-sir , and if the position [I]92-mr. bounderby shall assume at [the Bank]3460-the bank is one that [I]92-mr. bounderby could occupy without descending lower in the social scale — ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Why , of course it is , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ If it was not , [ma’am]350-ma’am , [you]350-ma’am do n’t suppose that [I]92-mr. bounderby should offer it to [a lady who has moved in the society [you]350-ma’am have moved in]3577-a lady who has moved in the society you have moved in . But _ [you]350-ma’am _ do . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , [you]92-mr. bounderby are very considerate . ’[730-the lady] ‘ [You]92-mr. bounderby ’ll have [[your]92-mr. bounderby own private apartments]3578-your own private apartments , and [you]92-mr. bounderby ’ll have [your]92-mr. bounderby coals and [your]92-mr. bounderby candles , and all the rest of [it]3578-your own private apartments , and [you]92-mr. bounderby ’ll have [[your]92-mr. bounderby maid]3579-your maid to attend upon [you]92-mr. bounderby , and [you]92-mr. bounderby ’ll have [your]92-mr. bounderby light porter to protect [you]92-mr. bounderby , and [you]92-mr. bounderby ’ll be what [I]92-mr. bounderby take the liberty of considering precious comfortable , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ [Sir]2713-sir , ’[92-mr. bounderby] rejoined [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ say no more . In yielding up [my]1083-she trust here , [I]1083-she shall not be freed from the necessity of eating the bread of dependence : ’[1083-she] [she]1083-she might have said the sweetbread , for that delicate article in a savoury brown sauce was [her]1083-she favourite supper : ‘ and [I]92-mr. bounderby would rather receive it from [your]2713-sir hand , than from any other . Therefore , [sir]2713-sir , [I]92-mr. bounderby accept [your]2713-sir offer gratefully , and with many sincere acknowledgments for past favours . And [I]92-mr. bounderby hope , [sir]2713-sir , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , concluding in an impressively compassionate manner , ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby fondly hope that [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind may be all [you]2713-sir desire , and deserve ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] Nothing moved [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby from that position any more . It was in vain for [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby to bluster or to assert [himself]92-mr. bounderby in any of [his]92-mr. bounderby explosive ways ; [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was resolved to have compassion on [him]92-mr. bounderby , as [a Victim]1084-a victim . [She]1083-she was polite , obliging , cheerful , hopeful ; but , the more polite , the more obliging , the more cheerful , the more hopeful , the more exemplary altogether , [she]1083-she ; [the forlorner Sacrifice]1085-the forlorner sacrifice and [Victim]151-victim , [he]92-mr. bounderby . [She]1083-she had that tenderness for [his]92-mr. bounderby melancholy fate , that [his]92-mr. bounderby great red countenance used to break out into cold perspirations when [she]1083-she looked at [him]92-mr. bounderby . Meanwhile the marriage was appointed to be solemnized in eight weeks ’ time , and [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby went every evening to [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge as [an accepted wooer]3583-an accepted wooer . Love was made on these occasions in the form of bracelets ; and , on all occasions during the period of betrothal , took a manufacturing aspect . Dresses were made , jewellery was made , cakes and gloves were made , settlements were made , and an extensive assortment of Facts did appropriate honour to the contract . The business was all Fact , from first to last . The Hours did not go through any of those rosy performances , which [foolish poets]3584-foolish poets have ascribed to [them]3584-foolish poets at such times ; neither did the clocks go any faster , or any slower , than at other seasons . The deadly statistical recorder in [the Gradgrind observatory]3585-the gradgrind observatory knocked every second on the head as it was born , and buried it with [his]92-mr. bounderby accustomed regularity . So the day came , as all other days come to [people who will only stick to reason]3586-people who will only stick to reason ; and when it came , there were married in [the church of the florid wooden legs]3587-the church of the florid wooden legs — that popular order of architecture — [Josiah Bounderby]96-josiah bounderby Esquire of [Coketown]4-coketown , to [Louisa eldest daughter of [Thomas Gradgrind Esquire]152-tom gradgrind of [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge , M.P. for [that borough]3589-that borough]3588-louisa eldest daughter of thomas gradgrind esquire of stone lodge , m.p. for that borough . And when [they]3590-they were united in holy matrimony , [they]3590-they went [home]336-home to breakfast at [Stone Lodge aforesaid]3-stone lodge . There was [an improving party assembled on the auspicious occasion]3592-an improving party assembled on the auspicious occasion , who knew what everything [they]3590-they [had to eat and drink was made of , and how it was imported or exported , and in what quantities , and in what bottoms , whether native or foreign , and all about it]3593-had to eat and drink was made of , and how it was imported or exported , and in what quantities , and in what bottoms , whether native or foreign , and all about it . [The bridesmaids]3594-the bridesmaids , down to [little Jane Gradgrind]99-jane , were , in an intellectual point of view , [fit helpmates for [the calculating boy]3596-the calculating boy]3595-fit helpmates for the calculating boy ; and there was no nonsense about any of [the company]570-the company . After breakfast , [the bridegroom]3501-the bridegroom addressed [them]3590-they in the following terms : ‘[3150-ladies] [Ladies]3150-ladies and [gentlemen]436-gentlemen , [I]0-i am [Josiah Bounderby of [Coketown]4-coketown]388-josiah bounderby of coketown . Since [you]1089-you have done [[my]0-i wife]1090-my wife and [myself]0-i the honour of drinking [our]1091-our healths and happiness , [I]0-i suppose [I]0-i must acknowledge the same ; though , as [you]1089-you all know [me]0-i , and know what [I]0-i am , and what [my]0-i extraction was , [you]1089-you wo n’t expect a speech from [a man who , when [he]1092-a man who , when he sees a post sees [a Post]1093-a post]1092-a man who , when he sees a post , says “ that ’s a Post , ” and when [he]1092-a man who , when he sees a post sees a Pump , says “ that ’s a Pump , ” and is not to be got to call a Post a Pump , or a Pump a Post , or either of [them]1094-them a Toothpick . If [you]1089-you want a speech this morning , [[my]0-i friend and father - in - law]1095-my friend and father - in - law , [Tom Gradgrind]152-tom gradgrind , is [a Member of Parliament]1096-a member of parliament , and [you]1089-you know where to get it . [I]0-i am not [[your]1089-you man]1097-your man . However , if [I]0-i feel a little independent when [I]0-i look around this table to - day , and reflect how little [I]0-i thought of marrying [[Tom Gradgrind]152-tom gradgrind ’s daughter]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter when [I]0-i was [a ragged street - boy]1099-a ragged street - boy , who never washed [his]1092-a man who , when he sees a post face unless it was at a pump , and that not oftener than once a fortnight , [I]0-i hope [I]0-i may be excused . So , [I]0-i hope [you]1089-you like [my]0-i feeling independent ; if [you]1089-you do n’t , [I]0-i ca n’t help it . [I]0-i _ do _ feel independent . Now [I]0-i have mentioned , and [you]1089-you have mentioned , that [I]0-i am this day married to [[Tom Gradgrind]152-tom gradgrind ’s daughter]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter . [I]0-i am very glad to be so . It has long been [my]0-i wish to be so . [I]0-i have watched [her]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter bringing - up , and [I]0-i believe [she]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter is worthy of [me]0-i . At the same time — not to deceive [you]1089-you — [I]0-i believe [I]0-i am worthy of [her]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter . So , [I]0-i thank [you]1089-you , on both [our]1101-our parts , for the good - will [you]1089-you have shown towards [us]1101-our ; and the best wish [I]0-i can give [the unmarried part of the present company]1102-the unmarried part of the present company , is this : [I]0-i hope [every bachelor]1103-every bachelor may find as good a wife as [I]0-i have found . And [I]0-i hope [every spinster]1104-every spinster may find as good a [husband]1105-husband as [[my]0-i wife]1090-my wife has found . ’ Shortly after which oration , as [they]1101-our were going on a nuptial trip to [Lyons]29-lyons , in order that [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby might take the opportunity of seeing how [the Hands]785-the hands got on in those parts , and whether [they]785-the hands , too , required to be fed with gold spoons ; [the happy pair]3600-the happy pair departed for [the railroad]3601-the railroad . [The bride]3602-the bride , in passing down - stairs , dressed for [her]3602-the bride journey , found [Tom]152-tom gradgrind waiting for [her]3602-the bride — flushed , either with [his]152-tom gradgrind feelings , or the vinous part of the breakfast . ‘[0-i] What [a game girl]1107-a game girl [you]1107-a game girl are , to be such [a first - rate sister]1108-a first - rate sister , [Loo]100-loo ! ’ whispered [Tom]152-tom gradgrind . [She]3602-the bride clung to [him]152-tom gradgrind as [she]3602-the bride should have clung to some far better nature that day , and was a little shaken in [her]3602-the bride reserved composure for the first time . ‘[100-loo] [Old Bounderby]153-old bounderby ’s quite ready , ’ said [Tom]152-tom gradgrind . ‘[100-loo] Time ’s up . Good - bye ! [I]0-i shall be on the look - out for [you]1107-a game girl , when [you]1107-a game girl come back . [I]0-i say , [[my]0-i dear]3090-my dear [Loo]100-loo ! AN’T it uncommonly jolly now ! ’ * * * * * [END OF THE FIRST BOOK BOOK THE SECOND _ REAPING _ CHAPTER]30-end of the first book book the second _ reaping _ chapter I EFFECTS IN [THE BANK]31-the bank A SUNNY midsummer day . There was such a thing sometimes , even in [Coketown]4-coketown . Seen from a distance in such weather , [Coketown]4-coketown lay shrouded in a haze of [its]4-coketown own , which appeared impervious to the sun ’s rays . [You]1107-a game girl only knew [the town]317-the town was there , because [you]1107-a game girl knew there could have been no such sulky blotch upon the prospect without [a town]3604-a town . A blur of soot and smoke , now confusedly tending this way , now that way , now aspiring to the vault of Heaven , now murkily creeping along [the earth]3171-the earth , as the wind rose and fell , or changed its quarter : a dense formless jumble , with sheets of cross light in it , that showed nothing but masses of darkness:—Coketown in the distance was suggestive of itself , though not a brick of it could be seen . The wonder was , it was there at all . It had been ruined so often , that it was amazing how it had borne so many shocks . Surely there never was such fragile china - ware as that of which [the millers of [Coketown]4-coketown]3606-the millers of coketown were made . Handle [them]3606-the millers of coketown never so lightly , and they fell to pieces with such ease that [you]1107-a game girl might suspect [them]3606-the millers of coketown of having been flawed before . [They]3606-the millers of coketown were ruined , when [they]3606-the millers of coketown were required to send [labouring children]3607-labouring children to [school]3608-school ; [they]3606-the millers of coketown were ruined when [inspectors]3609-inspectors were appointed to look into [[their]3606-the millers of coketown works]3610-their works ; [they]3606-the millers of coketown were ruined , when [such inspectors]3611-such inspectors considered it doubtful whether [they]3606-the millers of coketown were quite justified in chopping [people]300-people up with [their]3606-the millers of coketown machinery ; [they]3606-the millers of coketown were utterly undone , when it was hinted that perhaps [they]3606-the millers of coketown need not always make quite so much smoke . Besides [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s gold spoon which was generally received in [Coketown]4-coketown , another prevalent fiction was very popular [there]412-there . It took the form of a threat . Whenever [a Coketowner]3614-a coketowner felt [he]1110-he was ill - used — that is to say , whenever [he]1110-he was not left entirely alone , and it was proposed to hold [him]1110-he accountable for the consequences of any of [his]1110-he acts — [he]1110-he was sure to come out with the awful menace , that [he]1110-he would ‘[0-i] sooner pitch [[his]1110-he property]1111-his property into [the Atlantic]32-the atlantic . ’ This had terrified [the Home Secretary]3615-the home secretary within an inch of [his]3615-the home secretary life , on several occasions . However , [the Coketowners]154-the coketowners were so patriotic after all , that [they]154-the coketowners never had pitched [[their]154-the coketowners property]3616-their property into [the Atlantic]32-the atlantic yet , but , on the contrary , had been kind enough to take mighty good care of it . So there it was , in the haze yonder ; and it increased and multiplied . [The streets]2931-the streets were hot and dusty on the summer day , and the sun was so bright that it even shone through the heavy vapour drooping over [Coketown]4-coketown , and could not be looked at steadily . [Stokers]3618-stokers emerged from low underground doorways into [factory yards]3619-factory yards , and sat on steps , and posts , and palings , wiping [their]3618-stokers swarthy visages , and contemplating coals . [The whole town]3620-the whole town seemed to be frying in oil . There was a stifling smell of hot oil everywhere . The steam - engines shone with it , the dresses of [the Hands]785-the hands were soiled with it , [the mills]3400-the mills throughout [their]3400-the mills many stories oozed and trickled it . The atmosphere of [those Fairy palaces]3623-those fairy palaces was like the breath of the simoom : and [[their]3623-those fairy palaces inhabitants]3624-their inhabitants , wasting with heat , toiled languidly in [the desert]3625-the desert . But no temperature made the melancholy mad elephants more mad or more sane . [Their]154-the coketowners wearisome heads went up and down at the same rate , in hot weather and cold , wet weather and dry , fair weather and foul . The measured motion of [their]154-the coketowners shadows on the walls , was the substitute [Coketown]4-coketown had to show for the shadows of [rustling woods]3626-rustling woods ; while , for the summer hum of insects , it could offer , all the year round , from the dawn of Monday to the night of Saturday , the whirr of shafts and wheels . Drowsily [they]154-the coketowners whirred all through this sunny day , making [the passenger]3627-the passenger more sleepy and more hot as [he]3627-the passenger passed the humming walls of [the mills]3400-the mills . Sun - blinds , and sprinklings of water , a little cooled [the main streets]3629-the main streets and [the shops]379-the shops ; but [the mills]3400-the mills , and [the courts]3632-the courts and [alleys]3633-alleys , baked at a fierce heat . Down upon [the river]3634-the river that was black and thick with dye , [some [Coketown]4-coketown boys who were at large — a rare sight there]3635-some coketown boys who were at large — a rare sight there — rowed [a crazy boat]3636-a crazy boat , which made a spumous track upon [the water as]3637-the water as [it]3636-a crazy boat jogged along , while every dip of an oar stirred up vile smells . But the sun itself , however beneficent , generally , was less kind to [Coketown]4-coketown than hard frost , and rarely looked intently into any of [[its]4-coketown closer regions]3638-its closer regions without engendering more death than life . So does the eye of Heaven itself become an evil eye , when incapable or sordid hands are interposed between it and the things it looks upon to bless . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby sat in [[her]3639-her afternoon apartment]3640-her afternoon apartment at [the Bank]31-the bank , on [the shadier side of [the frying street]3642-the frying street]3641-the shadier side of the frying street . [Office]3643-office - hours were over : and at that period of the day , in warm weather , [she]3639-her usually embellished with [her]3639-her genteel presence , [a managerial board - room over [the public office]3645-the public office]3644-a managerial board - room over the public office . [[Her]3639-her own private sitting - room]3646-her own private sitting - room was a story higher , at the window of which post of observation [she]3639-her was ready , every morning , to greet [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , as [he]92-mr. bounderby came across [the road]326-the road , with the sympathizing recognition appropriate to [a Victim]1084-a victim . [He]92-mr. bounderby had been married now a year ; and [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby had never released [him]92-mr. bounderby from [her]3639-her determined pity a moment . [The Bank]3460-the bank offered no violence to the wholesome monotony of [the town]317-the town . [It]3460-the bank was [another red brick house , with black outside shutters]3651-another red brick house , with black outside shutters , green inside blinds , a black street - door up two white steps , a brazen door - plate , and a brazen door - handle full stop . [It]3460-the bank was a size larger than [[Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s house]3652-mr. bounderby ’s house , as [other houses]3653-other houses were from a size to half - a - dozen sizes smaller ; in all other particulars , [it]3460-the bank was strictly according to pattern . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was conscious that by coming in the evening - tide among the desks and writing implements , [she]3639-her shed a feminine , not to say also aristocratic , grace upon [the office]3654-the office . Seated , with [her]3639-her needlework or netting apparatus , at the window , [she]3639-her had a self - laudatory sense of correcting , by [her]3639-her ladylike deportment , the rude business aspect of [the place]329-the place . With this impression of [her]3639-her interesting character upon [her]3639-her , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby considered [herself]3639-her , in some sort , [the Bank Fairy]3656-the bank fairy . [The townspeople who , in [their]3657-the townspeople who , in their passing and repassing , saw her there passing and repassing , saw [her]3639-her [there]412-there]3657-the townspeople who , in their passing and repassing , saw her there , regarded [her]3639-her as [the Bank Dragon]155-the bank dragon keeping watch over the treasures of [the mine]3659-the mine . What those treasures were , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby knew as little as [they]3657-the townspeople who , in their passing and repassing , saw her there did . Gold and silver coin , precious paper , secrets that if divulged would bring vague destruction upon [vague persons]3660-vague persons ( generally , however , people whom [she]3639-her disliked ) , were the chief items in [her]3639-her ideal catalogue thereof . For the rest , [she]3639-her knew that after office - hours , [she]3639-her reigned supreme over all the office furniture , and over [a locked - up iron room with three locks]3661-a locked - up iron room with three locks , against the door of which strong chamber [the light porter]3662-the light porter laid [his]3662-the light porter head every night , on a truckle bed , that disappeared at cockcrow . Further , [she]3639-her was lady paramount over [certain vaults in [the basement]3664-the basement]3663-certain vaults in the basement , sharply spiked off from communication with [the predatory world]3665-the predatory world ; and over the relics of the current day ’s work , consisting of blots of ink , worn - out pens , fragments of wafers , and scraps of paper torn so small , that nothing interesting could ever be deciphered on them when [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby tried . Lastly , [she]3639-her was guardian over a little armoury of cutlasses and carbines , arrayed in vengeful order above one of the official chimney - pieces ; and over that respectable tradition never to be separated from a place of business claiming to be wealthy — a row of fire - buckets — vessels calculated to be of no physical utility on any occasion , but observed to exercise a fine moral influence , almost equal to bullion , on [most beholders]3666-most beholders . [A deaf serving - woman]3667-a deaf serving - woman and [the light porter]3662-the light porter completed [[Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s empire]3669-mrs. sparsit ’s empire . [The deaf serving - woman]3670-the deaf serving - woman was rumoured to be wealthy ; and a saying had for years gone about among [the lower orders of [Coketown]4-coketown]3671-the lower orders of coketown , that [she]3670-the deaf serving - woman would be murdered some night when [the Bank]3460-the bank was shut , for the sake of [her]3670-the deaf serving - woman money . It was generally considered , indeed , that [she]3639-her had been due some time , and ought to have fallen long ago ; but [she]3639-her had kept [her]3639-her life , and [her]3639-her situation , with an ill - conditioned tenacity that occasioned much offence and disappointment . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s tea was just set for [her]3639-her on a pert little table , with its tripod of legs in an attitude , which [she]3639-her insinuated after office - hours , into the company of the stern , leathern - topped , long board - table that bestrode the middle of [the room]2859-the room . [The light porter]3662-the light porter placed the tea - tray on it , knuckling [his]3662-the light porter forehead as a form of homage . ‘[0-i] Thank [you]1112-her , [Bitzer]77-bitzer , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[77-bitzer] Thank _ [you]1112-her _ , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’ returned [the light porter]3662-the light porter . [He]3662-the light porter was [a very light porter]3676-a very light porter indeed ; as light as in the days when [he]3662-the light porter blinkingly defined a horse , for girl number twenty . ‘[1112-her] All is shut up , [Bitzer]77-bitzer ? ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[77-bitzer] All is shut up , [ma’am]350-ma’am . ’ ‘[350-ma’am] And what , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , pouring out [her]1112-her tea , ‘[350-ma’am] is the news of the day ? Anything ? ’ ‘[350-ma’am] Well , [ma’am]350-ma’am , [I]0-i ca n’t say that [I]0-i have heard anything particular . [[Our]1116-our people]2977-our people are [a bad lot]1118-a bad lot , [ma’am]350-ma’am ; but that is no news , unfortunately . ’ ‘[350-ma’am] What are [the restless wretches]1120-the restless wretches doing now ? ’ asked [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[1120-the restless wretches] Merely going on in the old way , [ma’am]350-ma’am . [Uniting]156-uniting , and leaguing , and engaging to stand by [one another]2898-one another . ’ ‘[156-uniting] It is much to be regretted , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , making [her]1112-her nose more [Roman]157-roman and [her]1112-her eyebrows more Coriolanian in the strength of [her]1112-her severity , ‘[156-uniting] that [the united masters]1123-the united masters allow of any such class - combinations . ’ ‘[1123-the united masters] Yes , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’ said [Bitzer]77-bitzer . ‘[1123-the united masters] Being united [themselves]1123-the united masters , [they]1123-the united masters ought one and all to set [their]1123-the united masters faces against employing [any man who is united with [any other man]1126-any other man]1125-any man who is united with any other man , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[1123-the united masters] [They]1123-the united masters have done that , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’ returned [Bitzer]77-bitzer ; ‘[1123-the united masters] but it rather fell through , [ma’am]350-ma’am . ’ ‘[350-ma’am] [I]0-i do not pretend to understand these things , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , with dignity , ‘[350-ma’am] [my]0-i lot having been signally cast in a widely different sphere ; and [Mr. Sparsit]1129-mr. sparsit , as [a Powler]584-a powler , being also quite out of the pale of any such dissensions . [I]0-i only know that [these people]3064-these people must be conquered , and that it ’s high time it was done , once for all . ’ ‘[350-ma’am] Yes , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’ returned [Bitzer]77-bitzer , with a demonstration of great respect for [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s oracular authority . ‘[350-ma’am] [You]350-ma’am could n’t put it clearer , [I]0-i am sure , [ma’am]350-ma’am . ’ As this was [his]77-bitzer usual hour for having a little confidential chat with [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , and as [he]77-bitzer had already caught [her]1134-my lady eye and seen that [she]1134-my lady was going to ask [him]77-bitzer something , [he]77-bitzer made a pretence of arranging the rulers , inkstands , and so forth , while [that lady]600-that lady went on with [her]600-that lady tea , glancing through the open window , down into [the street]448-the street . ‘[0-i] Has it been a busy day , [Bitzer]77-bitzer ? ’ asked [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[77-bitzer] Not a very busy day , [[my]0-i lady]1134-my lady . About an average day . ’ [He]77-bitzer now and then slided into [[my]1135-the clerks lady]1134-my lady , instead of [ma’am]158-ma’am , as an involuntary acknowledgment of [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s personal dignity and claims to reverence . ‘[1135-the clerks] [The clerks]1135-the clerks , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , carefully brushing an imperceptible crumb of bread and butter from [her]1134-my lady left - hand mitten , ‘[1135-the clerks] are trustworthy , punctual , and industrious , of course ? ’ ‘[350-ma’am] Yes , [ma’am]350-ma’am , pretty fair , [ma’am]350-ma’am . With the usual exception . ’ [He]77-bitzer held the respectable office of [general spy]3680-general spy and informer in the establishment , for which volunteer service [he]77-bitzer received a present at Christmas , over and above [his]77-bitzer weekly wage . [He]77-bitzer had grown into [an extremely clear - headed , cautious , prudent young man , who was safe to rise in [the world]2766-the world]3681-an extremely clear - headed , cautious , prudent young man , who was safe to rise in the world . [His]77-bitzer mind was so exactly regulated , that [he]77-bitzer had no affections or passions . All [his]77-bitzer proceedings were the result of the nicest and coldest calculation ; and it was not without cause that [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby habitually observed of [him]77-bitzer , that [he]77-bitzer was [a young man of the steadiest principle]3683-a young man of the steadiest principle [she]1134-my lady had ever known . Having satisfied [himself]77-bitzer , on [[his]77-bitzer father]494-his father ’s death , that [[his]77-bitzer mother]2851-his mother had a right of settlement in [Coketown]4-coketown , [this excellent young economist]3686-this excellent young economist had asserted that right for [her]2851-his mother with such a steadfast adherence to the principle of the case , that [she]2851-his mother had been shut up in [the workhouse]3687-the workhouse ever since . It must be admitted that [he]77-bitzer allowed [her]2851-his mother half a pound of tea a year , which was weak in [him]77-bitzer : first , because all gifts have an inevitable tendency to pauperise [the recipient]3688-the recipient , and secondly , because [his]77-bitzer only reasonable transaction in that commodity would have been to buy it for as little as [he]77-bitzer could possibly give , and sell it for as much as [he]77-bitzer could possibly get ; it having been clearly ascertained by [philosophers]3689-philosophers that in this is comprised the whole duty of [man]2923-man — not a part of [man]2923-man ’s duty , but the whole . ‘[350-ma’am] Pretty fair , [ma’am]350-ma’am . With the usual exception , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’ repeated [Bitzer]77-bitzer . ‘[350-ma’am] Ah — h ! ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , shaking [her]350-ma’am head over [her]350-ma’am tea - cup , and taking a long gulp . ‘[75-tom] [Mr. Thomas]75-tom , [ma’am]350-ma’am , [I]0-i doubt [Mr. Thomas]75-tom very much , [ma’am]350-ma’am , [I]0-i do n’t like [his]75-tom ways at all . ’ ‘[77-bitzer] [Bitzer]77-bitzer , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , in a very impressive manner , ‘[77-bitzer] do [you]77-bitzer recollect [my]0-i having said anything to [you]77-bitzer respecting names ? ’ ‘[77-bitzer] [I]0-i beg [your]77-bitzer pardon , [ma’am]350-ma’am . It ’s quite true that [you]77-bitzer did object to names being used , and they ’re always best avoided . ’[350-ma’am] ‘ Please to remember that [I]350-ma’am have a charge here , ’[350-ma’am] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , with [her]350-ma’am air of state . ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby hold a trust here , [Bitzer]77-bitzer , under [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . However improbable both [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby and [myself]92-mr. bounderby might have deemed it years ago , that [he]92-mr. bounderby would ever become [[my]92-mr. bounderby patron]3692-my patron , making [me]92-mr. bounderby an annual compliment , [I]92-mr. bounderby can not but regard [him]92-mr. bounderby in that light . From [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby [I]92-mr. bounderby have received every acknowledgment of [my]92-mr. bounderby social station , and every recognition of [[my]92-mr. bounderby family]2868-my family descent , that [I]92-mr. bounderby could possibly expect . More , far more . Therefore , to [[my]92-mr. bounderby patron]3692-my patron [I]92-mr. bounderby will be scrupulously true . And [I]92-mr. bounderby do not consider , [I]92-mr. bounderby will not consider , [I]92-mr. bounderby can not consider , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , with a most extensive stock on hand of honour and morality , ‘ that [I]92-mr. bounderby _ should _ be scrupulously true , if [I]92-mr. bounderby allowed names to be mentioned under this roof , that are unfortunately — most unfortunately — no doubt of that — connected with [his]92-mr. bounderby . ’[92-mr. bounderby] [Bitzer]77-bitzer knuckled [his]77-bitzer forehead again , and again begged pardon . ‘ No , [Bitzer]77-bitzer , ’[92-mr. bounderby] continued [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ say [an individual]3695-an individual , and [I]92-mr. bounderby will hear [you]77-bitzer ; say [Mr. Thomas]75-tom , and [you]77-bitzer must excuse [me]92-mr. bounderby . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ With the usual exception , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[77-bitzer] said [Bitzer]77-bitzer , trying back , ‘ of [an individual]3695-an individual . ’[77-bitzer] ‘ Ah — h ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby repeated the ejaculation , the shake of the head over [her]1143-her tea - cup , and the long gulp , as taking up the conversation again at the point where it had been interrupted . ‘ [An individual]3695-an individual , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[77-bitzer] said [Bitzer]77-bitzer , ‘ has never been what [he]3695-an individual ought to have been , since [he]3695-an individual first came into [the place]329-the place . What [one person]1147-one person can do , another can do . ’ This , again , was among the fictions of [Coketown]4-coketown . [Any capitalist there , who had made sixty thousand pounds out of sixpence]3725-any capitalist there , who had made sixty thousand pounds out of sixpence , always professed to wonder why the sixty thousand nearest Hands did n’t each make sixty thousand pounds out of sixpence , and more or less reproached [them]1145-they every one for not accomplishing the little feat . Good day ! ’[1163-the stranger] [He]1163-the stranger bowed [himself]1163-the stranger out ; and [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , hiding in the window curtain , saw [him]1163-the stranger languishing down [the street]448-the street on the shady side of the way , observed of all [the town]317-the town . ‘ What do [you]3662-the light porter think of [the gentleman]284-the gentleman , [Bitzer]77-bitzer ? ’[1182-she] [she]1182-she asked [the light porter]3662-the light porter , when [he]3662-the light porter came to take away . ‘ Spends a deal of money on [his]284-the gentleman dress , [ma’am]350-ma’am . ’[1182-she] ‘ It must be admitted , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ that it ’s very tasteful . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Yes , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[77-bitzer] returned [Bitzer]77-bitzer , ‘ if that ’s worth the money . ’[77-bitzer] ‘ Besides which , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[77-bitzer] resumed [Bitzer]77-bitzer , while [he]77-bitzer was polishing the table , ‘ [he]284-the gentleman looks to [me]77-bitzer as if [he]284-the gentleman gamed . ’[77-bitzer] ‘ It ’s immoral to game , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ It ’s ridiculous , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[77-bitzer] said [Bitzer]77-bitzer , ‘ because the chances are against [the players]3808-the players . ’[77-bitzer] Whether it was that the heat prevented [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby from working , or whether it was that [her]1182-she hand was out , [she]1182-she did no work that night . [She]1182-she sat at the window , when the sun began to sink behind the smoke ; [she]1182-she sat there , when the smoke was burning red , when the colour faded from it , when darkness seemed to rise slowly out of the ground , and creep upward , upward , up to the [house]1184-house - tops , up [the church steeple]1185-the church steeple , up to the summits of [the factory chimneys]1186-the factory chimneys , up to the sky . Without a candle in [the room]2859-the room , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby sat at the window , with [her]1182-she hands before [her]1182-she , not thinking much of the sounds of evening ; the whooping of [boys]2716-boys , the barking of dogs , the rumbling of wheels , the steps and voices of [passengers]1189-passengers , the shrill street cries , the clogs upon the pavement when it was [their]1190-their hour for going by , the shutting - up of [shop]1191-shop - shutters . Not until [the light porter]3662-the light porter announced that [her]1182-she nocturnal sweetbread was ready , did [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby arouse [herself]92-mr. bounderby from [her]1182-she reverie , and convey [her]1182-she dense black eyebrows — by that time creased with meditation , as if [they]1193-they needed ironing out - up - [stairs]761-stairs . ‘ O , [[you]3809-you Fool]3810-you fool ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , when [she]1182-she was alone at [her]1182-she supper . Whom [she]1182-she meant , [she]1182-she did not say ; but [she]1182-she could scarcely have meant the sweetbread . CHAPTER II [MR . JAMES HARTHOUSE]162-mr. harthouse [THE Gradgrind party]1195-the gradgrind party wanted assistance in cutting the throats of [the Graces]163-the graces . [They]1195-the gradgrind party went about recruiting ; and where could [they]1195-the gradgrind party enlist [recruits]1196-recruits more hopefully , than among [the fine gentlemen who , having found out everything to be worth nothing]1197-the fine gentlemen who , having found out everything to be worth nothing , were equally ready for anything ? Moreover , [the healthy spirits who had mounted to this sublime height]1198-the healthy spirits who had mounted to this sublime height were attractive to [many of [the Gradgrind school]1200-the gradgrind school]1199-many of the gradgrind school . [They]1199-many of the gradgrind school liked [fine gentlemen]1201-fine gentlemen ; [they]1199-many of the gradgrind school pretended that [they]1199-many of the gradgrind school did not , but [they]1199-many of the gradgrind school did . [They]1199-many of the gradgrind school became exhausted in imitation of [them]1201-fine gentlemen ; and [they]1199-many of the gradgrind school yaw - yawed in [their]1199-many of the gradgrind school speech like [them]1201-fine gentlemen ; and [they]1199-many of the gradgrind school served out , with an enervated air , the little mouldy rations of political economy , on which [they]1199-many of the gradgrind school regaled [[their]1199-many of the gradgrind school disciples]1202-their disciples . There never before was seen on [earth]279-earth [such a wonderful hybrid race as was thus produced]1204-such a wonderful hybrid race as was thus produced . Among [the fine gentlemen not regularly belonging to [the Gradgrind school]1200-the gradgrind school]1205-the fine gentlemen not regularly belonging to the gradgrind school , there was [one of a good family]1207-one of a good family and a better appearance , with a happy turn of humour which had told immensely with [the House of Commons]2940-the house of commons on the occasion of [his]1209-his entertaining [it]2940-the house of commons with [his]1209-his ( and [the Board of Directors]1210-the board of directors ) view of a railway accident , in which [the most careful officers ever known]1211-the most careful officers ever known , employed by [the most liberal managers ever heard of , assisted by the finest mechanical contrivances ever devised , the whole in action on the best line ever constructed]1212-the most liberal managers ever heard of , assisted by the finest mechanical contrivances ever devised , the whole in action on the best line ever constructed , had killed [five people and wounded thirty - two]1213-five people and wounded thirty - two , by a casualty without which the excellence of the whole system would have been positively incomplete . Among [the slain]1214-the slain was a cow , and among the scattered articles unowned , [a widow]3765-a widow ’s cap . And [the honourable member]1216-the honourable member had so tickled [the House]2875-the house ( which has a delicate sense of humour ) by putting the cap on the cow , that it became impatient of any serious reference to [the Coroner]1218-the coroner ’s Inquest , and brought [the railway]3760-the railway off with Cheers and Laughter . Now , [this gentleman]280-this gentleman had [a younger brother of still better appearance than [himself]1209-his , who had tried life as [a Cornet of Dragoons]1222-a cornet of dragoons , and found it a bore ; and had afterwards tried it in the train of [an English minister abroad]1223-an english minister abroad]1221-a younger brother of still better appearance than himself , who had tried life as a cornet of dragoons , and found it a bore ; and had afterwards tried it in the train of an english minister abroad , and found it a bore ; and had then strolled to [Jerusalem]33-jerusalem , and got bored [there]412-there ; and had then gone yachting about [the world]2766-the world , and got bored everywhere . To whom [this honourable and jocular , member fraternally]1226-this honourable and jocular , member fraternally said one day , ‘ [Jem]162-mr. harthouse , there ’s a good opening among [the hard Fact fellows]3811-the hard fact fellows , and [they]3811-the hard fact fellows want [men]3039-men . So , [he]162-mr. harthouse went in . [He]162-mr. harthouse coached [himself]162-mr. harthouse up with a blue - book or two ; and [[his]162-mr. harthouse brother]1227-his brother put it about among [the hard Fact fellows]3811-the hard fact fellows , and said , ‘ If [you]162-mr. harthouse want to bring in , for any place , [a handsome dog who can make [you]162-mr. harthouse [a devilish good speech]3814-a devilish good speech , look after [[my]1227-his brother brother]3815-my brother [Jem]162-mr. harthouse , for [he]3815-my brother ’s [[your]162-mr. harthouse man]1097-your man]3813-a handsome dog who can make you a devilish good speech , look after my brother jem , for he ’s your man . ’[1227-his brother] After a few dashes in the public meeting way , [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom and [a council of [political sages]1230-political sages]1229-a council of political sages approved of [Jem]162-mr. harthouse , and it was resolved to send [him]162-mr. harthouse down to [Coketown]4-coketown , to become known there and in [the neighbourhood]3292-the neighbourhood . [Her]3841-the most remarkable girl mr. james harthouse had ever seen features were handsome ; but their natural play was so locked up , that it seemed impossible to guess at [their]3837-they genuine expression . From [the mistress of [the house]2875-the house]3844-the mistress of the house , [the visitor]1151-the visitor glanced to [the house itself]3847-the house itself . [I]91-louisa assure [you]92-mr. bounderby [I]91-louisa attach not the least importance to any opinions . The result of the varieties of boredom [I]91-louisa have undergone , is a conviction ( unless conviction is too industrious a word for the lazy sentiment [I]91-louisa entertain on the subject ) , that any set of ideas will do just as much good as any other set , and just as much harm as any other set . There ’s [an English family with a charming Italian motto]3864-an english family with a charming italian motto . What will be , will be . It ’s the only truth going ! ’[91-louisa] This vicious assumption of honesty in dishonesty — a vice so dangerous , so deadly , and so common — seemed , [he]1259-i observed , a little to impress [her]91-louisa in [his]1259-i favour . [He]1259-i followed up the advantage , by saying in [his]1259-i pleasantest manner : a manner to which [she]91-louisa might attach as much or as little meaning as [she]91-louisa pleased : ‘ The side that can prove anything in a line of units , tens , hundreds , and thousands , [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , seems to [me]1259-i to afford the most fun , and to give [a man]3830-a man the best chance . [I]1259-i am quite as much attached to it as if [I]1259-i believed it . [I]1259-i am quite ready to go in for it , to the same extent as if [I]1259-i believed it . And what more could [I]1259-i possibly do , if [I]1259-i did believe it ! ’[1259-i] ‘ [You]1259-i are [a singular politician]3866-a singular politician , ’[91-louisa] said [Louisa]91-louisa . ‘ Pardon [me]91-louisa ; [I]91-louisa have not even that merit . [We]3867-we are [the largest party in [the state]3869-the state]3868-the largest party in the state , [I]91-louisa assure [you]1259-i , [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , if [we]3867-we all fell out of [our]3867-we adopted ranks and were reviewed together . ’[91-louisa] [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby [, who had been in danger of bursting in silence]1260-, who had been in danger of bursting in silence , interposed here with a project for postponing the family dinner till half - past six , and taking [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse in the meantime on a round of visits to [the voting and interesting notabilities of [Coketown]4-coketown and [its]4-coketown vicinity]1261-the voting and interesting notabilities of coketown and its vicinity . The round of visits was made ; and [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , with a discreet use of [his]162-mr. harthouse blue coaching , came off triumphantly , though with a considerable accession of boredom . In the evening , [he]162-mr. harthouse found the dinner - table laid for four , but [they]1262-they sat down only three . It was an appropriate occasion for [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby to discuss the flavour of the hap’orth of stewed eels [he]92-mr. bounderby had purchased in [the streets]2931-the streets at eight years old ; and also of the inferior water , specially used for laying the dust , with which [he]92-mr. bounderby had washed down that repast . [He]92-mr. bounderby likewise entertained [[his]92-mr. bounderby guest]1264-his guest over the soup and fish , with the calculation that [he]92-mr. bounderby ( [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ) had eaten in [his]92-mr. bounderby youth at least three horses under the guise of [polonies and saveloys]1265-polonies and saveloys . These recitals , [Jem]162-mr. harthouse , in a languid manner , received with ‘ charming ! ’[1262-they] every now and then ; and [they]1262-they probably would have decided [him]162-mr. harthouse to ‘ go in ’[1262-they] for [Jerusalem]33-jerusalem again to - morrow morning , had [he]162-mr. harthouse been less curious respecting [Louisa]91-louisa . ‘ Is there nothing , ’[92-mr. bounderby] [he]92-mr. bounderby thought , glancing at [her]91-louisa as [she]91-louisa sat at the head of the table , where [her]91-louisa youthful figure , small and slight , but very graceful , looked as pretty as it looked misplaced ; ‘ is there nothing that will move that face ? ’[91-louisa] Yes ! By [Jupiter]164-jupiter , there was something , and here it was , in an unexpected shape . [Tom]75-tom appeared . [She]91-louisa changed as the door opened , and broke into a beaming smile . A beautiful smile . [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse might not have thought so much of it , but that [he]162-mr. harthouse had wondered so long at [her]91-louisa impassive face . [She]91-louisa put out [her]91-louisa hand — a pretty little soft hand ; and [her]91-louisa fingers closed upon [[her]91-louisa brother]2889-her brother ’s , as if [she]91-louisa would have carried them to [her]91-louisa lips . ‘ Ay , ay ? ’[1151-the visitor] thought [the visitor]1151-the visitor . ‘ [This whelp]3870-this whelp is the only creature [she]91-louisa cares for . So , so ! ’[1151-the visitor] [The whelp]1268-the whelp was presented , and took [his]1268-the whelp chair . The appellation was not flattering , but not unmerited . ‘ When [I]92-mr. bounderby was [your]75-tom age , [young Tom]75-tom , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby was punctual , or [I]92-mr. bounderby got no dinner ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ When [you]75-tom were [my]75-tom age , ’[75-tom] resumed [Tom]75-tom , ‘ [you]75-tom had n’t a wrong balance to get right , and had n’t to dress afterwards . ’[75-tom] ‘ Never mind that now , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ Well , then , ’[75-tom] grumbled [Tom]75-tom . ‘ Do n’t begin with [me]75-tom . ’[75-tom] ‘ [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ’[162-mr. harthouse] said [Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , perfectly hearing this under - strain as it went on ; ‘ [[your]92-mr. bounderby brother]3871-your brother ’s face is quite familiar to [me]162-mr. harthouse . Can [I]162-mr. harthouse have seen [him]3871-your brother abroad ? Or at [some public school]3872-some public school , perhaps ? ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ No , ’[1269-her] [she]1269-her resumed , quite interested , ‘ [he]3871-your brother has never been abroad yet , and was educated [here]354-here , at [home]336-home . [Tom]75-tom , love , [I]1269-her am telling [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse that [he]3871-your brother never saw [you]75-tom abroad . ’[1269-her] ‘ No such luck , [sir]2713-sir , ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom . There was little enough in [him]75-tom to brighten [her]1269-her face , for [he]75-tom was [a sullen young fellow]1270-a sullen young fellow , and ungracious in [his]75-tom manner even to [her]1269-her . So much the greater must have been the solitude of [her]1269-her heart , and [her]1269-her need of [some one on whom to bestow it]1271-some one on whom to bestow it . ‘ So much the more is [this whelp the only creature [she]1269-her has ever cared for]3876-this whelp the only creature she has ever cared for , ’[162-mr. harthouse] thought [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , turning it over and over . ‘ So much the more . So much the more . ’[162-mr. harthouse] Both in [[his]162-mr. harthouse sister]644-his sister ’s presence , and after [she]1269-her had left [the room]2859-the room , [the whelp]1268-the whelp took no pains to hide [his]1268-the whelp contempt for [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , whenever [he]1268-the whelp could indulge it without the observation of [that independent man]1275-that independent man , by making wry faces , or shutting one eye . Without responding to these telegraphic communications , [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse encouraged [him]75-tom much in the course of the evening , and showed an unusual liking for [him]75-tom . At last , when [he]75-tom rose to return to [[his]75-tom hotel]1276-his hotel , and was a little doubtful whether [he]75-tom knew the way by night , [the whelp]1268-the whelp immediately proffered [his]75-tom services as [guide]1278-guide , and turned out with [him]75-tom to escort [him]75-tom thither . [ Picture : [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse dines at [the Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s ] CHAPTER III [THE WHELP]1268-the whelp IT was very remarkable that [a young gentleman who had been brought up under one continuous system of unnatural restraint]1280-a young gentleman who had been brought up under one continuous system of unnatural restraint , should be [a hypocrite]1281-a hypocrite ; but it was certainly the case with [Tom]75-tom . It was very strange that [a young gentleman who had never been left to [his]1282-a young gentleman who had never been left to his own guidance for five consecutive minutes , should be incapable at last of governing himself own guidance for five consecutive minutes , should be incapable at last of governing [himself]1282-a young gentleman who had never been left to his own guidance for five consecutive minutes , should be incapable at last of governing himself]1282-a young gentleman who had never been left to his own guidance for five consecutive minutes , should be incapable at last of governing himself ; but so it was with [Tom]75-tom . It was altogether unaccountable that [a young gentleman whose imagination had been strangled]1283-a young gentleman whose imagination had been strangled in [his]1282-a young gentleman who had never been left to his own guidance for five consecutive minutes , should be incapable at last of governing himself cradle , should be still inconvenienced by its ghost in the form of grovelling sensualities ; but [such a monster]1284-such a monster , beyond all doubt , was [Tom]75-tom . ‘ Do [you]75-tom smoke ? ’[162-mr. harthouse] asked [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , when [they]1285-they came to [the hotel]3776-the hotel . ‘ [I]75-tom believe [you]162-mr. harthouse ! ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom . [He]75-tom could do no less than ask [Tom]75-tom up ; and [Tom]75-tom could do no less than go up . What with a cooling drink adapted to the weather , but not so weak as cool ; and what with a rarer tobacco than was to be bought in those parts ; [Tom]75-tom was soon in a highly free and easy state at [his]75-tom end of the sofa , and more than ever disposed to admire [[his]75-tom new friend]1287-his new friend at the other end . [Tom]75-tom blew [his]75-tom smoke aside , after [he]75-tom had been smoking a little while , and took an observation of [[his]75-tom friend]2878-his friend . ‘ [He]2878-his friend do n’t seem to care about [his]2878-his friend dress , ’[75-tom] thought [Tom]75-tom , ‘ and yet how capitally [he]2878-his friend does it . What [an easy swell]3877-an easy swell [he]2878-his friend is ! ’[75-tom] [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , happening to catch [Tom]75-tom ’s eye , remarked that [he]162-mr. harthouse drank nothing , and filled [his]162-mr. harthouse glass with [his]162-mr. harthouse own negligent hand . ‘ [Thank’ee]165-thank’ee , ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom . ‘ [Thank’ee]165-thank’ee . Well , [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , [I]75-tom hope [you]162-mr. harthouse have had about a dose of [old Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby to - night . ’[75-tom] [Tom]75-tom said this with one eye shut up again , and looking over [his]75-tom glass knowingly , at [[his]162-mr. harthouse entertainer]1289-his entertainer . ‘ [A very good fellow]3878-a very good fellow indeed ! ’[75-tom] returned [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse . ‘ [You]162-mr. harthouse think so , do n’t [you]162-mr. harthouse ? ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom . And shut up [his]75-tom eye again . [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse smiled ; and rising from [his]162-mr. harthouse end of the sofa , and lounging with [his]162-mr. harthouse back against the chimney - piece , so that [he]162-mr. harthouse stood before the empty fire - grate as [he]162-mr. harthouse smoked , in front of [Tom]75-tom and looking down at [him]75-tom , observed : ‘ What [a comical brother - in - law]3879-a comical brother - in - law [you]75-tom are ! ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ What [a comical brother - in - law old Bounderby]3880-a comical brother - in - law old bounderby is , [I]75-tom think [you]162-mr. harthouse mean , ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom . ‘ [You]75-tom are a piece of caustic , [Tom]75-tom , ’[75-tom] retorted [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse . There was something so very agreeable in being so intimate with such a waistcoat ; in being called [Tom]75-tom , in such an intimate way , by such a voice ; in being on such off - hand terms so soon , with such a pair of whiskers ; that [Tom]75-tom was uncommonly pleased with [himself]75-tom . ‘ Oh ! [I]75-tom do n’t care for [old Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ’[75-tom] said [he]75-tom , ‘ if [you]162-mr. harthouse mean that . [I]75-tom have always called [old Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby by the same name when [I]75-tom have talked about [him]92-mr. bounderby , and [I]75-tom have always thought of [him]92-mr. bounderby in the same way . [I]75-tom am not going to begin to be polite now , about [old Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . It would be rather late in the day . ’[75-tom] ‘ Do n’t mind [me]162-mr. harthouse , ’[162-mr. harthouse] returned [James]162-mr. harthouse ; ‘ but take care when [[his]92-mr. bounderby wife]972-his wife is by , [you]75-tom know . ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ [[His]92-mr. bounderby wife]972-his wife ? ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom . ‘ [[My]75-tom sister]664-my sister [Loo]100-loo ? O yes ! ’[75-tom] And [he]162-mr. harthouse laughed , and took a little more of the cooling drink . [James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse continued to lounge in [the same place]1290-the same place and attitude , smoking [his]162-mr. harthouse cigar in [his]162-mr. harthouse own easy way , and looking pleasantly at the whelp , as if [he]162-mr. harthouse knew [himself]162-mr. harthouse to be a kind of agreeable demon who had only to hover over [him]162-mr. harthouse , and [he]162-mr. harthouse must give up [his]162-mr. harthouse whole soul if required . It certainly did seem that [the whelp yielded to this influence]1291-the whelp yielded to this influence . [He]162-mr. harthouse looked at [[his]162-mr. harthouse companion]1292-his companion sneakingly , [he]162-mr. harthouse looked at [him]1292-his companion admiringly , [he]162-mr. harthouse looked at [him]1292-his companion boldly , and put up one leg on the sofa . ‘ [[My]75-tom sister]664-my sister [Loo]100-loo ? ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom . ‘ _ [She]664-my sister _ never cared for [old Bounderby]100-loo . ’[75-tom] ‘ That ’s the past tense , [Tom]75-tom , ’[162-mr. harthouse] returned [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , striking the ash from [his]162-mr. harthouse cigar with [his]162-mr. harthouse little finger . ‘ [We]3885-we are in the present tense , now . ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ Verb neuter , not to care . Indicative mood , present tense . First person singular , [I]75-tom do not care ; [second person singular]3886-second person singular , [thou]3887-thou dost not care ; [third person singular]3888-third person singular , [she]664-my sister does not care , ’[75-tom] returned [Tom]75-tom . ‘ Good ! If [his]75-tom second leg had not been already there when [he]75-tom was called [a dear fellow]1295-a dear fellow , [he]75-tom would have put it up at that great stage of the conversation . Feeling it necessary to do something then , [he]75-tom stretched [himself]75-tom out at greater length , and , reclining with the back of [his]75-tom head on the end of the sofa , and smoking with an infinite assumption of negligence , turned [his]75-tom common face , and not too sober eyes , towards the face looking down upon [him]75-tom so carelessly yet so potently . ‘ [You]3892-you know [[our]3893-our governor]3894-our governor , [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom , ‘ and therefore , [you]3892-you need n’t be surprised that [Loo]100-loo married [old Bounderby]100-loo . [She]100-loo never had [a lover]3895-a lover , and [the governor]3896-the governor proposed [old Bounderby]100-loo , and [she]100-loo took [him]3895-a lover . ’[75-tom] ‘ Very dutiful in [[your]162-mr. harthouse interesting sister]3897-your interesting sister , ’[162-mr. harthouse] said [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse . ‘ Yes , but [she]100-loo would n’t have been as dutiful , and it would not have come off as easily , ’[1268-the whelp] returned [the whelp]1268-the whelp , ‘ if it had n’t been for [me]1268-the whelp . ’[1268-the whelp] [The tempter]1297-the tempter merely lifted [his]1297-the tempter eyebrows ; but [the whelp]1268-the whelp was obliged to go on . ‘ _ [I]1268-the whelp _ persuaded [her]100-loo , ’[1268-the whelp] [he]1268-the whelp said , with an edifying air of superiority . ‘ [I]1268-the whelp was stuck into [[old Bounderby]100-loo ’s bank]3898-old bounderby ’s bank ( where [I]1268-the whelp never wanted to be ) , and [I]1268-the whelp knew [I]1268-the whelp should get into scrapes there , if [she]100-loo put [old Bounderby]100-loo ’s pipe out ; so [I]1268-the whelp told [her]100-loo [my]1268-the whelp wishes , and [she]100-loo came into them . [She]100-loo would do anything for [me]1268-the whelp . It was very game of [her]100-loo , was n’t it ? ’[1268-the whelp] ‘ It was charming , [Tom]75-tom ! ’[1268-the whelp] ‘ Not that it was altogether so important to [her]100-loo as it was to [me]75-tom , ’[75-tom] continued [Tom]75-tom coolly , ‘ because [my]75-tom liberty and comfort , and perhaps [my]75-tom getting on , depended on it ; and [she]100-loo had [no other lover]3899-no other lover , and staying at [home]336-home was like staying in [jail]3901-jail — especially when [I]75-tom was gone . [A girl]653-a girl can get on anywhere . [She]100-loo has settled down to the life , and _ [she]100-loo _ do n’t mind . It does just as well as another . Besides , though [Loo]100-loo is [a girl]653-a girl , [she]100-loo ’s not [a common sort of girl]3906-a common sort of girl . [She]100-loo can shut [herself]100-loo up within [herself]100-loo , and think — as [I]75-tom have often known [her]100-loo sit and watch the fire — for an hour at a stretch . ’[75-tom] ‘ Ay , ay ? Has resources of [her]100-loo own , ’[162-mr. harthouse] said [Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , smoking quietly . ‘ Not so much of that as [you]162-mr. harthouse may suppose , ’[75-tom] returned [Tom]75-tom ; ‘ for [[our]3907-our governor]3894-our governor had [her]100-loo crammed with all sorts of dry bones and sawdust . [I]75-tom can hardly believe that . [I]75-tom have picked up a little since . [I]75-tom do n’t deny that . But [I]75-tom have done it [myself]75-tom ; no thanks to [the governor]3896-the governor . ’[75-tom] ‘ And [[your]75-tom intelligent sister]3914-your intelligent sister ? ’[75-tom] ‘ [[My]75-tom intelligent sister]3915-my intelligent sister is about where [she]3915-my intelligent sister was . But _ [she]3915-my intelligent sister _ do n’t mind , ’[75-tom] [he]75-tom sagaciously added , puffing at [his]75-tom cigar again . ‘ [Girls]2709-girls can always get on , somehow . ’[75-tom] ‘ Calling at [the Bank]3460-the bank yesterday evening , for [[Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s address]3919-mr. bounderby ’s address , [I]162-mr. harthouse found [an ancient lady there]3920-an ancient lady there , who seems to entertain great admiration for [[your]75-tom sister]2822-your sister , ’[162-mr. harthouse] observed [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , throwing away the last small remnant of the cigar [he]162-mr. harthouse had now smoked out . ‘ [Mother Sparsit]166-mother sparsit ! ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom . ‘ What ! Oh no ! ’[75-tom] These were the last words spoken by [the whelp]1268-the whelp , before a giddy drowsiness came upon [him]1268-the whelp , followed by complete oblivion . [He]1268-the whelp was roused from the latter state by an uneasy dream of being stirred up with a boot , and also of a voice saying : ‘ Come , it ’s late . Be off ! ’[75-tom] ‘ Well ! ’[1268-the whelp] [he]1268-the whelp said , scrambling from the sofa . ‘ [I]1268-the whelp must take [my]1268-the whelp leave of [you]1289-his entertainer though . [I]1268-the whelp say . [Yours]1289-his entertainer is very good tobacco .
