[He]1541-i was at the bottom when [she]1542-you began to descend , and was in [the street]448-the street before [she]1542-you could take [his]1541-i arm . [Mrs. Pegler]179-mrs. pegler remained in [[her]179-mrs. pegler corner]4171-her corner until [the brother and sister]3232-the brother and sister were gone , and until [Stephen]137-stephen came back with the candle in [his]137-stephen hand . [She]179-mrs. pegler was in a state of inexpressible admiration of [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , and , like [an unaccountable old woman]4173-an unaccountable old woman , wept , ‘[1543-thee] because [she]1543-thee was such [a pretty dear]1544-a pretty dear . ’ Yet [Mrs. Pegler]179-mrs. pegler was so flurried lest the object of [her]179-mrs. pegler admiration should return by chance , or [anybody else]4174-anybody else should come , that [her]179-mrs. pegler cheerfulness was ended for that night . It was late too , to [people who rose early and worked hard]4175-people who rose early and worked hard ; therefore [the party]4176-the party broke up ; and [Stephen]137-stephen and [Rachael]140-rachael escorted [[their]1545-they mysterious acquaintance]4177-their mysterious acquaintance to the door of [the Travellers ’[1543-thee] Coffee House]4090-the travellers ’ coffee house , where [they]1545-they parted from [her]1543-thee . [They]1545-they walked back together to the corner of [the street where [Rachael]140-rachael lived]1546-the street where rachael lived , and as [they]1545-they drew nearer and nearer to [it]1546-the street where rachael lived , silence crept upon [them]1545-they . When [they]1545-they came to the dark corner where [their]1545-they unfrequent meetings always ended , [they]1545-they stopped , still silent , as if both were afraid to speak . ‘ [I]1545-they shall strive t ’[1545-they] see [thee]1543-thee agen , [Rachael]140-rachael , afore [I]0-i go , but if not — ’ ‘[1547-thou] [Thou]1547-thou wilt not , [Stephen]137-stephen , [I]0-i know . ’ Tis better that [we]1545-they make up [our]1545-they minds to be open wi ’[0-i] one another . ’ ‘[0-i] Thou’rt awlus right . ’ Tis bolder and better . [I]0-i ha been thinkin then , [Rachael]140-rachael , that as ’[0-i] tis but a day or two that remains , ’ twere better for [thee]1543-thee , [[my]0-i dear]3090-my dear , not t ’[0-i] be seen wi ’ [me]0-i . ’[0-i] T might bring [thee]1543-thee into trouble , fur no good . ’ ‘[0-i] ’ Tis not for that , [Stephen]137-stephen , that [I]0-i mind . But [thou]1547-thou know’st [our]1545-they old agreement . ’[0-i] Tis for that . ’ ‘[0-i] Well , well , ’ said [he]137-stephen . ‘[0-i] ’ Tis better , onnyways . ’[0-i] ‘ [Thou’lt]1547-thou write to [me]0-i , and tell [me]0-i all that happens , [Stephen]137-stephen ? ’[0-i] ‘ Yes . What can [I]0-i say now , but Heaven be wi ’[0-i] [thee]1543-thee , Heaven bless [thee]1543-thee , Heaven thank [thee]1543-thee and reward [thee]1543-thee ! ’ ‘[0-i] May it bless [thee]1543-thee , [Stephen]137-stephen , too , in all [thy]1543-thee wanderings , and send [thee]1543-thee peace and rest at last ! ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i towd [thee]1543-thee , [[my]0-i dear]3090-my dear , ’ said [Stephen]137-stephen Blackpool—‘that night — that [I]0-i would never see or think o ’[0-i] onnything that angered [me]0-i , but [thou]1549-thou , so much better than [me]0-i , should’st be beside it . Thou’rt beside it now . [Thou]1549-thou mak’st [me]0-i see it wi ’ a better eye . Bless [thee]1543-thee . Good night . Good - bye ! ’[1549-thou] It was but a hurried parting in [a common street]1550-a common street , yet it was a sacred remembrance to [these two common people]1551-these two common people . [Utilitarian economists]1552-utilitarian economists , [skeletons of [schoolmasters]1554-schoolmasters]1553-skeletons of schoolmasters , [Commissioners of Fact]306-commissioners of fact , [genteel and used - up infidels]1556-genteel and used - up infidels , [gabblers of many little dog’s - eared creeds]1557-gabblers of many little dog’s - eared creeds , [the poor [you]1559-you will have always with [you]1559-you]1558-the poor you will have always with you . Cultivate in [them]1551-these two common people , while there is yet time , the utmost graces of the fancies and affections , to adorn [their]1551-these two common people lives so much in need of ornament ; or , in the day of [your]1559-you triumph , when romance is utterly driven out of [their]1551-these two common people souls , and [they]1551-these two common people and a bare existence stand face to face , [Reality]181-reality will take a wolfish turn , and make an end of [you]1559-you . [Stephen]137-stephen worked the next day , and the next , uncheered by a word from [any one]2994-any one , and shunned in all [his]137-stephen comings and goings as before . At the end of the second day , [he]137-stephen saw [land]1561-land ; at the end of the third , [his]137-stephen loom stood empty . [He]137-stephen had overstayed [his]137-stephen hour in [the street outside [the Bank]3460-the bank]1562-the street outside the bank , on each of the two first evenings ; and nothing had happened there , good or bad . That [he]137-stephen might not be remiss in [his]137-stephen part of the engagement , [he]137-stephen resolved to wait full two hours , on this third and last night . There was [the lady who had once kept [[Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s house]3652-mr. bounderby ’s house , sitting at the first - floor window as [he]137-stephen had seen [her]1564-the lady who had once kept mr. bounderby ’s house , sitting at the first - floor window as he had seen her before before]1564-the lady who had once kept mr. bounderby ’s house , sitting at the first - floor window as he had seen her before ; and there was [the light porter]3662-the light porter , sometimes talking with [her]1564-the lady who had once kept mr. bounderby ’s house , sitting at the first - floor window as he had seen her before there , and sometimes looking over the blind below which had BANK upon [it]1567-it , and sometimes coming to the door and standing on the steps for a breath of air . When [he]137-stephen first came out , [Stephen]137-stephen thought [he]137-stephen might be looking for [him]137-stephen , and passed near ; but [the light porter]3662-the light porter only cast [his]3662-the light porter winking eyes upon [him]137-stephen slightly , and said nothing . Two hours were a long stretch of lounging about , after a long day ’s labour . [Stephen]137-stephen sat upon the step of a door , leaned against a wall under an archway , strolled up and down , listened for the church clock , stopped and watched [children]643-children playing in [the street]448-the street . Some purpose or other is so natural to [every one]1571-every one , that [a mere loiterer]1572-a mere loiterer always looks and feels remarkable . When the first hour was out , [Stephen]137-stephen even began to have an uncomfortable sensation upon [him]137-stephen of being for the time a disreputable character . Then came the lamplighter , and two lengthening lines of light all down the long perspective of [the street]448-the street , until they were blended and lost in the distance . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby closed the first - floor window , drew down the blind , and went up - [stairs]761-stairs . Presently , a light went up - [stairs]761-stairs after [her]1564-the lady who had once kept mr. bounderby ’s house , sitting at the first - floor window as he had seen her before , passing first the fanlight of the door , and afterwards the two staircase windows , on its way up . By and by , one corner of the second - floor blind was disturbed , as if [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s eye were there ; also the other corner , as if [the light porter]3662-the light porter ’s eye were on that side . Still , no communication was made to [Stephen]137-stephen . Much relieved when the two hours were at last accomplished , [he]137-stephen went away at a quick pace , as a recompense for so much loitering . [He]137-stephen had only to take leave of [[his]137-stephen landlady]1516-his landlady , and lie down on [his]137-stephen temporary bed upon the floor ; for [his]137-stephen bundle was made up for to - morrow , and all was arranged for [his]137-stephen departure . [He]137-stephen meant to be clear of [the town]317-the town very early ; before [the Hands]785-the hands were in [the streets]2931-the streets . It was barely daybreak , when , with a parting look round [[his]137-stephen room]3401-his room , mournfully wondering whether [he]137-stephen should ever see it again , [he]137-stephen went out . [The town]317-the town was as entirely deserted as if [the inhabitants]1583-the inhabitants had abandoned [it]317-the town , rather than hold communication with [him]137-stephen . Everything looked wan at that hour . Even the coming sun made but a pale waste in the sky , like a sad sea . By [the place where [Rachael]140-rachael lived , though it was not in [his]137-stephen way]1584-the place where rachael lived , though it was not in his way ; by [the red brick streets]1585-the red brick streets ; by [the great silent factories]1586-the great silent factories , not trembling yet ; by [the railway]3760-the railway , where the danger - lights were waning in the strengthening day ; by [the railway ’s crazy neighbourhood]1588-the railway ’s crazy neighbourhood , half pulled down and half built up ; by [scattered red brick villas]1589-scattered red brick villas , where the besmoked evergreens were sprinkled with a dirty powder , like [untidy snuff - takers]1590-untidy snuff - takers ; by coal - dust paths and many varieties of ugliness ; [Stephen]137-stephen got to [the top of [the hill]1592-the hill]1591-the top of the hill , and looked back . Day was shining radiantly upon [the town]317-the town then , and the bells were going for the morning work . Domestic fires were not yet lighted , and the high chimneys had the sky to themselves . Puffing out their poisonous volumes , [they]1583-the inhabitants would not be long in hiding it ; but , for half an hour , some of the many windows were golden , which showed [the Coketown people]1594-the coketown people a sun eternally in eclipse , through a medium of smoked glass . So strange to turn from the chimneys to the birds . So strange , to have the road - dust on [his]137-stephen feet instead of the coal - grit . So strange to have lived to [his]137-stephen time of life , and yet to be beginning like [a boy]655-a boy this summer morning ! With these musings in [his]137-stephen mind , and [his]137-stephen bundle under [his]137-stephen arm , [Stephen]137-stephen took [his]137-stephen attentive face along [the high road]1596-the high road . And the trees arched over [him]137-stephen , whispering that [he]137-stephen left a true and loving heart behind . CHAPTER VII [GUNPOWDER MR . JAMES HARTHOUSE]162-mr. harthouse , ‘ going in ’[162-mr. harthouse] for [[his]162-mr. harthouse adopted party]1597-his adopted party , soon began to score . With the aid of a little more coaching for [the political sages]1598-the political sages , a little more genteel listlessness for [the general society]1599-the general society , and a tolerable management of the assumed honesty in dishonesty , most effective and most patronized of the polite deadly sins , [he]162-mr. harthouse speedily came to be considered of much promise . The not being troubled with earnestness was a grand point in [his]162-mr. harthouse favour , enabling [him]162-mr. harthouse to take to the hard Fact fellows with as good a grace as if [he]162-mr. harthouse had been born one of [the tribe]1600-the tribe , and to throw all other tribes overboard , as [conscious hypocrites]1601-conscious hypocrites . ‘ Whom [none of]4180-none of [us]4181-us believe , [[my]1601-conscious hypocrites dear]3090-my dear [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , and who do not believe [themselves]4183-themselves . The only difference between [us]4181-us and [the professors of virtue or benevolence , or philanthropy]4184-the professors of virtue or benevolence , or philanthropy — never mind the name — is , that [we]4181-us know it is all meaningless , and say so ; while [they]4184-the professors of virtue or benevolence , or philanthropy know it equally and will never say so . ’[1601-conscious hypocrites] Why should [she]1602-her be shocked or warned by this reiteration ? It was not so unlike [[her]1602-her father]335-her father ’s principles , and [her]1602-her early training , that it need startle [her]1602-her . Where was the great difference between [the two schools]1604-the two schools , when each chained [her]1602-her down to material realities , and inspired [her]1602-her with no faith in anything else ? What was there in [her]1602-her soul for [James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse to destroy , which [Thomas Gradgrind]75-tom had nurtured there in its state of innocence ! It was even the worse for [her]1602-her at this pass , that in [her]1602-her mind — implanted there before [[her]1602-her eminently practical father]1605-her eminently practical father began to form it — a struggling disposition to believe in a wider and nobler humanity than [she]1602-her had ever heard of , constantly strove with doubts and resentments . With doubts , because the aspiration had been so laid waste in [her]1602-her youth . With resentments , because of the wrong that had been done [her]1602-her , if it were indeed a whisper of the truth . Upon a nature long accustomed to self - suppression , thus torn and divided , [the Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse philosophy came as a relief and justification . Everything being hollow and worthless , [she]1602-her had missed nothing and sacrificed nothing . What did it matter , [she]1602-her had said to [[her]1602-her father]335-her father , when [he]335-her father proposed [[her]1602-her husband]2861-her husband . What did it matter , [she]1602-her said still . With a scornful self - reliance , [she]1602-her asked [herself]1602-her , What did anything matter — and went on . Towards what ? Step by step , onward and downward , towards some end , yet so gradually , that [she]1602-her believed [herself]1602-her to remain motionless . As to [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , whither _ [he]162-mr. harthouse _ tended , [he]162-mr. harthouse neither considered nor cared . [He]162-mr. harthouse had no particular design or plan before [him]162-mr. harthouse : no energetic wickedness ruffled [his]162-mr. harthouse lassitude . [He]162-mr. harthouse was as much amused and interested , at present , as it became so fine [a gentleman]3743-a gentleman to be ; perhaps even more than it would have been consistent with [his]162-mr. harthouse reputation to confess . Soon after [his]162-mr. harthouse arrival [he]162-mr. harthouse languidly wrote to [[his]162-mr. harthouse brother]1227-his brother , [the honourable and jocular member]1610-the honourable and jocular member , that [the Bounderbys]182-the bounderbys were ‘ great fun ; ’[162-mr. harthouse] and further , that [the female Bounderby]1611-the female bounderby , instead of being the Gorgon [he]162-mr. harthouse had expected , was young , and remarkably pretty . After that , [he]162-mr. harthouse wrote no more about [them]1612-their , and devoted [his]162-mr. harthouse leisure chiefly to [[their]1612-their house]1613-their house . [He]162-mr. harthouse was very often in [[their]1612-their house]1613-their house , in [his]162-mr. harthouse flittings and visitings about [the Coketown district]1615-the coketown district ; and was much encouraged by [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . It was quite in [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s gusty way to boast to all [his]92-mr. bounderby world that _ [he]162-mr. harthouse _ did n’t care about [[your]1616-your highly connected people]1617-your highly connected people , but that if [[his]92-mr. bounderby wife [Tom Gradgrind]75-tom ’s daughter]1618-his wife tom gradgrind ’s daughter did , [she]1618-his wife tom gradgrind ’s daughter was welcome to [[their]1612-their company]1619-their company . [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse began to think it would be a new sensation , if the face which changed so beautifully for [the whelp]1268-the whelp , would change for [him]162-mr. harthouse . [He]162-mr. harthouse was quick enough to observe ; [he]162-mr. harthouse had a good memory , and did not forget a word of [the brother]1621-the brother ’s revelations . [He]162-mr. harthouse interwove them with everything [he]162-mr. harthouse saw of [the sister]1622-the sister , and [he]162-mr. harthouse began to understand [her]1622-the sister . To be sure , the better and profounder part of [her]1622-the sister character was not within [his]162-mr. harthouse scope of perception ; for in natures , as in seas , depth answers unto depth ; but [he]162-mr. harthouse soon began to read the rest with [a student]1623-a student ’s eye . [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby had taken possession of [a house]1624-a house and [grounds]1625-grounds , about fifteen miles from [the town]317-the town , and accessible within a mile or two , by [a railway]1627-a railway striding on many arches over [a wild country]1628-a wild country , undermined by [deserted coal - shafts]1629-deserted coal - shafts , and spotted at night by fires and black shapes of stationary engines at pits ’ mouths . [This country]4185-this country , gradually softening towards [the neighbourhood of [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s retreat]4186-the neighbourhood of mr. bounderby ’s retreat , there mellowed into a rustic landscape , [golden with heath]4187-golden with heath , and snowy with hawthorn in the spring of the year , and tremulous with leaves and their shadows all the summer time . [The bank]3460-the bank had foreclosed a mortgage effected on [the property thus pleasantly situated]4189-the property thus pleasantly situated , by [one of [the Coketown magnates , who , in [his]4190-one of the coketown magnates , who , in his determination to make a shorter cut than usual to an enormous fortune , overspeculated himself by about two hundred thousand pounds . these accidents did sometimes happen in the best regulated families of coketown determination to make a shorter cut than usual to an enormous fortune]4191-the coketown magnates , who , in his determination to make a shorter cut than usual to an enormous fortune , overspeculated [himself]4190-one of the coketown magnates , who , in his determination to make a shorter cut than usual to an enormous fortune , overspeculated himself by about two hundred thousand pounds . these accidents did sometimes happen in the best regulated families of coketown by about two hundred thousand pounds . It afforded [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby supreme satisfaction to instal [himself]92-mr. bounderby in [this snug little estate]4195-this snug little estate , and with demonstrative humility to grow cabbages in [the flower - garden]4196-the flower - garden . [He]92-mr. bounderby delighted to live , barrack - fashion , among the elegant furniture , and [he]92-mr. bounderby bullied the very pictures with [his]92-mr. bounderby origin . ‘[2713-sir] Why , [sir]2713-sir , ’ [he]92-mr. bounderby would say to [a visitor]4197-a visitor , ‘[2713-sir] [I]0-i am told that [Nickits]183-nickits , ’ [the late owner]4198-the late owner , ‘[183-nickits] gave seven hundred pound for that Seabeach . Now , to be plain with [you]1631-you , if [I]0-i ever , in the whole course of [my]0-i life , take seven looks at it , at a hundred pound a look , it will be as much as [I]0-i shall do . No , by [George]71-george ! [I]0-i do n’t forget that [I]0-i am [Josiah Bounderby]96-josiah bounderby of [Coketown]4-coketown . For years upon years , the only pictures in [my]0-i possession , or that [I]0-i could have got into [my]0-i possession , by any means , unless [I]0-i stole ’em , were the engravings of [a man]3830-a man shaving [himself]3830-a man in a boot , on the blacking bottles that [I]0-i was overjoyed to use in cleaning boots with , and that [I]0-i sold when they were empty for a farthing a - piece , and glad to get it ! ’[0-i] Then [he]0-i would address [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse in the same style . ‘ [Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , [you]162-mr. harthouse have a couple of horses down [here]354-here . Bring half a dozen more if [you]162-mr. harthouse like , and [we]4201-we ’ll find room for [’em]4202-’em[0-i] . There ’s stabling in [this place]656-this place for a dozen horses ; and unless [Nickits]183-nickits is belied , [he]183-nickits kept the full number . A round dozen of ’em , [sir]2713-sir . When [that man]3019-that man was [a boy]655-a boy , [he]3019-that man went to [Westminster School]39-westminster school . Went to [Westminster School]39-westminster school as [[a King]4206-a king ’s Scholar]4207-a king ’s scholar , when [I]183-nickits was principally living on garbage , and sleeping in market baskets . Why , if [I]183-nickits wanted to keep a dozen horses — which [I]183-nickits do n’t , for one ’s enough for [me]183-nickits — [I]183-nickits could n’t bear to see ’em[183-nickits] in [their]1633-their stalls [here]354-here , and think what [[my]0-i own lodging]1635-my own lodging used to be . [I]0-i could n’t look at ’em , [sir]2713-sir , and not order ’em[183-nickits] out . Yet so things come round . [You]1636-you see [this place]656-this place ; [you]1636-you know what sort of [a place]1638-a place [it]656-this place is ; [you]1636-you are aware that there ’s not a completer place of [its]656-this place size in [this kingdom]1639-this kingdom or elsewhere — [I]0-i do n’t care where — and [here]354-here , got into the middle of [it]656-this place , like a maggot into a nut , is [Josiah Bounderby]96-josiah bounderby . While [Nickits]183-nickits ( as [a man]3830-a man came into [[my]0-i office]619-my office , and told [me]0-i yesterday ) , [Nickits]183-nickits , who used to act in Latin , in the Westminster School plays , with [the chief - justices and nobility of [this country]4185-this country]1643-the chief - justices and nobility of this country applauding [him]183-nickits till [they]1643-the chief - justices and nobility of this country were black in the face , is drivelling at this minute — drivelling , sir!—in [a fifth floor]1645-a fifth floor , up [a narrow dark back street in [Antwerp]40-antwerp]1646-a narrow dark back street in antwerp . ’ It was among the leafy shadows of [this retirement]4209-this retirement , in the long sultry summer days , that [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse began to prove the face which had set [him]162-mr. harthouse wondering when [he]162-mr. harthouse first saw it , and to try if it would change for [him]162-mr. harthouse . ‘[92-mr. bounderby] [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , [I]0-i esteem it a most fortunate accident that [I]0-i find [you]92-mr. bounderby alone [here]354-here . [I]0-i have for some time had a particular wish to speak to [you]92-mr. bounderby . ’ It was not by any wonderful accident that [he]162-mr. harthouse found [her]4210-her , the time of day being that at which [she]4210-her was always alone , and [the place]329-the place being [[her]4210-her favourite resort]4212-her favourite resort . [He]162-mr. harthouse sat down beside [her]4210-her , with a glance at [her]4210-her face . ‘[0-i] [[Your]92-mr. bounderby brother]3871-your brother . [I]0-i am interested in [him]3815-my brother for [his]3815-my brother own sake . ’ [She]4218-she had made the slightest action possible , as if [she]4218-she would have risen in a hurry and gone away . [He]3815-my brother had turned the course of what [he]3815-my brother said at that instant , and [she]4218-she remained . ‘[92-mr. bounderby] [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ’ [he]3815-my brother resumed , in a lighter manner , and yet with a show of effort in assuming it , which was even more expressive than the manner [he]3815-my brother dismissed ; ‘[92-mr. bounderby] it is no irrevocable offence in [a young fellow of [[your]92-mr. bounderby brother]3871-your brother ’s years]1655-a young fellow of your brother ’s years , if [he]3815-my brother is heedless , inconsiderate , and expensive — a little dissipated , in the common phrase . Is [he]3815-my brother ? ’ ‘[3815-my brother] Yes . ’ ‘[3815-my brother] Allow [me]0-i to be frank . [I]0-i would never complain of anything , and what [I]0-i have done [I]0-i do not in the least regret . ’ ‘[0-i] So spirited , too ! ’ thought [James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse . ‘[0-i] When [I]0-i married , [I]0-i found that [[my]0-i brother]3815-my brother was even at that time heavily in debt . [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s fine bluff English independence , though a most charming characteristic , does not — as [we]1670-we have agreed — invite confidence . If [I]0-i might venture to remark that it is the least in [the world]2766-the world deficient in that delicacy to which [a youth mistaken]1672-a youth mistaken , [a character]1673-a character misconceived , and abilities misdirected , would turn for relief and guidance , [I]0-i should express what it presents to [my]0-i own view . ’ As [she]4223-her sat looking straight before [her]4223-her , across the changing lights upon the grass into the darkness of [the wood beyond]4224-the wood beyond , [he]0-i saw in [her]4223-her face [her]4223-her application of [his]0-i very distinctly uttered words . ‘[0-i] All allowance , ’ [he]0-i continued , ‘[0-i] must be made . [I]0-i can not forgive [him]3871-your brother for not being more sensible in every word , look , and act of [his]3871-your brother life , of the affection of [[his]3871-your brother best friend]1676-his best friend ; of the devotion of [[his]3871-your brother best friend]1676-his best friend ; of [her]1676-his best friend unselfishness ; of [her]1676-his best friend sacrifice . The return [he]3871-your brother makes [her]1676-his best friend , within [my]0-i observation , is a very poor one . What [she]1676-his best friend has done for [him]3871-your brother demands [his]3871-your brother constant love and gratitude , not [his]3871-your brother ill - humour and caprice . [Careless fellow]1678-careless fellow as [I]0-i am , [I]0-i am not so indifferent , [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , as to be regardless of this vice in [[your]92-mr. bounderby brother]3871-your brother , or inclined to consider it a venial offence . ’ The wood floated before [her]1676-his best friend , for [her]1676-his best friend eyes were suffused with tears . They rose from a deep well , long concealed , and [her]1676-his best friend heart was filled with acute pain that found no relief in them . ‘[92-mr. bounderby] In a word , it is to correct [[your]92-mr. bounderby brother]3871-your brother in this , [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , that [I]0-i must aspire . [My]0-i better knowledge of [his]3871-your brother circumstances , and [my]0-i direction and advice in extricating [them]1681-them — rather valuable , [I]0-i hope , as coming from [a scapegrace on a much larger scale]1682-a scapegrace on a much larger scale — will give [me]0-i some influence over [him]3871-your brother , and all [I]0-i gain [I]0-i shall certainly use towards this end . [I]0-i seem to be protesting that [I]0-i am [a sort of good fellow]1683-a sort of good fellow , when , upon [my]0-i honour , [I]0-i have not the least intention to make any protestation to that effect , and openly announce that [I]0-i am nothing of the sort . [Yonder]184-yonder , among the trees , ’ [he]0-i added , having lifted up [his]0-i eyes and looked about ; for [he]0-i had watched [her]4225-her closely until now ; ‘[184-yonder] is [[your]184-yonder brother]3871-your brother [himself]3871-your brother ; no doubt , just come down . As [he]3871-your brother seems to be loitering in this direction , it may be as well , perhaps , to walk towards [him]3871-your brother , and throw [ourselves]1685-they in [his]3871-your brother way . [He]3871-your brother has been very silent and doleful of late . Perhaps , [his]3871-your brother brotherly conscience is touched — if there are such things as consciences . Though , upon [my]0-i honour , [I]0-i hear of them much too often to believe in them . ’ [He]0-i assisted [her]4225-her to rise , and [she]4225-her took [his]0-i arm , and [they]1685-they advanced to meet the whelp . [He]0-i was idly beating the branches as [he]0-i lounged along : or [he]0-i stooped viciously to rip the moss from the trees with [his]0-i stick . [He]0-i was startled when [they]1685-they came upon [him]0-i while [he]0-i was engaged in this latter pastime , and [his]0-i colour changed . ‘[103-halloa] [Halloa]103-halloa ! ’ [he]0-i stammered ; ‘[103-halloa] [I]0-i did n’t know [you]103-halloa were [here]354-here . ’ ‘[0-i] Whose name , [Tom]75-tom , ’ said [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , putting [his]162-mr. harthouse hand upon [his]75-tom shoulder and turning [him]75-tom , so that [they]1685-they all three walked towards [the house]2875-the house together , ‘[75-tom] have [you]75-tom been carving on the trees ? ’ ‘[75-tom] Whose name ? ’ returned [Tom]75-tom . ‘[75-tom] Oh ! [You]103-halloa mean what [girl]2742-girl ’s name ? ’ ‘[2742-girl] [You]75-tom have a suspicious appearance of inscribing some fair creature ’s on the bark , [Tom]75-tom . ’ [ Picture : [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse and [Tom Gradgrind]75-tom in [the garden]4227-the garden ] ‘[75-tom] Not much of that , [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , unless [some fair creature with a slashing fortune at [her]1688-some fair creature with a slashing fortune at her own disposal own disposal]1688-some fair creature with a slashing fortune at her own disposal would take a fancy to [me]0-i . Or [she]1688-some fair creature with a slashing fortune at her own disposal might be as ugly as [she]1688-some fair creature with a slashing fortune at her own disposal was rich , without any fear of losing [me]0-i . [I]0-i ’d carve [her]1688-some fair creature with a slashing fortune at her own disposal name as often as [she]1688-some fair creature with a slashing fortune at her own disposal liked . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am afraid [you]75-tom are [mercenary]1689-mercenary , [Tom]75-tom . ’ ‘[75-tom] Mercenary , ’ repeated [Tom]75-tom . ‘[75-tom] Who is [not mercenary]1690-not mercenary ? Ask [[my]0-i sister]664-my sister . ’ ‘[664-my sister] Have [you]75-tom so proved it to be a failing of [mine]664-my sister , [Tom]75-tom ? ’ said [Louisa]91-louisa , showing no other sense of [his]75-tom discontent and ill - nature . ‘[75-tom] [You]75-tom know whether the cap fits [you]75-tom , [Loo]100-loo , ’ returned [[her]91-louisa brother]2889-her brother sulkily . ‘[100-loo] If it does , [you]75-tom can wear it . ’ ‘[75-tom] [Tom]75-tom is misanthropical to - day , as [all bored people]1692-all bored people are now and then , ’ said [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse . ‘[75-tom] Do n’t believe [him]75-tom , [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . [He]75-tom knows much better . [I]0-i shall disclose some of [his]75-tom opinions of [you]75-tom , privately expressed to [me]0-i , unless [he]75-tom relents a little . ’ ‘[75-tom] At all events , [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , ’ said [Tom]75-tom , softening in [his]75-tom admiration of [[his]75-tom patron]4229-his patron , but shaking [his]75-tom head sullenly too , ‘[75-tom] [you]75-tom ca n’t tell [her]1693-her that [I]0-i ever praised [her]1693-her for being [mercenary]1689-mercenary . [I]0-i may have praised [her]1693-her for being the contrary , and [I]0-i should do it again , if [I]0-i had as good reason . However , never mind this now ; it ’s not very interesting to [you]75-tom , and [I]0-i am sick of the subject . ’ [They]4230-they walked on to [the house]2875-the house , where [Louisa]91-louisa quitted [[her]91-louisa visitor]4232-her visitor ’s arm and went in . [He]75-tom stood looking after [her]91-louisa , as [she]91-louisa ascended the steps , and passed into the shadow of the door ; then put [his]75-tom hand upon [[her]91-louisa brother]2889-her brother ’s shoulder again , and invited [him]75-tom with a confidential nod to a walk in [the garden]4227-the garden . ‘[75-tom] [Tom]75-tom , [[my]0-i fine fellow]1695-my fine fellow , [I]0-i want to have a word with [you]75-tom . ’ [They]4230-they had stopped among a disorder of roses — it was part of [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s humility to keep [Nickits]183-nickits ’s roses on a reduced scale — and [Tom]75-tom sat down on [a terrace - parapet]4235-a terrace - parapet , plucking buds and picking them to pieces ; while [[his]75-tom powerful Familiar]4236-his powerful familiar stood over [him]75-tom , with a foot upon the parapet , and [his]75-tom figure easily resting on the arm supported by that knee . [They]4230-they were just visible from [her]4236-his powerful familiar window . Perhaps [she]4236-his powerful familiar saw them . ‘[75-tom] [Tom]75-tom , what ’s the matter ? ’ ‘[75-tom] Oh ! [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , ’ said [Tom]75-tom with a groan , ‘[162-mr. harthouse] [I]0-i am hard up , and bothered out of [my]0-i life . ’ ‘[0-i] [[My]0-i good fellow]882-my good fellow , so am [I.]0-i ’ ‘[162-mr. harthouse] [You]162-mr. harthouse ! ’ returned [Tom]75-tom . ‘[162-mr. harthouse] [You]162-mr. harthouse are the picture of independence . [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , [I]0-i am in a horrible mess . [You]162-mr. harthouse have no idea what a state [I]0-i have got [myself]0-i into — what a state [[my]0-i sister]664-my sister might have got [me]0-i out of , if [she]664-my sister would only have done it . ’ [He]0-i took to biting the rosebuds now , and tearing them away from [his]0-i teeth with a hand that trembled like [an infirm old man]4237-an infirm old man ’s . After one exceedingly observant look at [him]0-i , [[his]0-i companion]1292-his companion relapsed into [his]0-i lightest air . ‘[75-tom] [Tom]75-tom , [you]75-tom are inconsiderate : [you]75-tom expect too much of [[your]75-tom sister]2822-your sister . [You]75-tom have had money of [her]2822-your sister , [you]75-tom dog , [you]75-tom know [you]75-tom have . ’ ‘[75-tom] Well , [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , [I]0-i know [I]0-i have . How else was [I]0-i to get it ? Here ’s [old Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby always boasting that at [my]0-i age [he]92-mr. bounderby lived upon twopence a month , or something of that sort . Here ’s [[my]0-i father]1699-my father drawing what [he]1699-my father calls a line , and tying [me]0-i down to it from [a baby]714-a baby , neck and heels . Here ’s [[[my]0-i mother]357-my mother who never has anything of [her]357-my mother own , except [her]357-my mother complaints . What _ is _ [a fellow]1703-a fellow to do for money , and where _ am _ [I]0-i to look for it , if not to [[my]0-i sister]664-my sister]1702-my mother who never has anything of her own , except her complaints . what _ is _ a fellow to do for money , and where _ am _ i to look for it , if not to my sister ? ’ [He]0-i was almost crying , and scattered the buds about by dozens . [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse took [him]0-i persuasively by the coat . ‘[75-tom] But , [[my]0-i dear]3090-my dear [Tom]75-tom , if [[your]75-tom sister]2822-your sister has not got it — ’ ‘[2822-your sister] Not got it , [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse ? [I]0-i do n’t say [she]2822-your sister has got it . [I]0-i may have wanted more than [she]2822-your sister was likely to have got . But then [she]2822-your sister ought to get it . [She]2822-your sister could get it . It ’s of no use pretending to make a secret of matters now , after what [I]0-i have told [you]75-tom already ; [you]75-tom know [she]2822-your sister did n’t marry [old Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby for [her]2822-your sister own sake , or for [his]92-mr. bounderby sake , but for [my]0-i sake . Then why does n’t [she]2822-your sister get what [I]0-i want , out of [him]92-mr. bounderby , for [my]0-i sake ? [She]2822-your sister is not obliged to say what [she]2822-your sister is going to do with it ; [she]2822-your sister is sharp enough ; [she]2822-your sister could manage to coax it out of [him]92-mr. bounderby , if [she]2822-your sister chose . Then why does n’t [she]2822-your sister choose , when [I]0-i tell [her]2822-your sister of what consequence it is ? But no . There [she]2822-your sister sits in [[his]92-mr. bounderby company]1707-his company like a stone , instead of making [herself]2822-your sister agreeable and getting it easily . [I]0-i do n’t know what [you]1708-you may call this , but [I]0-i call it unnatural conduct . ’ There was a piece of ornamental water immediately below the parapet , on the other side , into which [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse had a very strong inclination to pitch [Mr. Thomas Gradgrind junior]75-tom , as [the injured men of [Coketown]4-coketown]4239-the injured men of coketown threatened to pitch [[their]4239-the injured men of coketown property]3616-their property into [the Atlantic]32-the atlantic . But [he]162-mr. harthouse preserved [his]162-mr. harthouse easy attitude ; and nothing more solid went over the stone balustrades than the accumulated rosebuds now floating about , a little surface - island . ‘[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]3090-my dear [Tom]75-tom , ’ said [Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , ‘[0-i] let [me]0-i try to be [[your]75-tom banker]1710-your banker . ’ ‘[0-i] For [God]126-god ’s sake , ’ replied [Tom]75-tom , suddenly , ‘[0-i] do n’t talk about [bankers]1711-bankers ! ’ And very white [he]75-tom looked , in contrast with the roses . Very white . [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , as [a thoroughly well - bred man]4241-a thoroughly well - bred man , accustomed to the best society , was not to be surprised — [he]162-mr. harthouse could as soon have been affected — but [he]162-mr. harthouse raised [his]162-mr. harthouse eyelids a little more , as if they were lifted by a feeble touch of wonder . Albeit it was as much against the precepts of [[his]162-mr. harthouse school]2779-his school to wonder , as it was against the doctrines of [the Gradgrind College]41-the gradgrind college . ‘[0-i] What is the present need , [Tom]75-tom ? [Three figures]1712-three figures ? Out with [them]1712-three figures . Say what [they]1712-three figures are . ’ ‘[162-mr. harthouse] [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , ’ returned [Tom]75-tom , now actually crying ; and [his]75-tom tears were better than [his]75-tom injuries , however pitiful a figure [he]75-tom made : ‘[162-mr. harthouse] it ’s too late ; the money is of no use to [me]0-i at present . [I]0-i should have had it before to be of use to [me]0-i . But [I]0-i am very much obliged to [you]162-mr. harthouse ; [you]162-mr. harthouse ’re [a true friend]4243-a true friend . ’[162-mr. harthouse] [A true friend]4243-a true friend ! ‘ Whelp , whelp ! ’[162-mr. harthouse] thought [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , lazily ; ‘ what an Ass [you]162-mr. harthouse are ! ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ And [I]75-tom take [your]162-mr. harthouse offer as a great kindness , ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom , grasping [his]162-mr. harthouse hand . ‘ As a great kindness , [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse . ’[75-tom] ‘ Well , ’[1294-the other] returned [the other]1294-the other , ‘ it may be of more use by and by . And , [[my]1294-the other good fellow]882-my good fellow , if [you]162-mr. harthouse will open [your]162-mr. harthouse bedevilments to [me]1294-the other when they come thick upon [you]162-mr. harthouse , [I]1294-the other may show [you]162-mr. harthouse better ways out of them than [you]162-mr. harthouse can find for [yourself]162-mr. harthouse . ’[1294-the other] ‘ Thank [you]162-mr. harthouse , ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom , shaking [his]75-tom head dismally , and chewing rosebuds . ‘ [I]75-tom wish [I]75-tom had known [you]162-mr. harthouse sooner , [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse . ’[75-tom] ‘ Now , [you]75-tom see , [Tom]75-tom , ’[162-mr. harthouse] said [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse in conclusion , [himself]162-mr. harthouse tossing over a rose or two , as a contribution to [the island]1715-the island , which was always drifting to the wall as if it wanted to become a part of [the mainland]1716-the mainland : ‘ [every man]822-every man is selfish in everything [he]822-every man does , and [I]162-mr. harthouse am exactly like the rest of [my]162-mr. harthouse fellow - creatures . [I]162-mr. harthouse am desperately intent ; ’[162-mr. harthouse] the languor of [his]162-mr. harthouse desperation being quite tropical ; ‘ on [your]75-tom softening towards [[your]75-tom sister]2822-your sister — which [you]75-tom ought to do ; and on [your]75-tom being a more loving and agreeable sort of brother — which [you]75-tom ought to be . ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ [I]162-mr. harthouse will be , [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse . ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ No time like the present , [Tom]75-tom . Begin at once . ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ Certainly [I]162-mr. harthouse will . And [[my]162-mr. harthouse sister]664-my sister [Loo]100-loo shall say so . ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ Having made which bargain , [Tom]75-tom , ’[162-mr. harthouse] said [Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , clapping [him]162-mr. harthouse on the shoulder again , with an air which left [him]162-mr. harthouse at liberty to infer — as [he]162-mr. harthouse did , [poor fool]1717-poor fool — that this condition was imposed upon [him]162-mr. harthouse in mere careless good nature to lessen [his]162-mr. harthouse sense of obligation , ‘ [we]4248-we will tear [ourselves]4248-we asunder until dinner - time . ’[162-mr. harthouse] When [Tom]75-tom appeared before dinner , though [his]75-tom mind seemed heavy enough , [his]75-tom body was on the alert ; and [he]75-tom appeared before [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby came in . ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby did n’t mean to be cross , [Loo]100-loo , ’[92-mr. bounderby] [he]92-mr. bounderby said , giving [her]1718-her [his]92-mr. bounderby hand , and kissing [her]1718-her . ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby know [you]1718-her are fond of [me]92-mr. bounderby , and [you]1718-her know [I]92-mr. bounderby am fond of [you]1718-her . ’[92-mr. bounderby] After this , there was a smile upon [Louisa]91-louisa ’s face that day , for [some one else]1719-some one else . Alas , for [some one else]1719-some one else ! ‘ So much the less is the whelp the only creature that [she]1718-her cares for , ’[162-mr. harthouse] thought [James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , reversing the reflection of [his]162-mr. harthouse first day ’s knowledge of [her]1718-her pretty face . ‘ So much the less , so much the less . ’[162-mr. harthouse] CHAPTER VIII EXPLOSION THE next morning was too bright a morning for sleep , and [James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse rose early , and sat in the pleasant bay window of [[his]162-mr. harthouse dressing - room]1721-his dressing - room , smoking the rare tobacco that had had so wholesome an influence on [[his]162-mr. harthouse young friend]510-his young friend . Reposing in the sunlight , with the fragrance of [his]162-mr. harthouse eastern pipe about [him]162-mr. harthouse , and the dreamy smoke vanishing into the air , so rich and soft with summer odours , [he]162-mr. harthouse reckoned up [his]162-mr. harthouse advantages as [an idle winner]1723-an idle winner might count [his]162-mr. harthouse gains . [He]162-mr. harthouse was not at all bored for the time , and could give [his]162-mr. harthouse mind to it . [He]162-mr. harthouse had established a confidence with [her]1718-her , from which [[her]1718-her husband]2861-her husband was excluded . [He]162-mr. harthouse had established a confidence with [her]1718-her , that absolutely turned upon [her]1718-her indifference towards [[her]1718-her husband]2861-her husband , and the absence , now and at all times , of any congeniality between [them]1726-them . [He]162-mr. harthouse had artfully , but plainly , assured [her]1718-her that [he]162-mr. harthouse knew [her]1718-her heart in its last most delicate recesses ; [he]162-mr. harthouse had come so near to [her]1718-her through its tenderest sentiment ; [he]162-mr. harthouse had associated [himself]162-mr. harthouse with that feeling ; and the barrier behind which [she]1718-her lived , had melted away . All very odd , and very satisfactory ! And yet [he]162-mr. harthouse had not , even now , any earnest wickedness of purpose in [him]162-mr. harthouse . Publicly and privately , it were much better for the age in which [he]162-mr. harthouse lived , that [he]162-mr. harthouse and [the legion of whom [he]162-mr. harthouse was [one]2846-one]1727-the legion of whom he was one were designedly bad , than indifferent and purposeless . It is the drifting icebergs setting with any current anywhere , that wreck [the ships]1729-the ships . When [the Devil]185-the devil goeth about like a roaring lion , [he]185-the devil goeth about in a shape by which [few but savages and hunters]1730-few but savages and hunters are attracted . But , when [he]185-the devil is trimmed , smoothed , and varnished , according to the mode ; when [he]185-the devil is aweary of vice , and aweary of virtue , used up as to brimstone , and used up as to bliss ; then , whether [he]185-the devil take to the serving out of red tape , or to the kindling of red fire , [he]185-the devil is [the very Devil]1731-the very devil . So [James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse reclined in the window , indolently smoking , and reckoning up the steps [he]162-mr. harthouse had taken on [the road by which [he]162-mr. harthouse happened to be travelling]1732-the road by which he happened to be travelling . The end to which it led was before [him]162-mr. harthouse , pretty plainly ; but [he]162-mr. harthouse troubled [himself]162-mr. harthouse with no calculations about it . What will be , will be . As [he]162-mr. harthouse had rather a long ride to take that day — for there was a public occasion ‘ to do ’[162-mr. harthouse] at some distance , which afforded a tolerable opportunity of going in for [the Gradgrind men]1733-the gradgrind men — [he]162-mr. harthouse dressed early and went down to breakfast . [He]162-mr. harthouse was anxious to see if [she]1734-she had relapsed since the previous evening . No . [He]162-mr. harthouse resumed where [he]162-mr. harthouse had left off . There was a look of interest for [him]162-mr. harthouse again . [He]162-mr. harthouse got through the day as much ( or as little ) to [his]162-mr. harthouse own satisfaction , as was to be expected under the fatiguing circumstances ; and came riding back at six o’clock . There was a sweep of some half - mile between [the lodge]1735-the lodge and [the house]2875-the house , and [he]162-mr. harthouse was riding along at a foot pace over the smooth gravel , once [Nickits]183-nickits ’s , when [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby burst out of the shrubbery , with such violence as to make [his]92-mr. bounderby horse shy across [the road]326-the road . ‘ [Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] cried [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ Have [you]162-mr. harthouse heard ? ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Heard what ? ’[162-mr. harthouse] said [Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , soothing [his]162-mr. harthouse horse , and inwardly favouring [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby with no good wishes . ‘ Then [you]92-mr. bounderby _ have n’t _ heard ! ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby have heard [you]162-mr. harthouse , and so has [this brute]4249-this brute . [I]92-mr. bounderby have heard nothing else . ’[92-mr. bounderby] [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , red and hot , planted [himself]92-mr. bounderby in the centre of the path before the horse ’s head , to explode [his]92-mr. bounderby bombshell with more effect . ‘ [The Bank]3460-the bank ’s robbed ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ [You]92-mr. bounderby do n’t mean it ! ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ Robbed last night , [sir]2713-sir . Robbed in an extraordinary manner . Robbed with a false key . ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ Of much ? ’[92-mr. bounderby] [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , in [his]92-mr. bounderby desire to make the most of it , really seemed mortified by being obliged to reply , ‘ Why , no ; not of very much . But it might have been . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Of how much ? ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ Oh ! as a sum — if [you]162-mr. harthouse stick to a sum — of not more than a hundred and fifty pound , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , with impatience . ‘ But it ’s not the sum ; it ’s the fact . It ’s the fact of [the Bank]3460-the bank being robbed , that ’s the important circumstance . [I]92-mr. bounderby am surprised [you]162-mr. harthouse do n’t see it . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ [[My]162-mr. harthouse dear]3090-my dear [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ’[162-mr. harthouse] said [James]162-mr. harthouse , dismounting , and giving [his]162-mr. harthouse bridle to [[his]162-mr. harthouse servant]838-his servant , ‘ [I]162-mr. harthouse _ do _ see it ; and am as overcome as [you]92-mr. bounderby can possibly desire [me]162-mr. harthouse to be , by the spectacle afforded to [my]162-mr. harthouse mental view . Nevertheless , [I]162-mr. harthouse may be allowed , [I]162-mr. harthouse hope , to congratulate [you]92-mr. bounderby — which [I]162-mr. harthouse do with all [my]162-mr. harthouse soul , [I]162-mr. harthouse assure [you]92-mr. bounderby — on [your]92-mr. bounderby not having sustained a greater loss . ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ [Thank’ee]165-thank’ee , ’[92-mr. bounderby] replied [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , in a short , ungracious manner . ‘ But [I]92-mr. bounderby tell [you]92-mr. bounderby what . It might have been twenty thousand pound . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ [I]162-mr. harthouse suppose it might . ’[162-mr. harthouse] ‘ Suppose it might ! By [the Lord]4254-the lord , [you]92-mr. bounderby _ may _ suppose so . By [George]71-george ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , with sundry menacing nods and shakes of [his]92-mr. bounderby head . ‘ It might have been twice twenty . There ’s no knowing what it would have been , or would n’t have been , as it was , but for [the fellows]4255-the fellows ’[92-mr. bounderby] being disturbed . ’ [Louisa]91-louisa had come up now , and [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , and [Bitzer]77-bitzer . ‘[92-mr. bounderby] Here ’s [[Tom Gradgrind]75-tom ’s daughter]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter knows pretty well what it might have been , if [you]92-mr. bounderby do n’t , ’ blustered [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[92-mr. bounderby] Dropped , [sir]2713-sir , as if [she]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter was shot when [I]0-i told [her]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter ! Never knew [her]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter do such a thing before . Does [her]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter credit , under the circumstances , in [my]0-i opinion ! ’ [She]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter still looked faint and pale . [James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse begged [her]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter to take [his]162-mr. harthouse arm ; and as [they]4256-they moved on very slowly , asked [her]3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter how the robbery had been committed . ‘[3555-tom gradgrind ’s daughter] Why , [I]0-i am going to tell [you]92-mr. bounderby , ’ said [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , irritably giving [his]92-mr. bounderby arm to [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[0-i] If [you]92-mr. bounderby had n’t been so mighty particular about the sum , [I]0-i should have begun to tell [you]92-mr. bounderby before . [You]92-mr. bounderby know [this lady]3106-this lady ( for [she]3106-this lady _ is _ [a lady]1742-a lady ) , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ? ’ ‘[92-mr. bounderby] [I]0-i have already had the honour — ’ ‘[0-i] Very well . And [this young man]1743-this young man , [Bitzer]77-bitzer , [you]92-mr. bounderby saw [him]1743-this young man too on the same occasion ? ’ [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse inclined [his]162-mr. harthouse head in assent , and [Bitzer]77-bitzer knuckled [his]77-bitzer forehead . ‘[1743-this young man] Very well . [They]1744-they live at [the Bank]3460-the bank . [You]92-mr. bounderby know [they]1744-they live at [the Bank]3460-the bank , perhaps ? Very well . Yesterday afternoon , at the close of business hours , everything was put away as usual . In [the iron room that [this young fellow]1748-this young fellow sleeps outside of]1747-the iron room that this young fellow sleeps outside of , there was never mind how much . In the little safe in [[young Tom]75-tom ’s closet]1749-young tom ’s closet , the safe used for petty purposes , there was a hundred and fifty odd pound . ’ ‘[0-i] A hundred and fifty - four , seven , one , ’ said [Bitzer]77-bitzer . ‘[0-i] Come ! ’ retorted [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , stopping to wheel round upon [him]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[0-i] let ’s have none of _ [your]92-mr. bounderby _ interruptions . It ’s enough to be robbed while [you]92-mr. bounderby ’re snoring because [you]92-mr. bounderby ’re[0-i] too comfortable , without being put right with _ [your]92-mr. bounderby _ four seven ones . [I]0-i did n’t snore , [myself]0-i , when [I]0-i was [your]92-mr. bounderby age , let [me]0-i tell [you]92-mr. bounderby . [I]0-i had n’t victuals enough to snore . And [I]0-i did n’t four seven one . Not if [I]0-i knew it . ’ [Bitzer]77-bitzer knuckled [his]77-bitzer forehead again , in a sneaking manner , and seemed at once particularly impressed and depressed by the instance last given of [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s moral abstinence . ‘[0-i] A hundred and fifty odd pound , ’ resumed [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[0-i] That sum of money , [young Tom]75-tom locked in [[his]75-tom safe]1750-his safe , not a very strong safe , but that ’s no matter now . Everything was left , all right . Some time in the night , while [this young fellow]1748-this young fellow snored — [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , [ma’am]350-ma’am , [you]92-mr. bounderby say [you]92-mr. bounderby have heard [him]1748-this young fellow snore ? ’ ‘[2713-sir] [Sir]2713-sir , ’ returned [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[2713-sir] [I]0-i can not say that [I]0-i have heard [him]1748-this young fellow precisely snore , and therefore must not make that statement . But on winter evenings , when [he]1748-this young fellow has fallen asleep at [his]1748-this young fellow table , [I]0-i have heard [him]1748-this young fellow , what [I]0-i should prefer to describe as partially choke . Not , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , with a lofty sense of giving strict evidence , ‘[0-i] that [I]0-i would convey any imputation on [his]1748-this young fellow moral character . Far from it . [I]0-i have always considered [Bitzer]77-bitzer [a young man of the most upright principle]1754-a young man of the most upright principle ; and to that [I]0-i beg to bear [my]0-i testimony . ’ ‘[0-i] Well ! ’ said [the exasperated Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[1748-this young fellow] while [he]1748-this young fellow was snoring , _ or _ choking , _ or _ Dutch - clocking , _ or _ something _ or _ other — being asleep — [some fellows]1037-some fellows , somehow , whether previously concealed in [the house]2875-the house or not remains to be seen , got to [young Tom]75-tom ’s safe , forced it , and abstracted the contents . Being then disturbed , [they]1037-some fellows made off ; letting [themselves]1037-some fellows out at the main door , and double - locking it again ( it was double - locked , and the key under [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s pillow ) with a false key , which was picked up in [the street]448-the street near [the Bank]3460-the bank , about twelve o’clock to - day . Then , looking at [Tom]75-tom ’s safe , [he]1759-this chap sees the door ajar , and finds the lock forced , and the money gone . ’ ‘[1759-this chap] Where is [Tom]75-tom , by the by ? ’ asked [Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , glancing round . ‘[75-tom] [He]75-tom has been helping [the police]1761-the police , ’ said [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[75-tom] and stays behind at [the Bank]3460-the bank . [You]1784-you ’ll have the goodness to keep it quiet , and mention it to [no one]545-no one . It may take time , but [we]1786-we shall have ’em . It ’s policy to give ’em[440-an old woman] line enough , and there ’s no objection to that . ’ ‘[440-an old woman] Of course , [they]1787-they will be punished with the utmost rigour of the law , as notice - boards observe , ’ replied [James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , ‘[160-banks] and serve [them]1787-they right . [Fellows who go in for [Banks]160-banks]1788-fellows who go in for banks must take the consequences . If there were no consequences , [we]1786-we should all go in for [Banks]160-banks . ’ [He]92-mr. bounderby had gently taken [Louisa]91-louisa ’s parasol from [her]91-louisa hand , and had put it up for [her]91-louisa ; and [she]91-louisa walked under its shade , though the sun did not shine there . ‘[100-loo] For the present , [Loo Bounderby]100-loo , ’ said [[her]91-louisa husband]2861-her husband , ‘[100-loo] here ’s [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby to look after . Anything will do for [Me]0-i . ’ It soon appeared that if [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby had a failing in [her]91-louisa association with [that domestic establishment]4286-that domestic establishment , it was that [she]91-louisa was so excessively regardless of [herself]91-louisa and regardful of [others]671-others , as to be a nuisance . On being shown [[her]91-louisa chamber]4288-her chamber , [she]91-louisa was so dreadfully sensible of its comforts as to suggest the inference that [she]91-louisa would have preferred to pass the night on the mangle in [the laundry]4289-the laundry . True , [the Powlers]190-the powlers and [the Scadgerses]4290-the scadgerses were accustomed to splendour , ‘[0-i] but it is [my]0-i duty to remember , ’ [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was fond of observing with a lofty grace : particularly when [any of [the domestics]4292-the domestics]4291-any of the domestics were present , ‘[0-i] that what [I]0-i was , [I]0-i am no longer . Indeed , ’ said [she]91-louisa , ‘[0-i] if [I]0-i could altogether cancel the remembrance that [Mr. Sparsit]1792-mr. sparsit was [a Powler]584-a powler , or that [I]0-i [myself]0-i am related to [the Scadgers family]1794-the scadgers family ; or if [I]0-i could even revoke the fact , and make [myself]0-i [a person of common descent and ordinary connexions]1795-a person of common descent and ordinary connexions ; [I]0-i would gladly do so . [I]0-i should think it , under existing circumstances , right to do so . ’ The same Hermitical state of mind led to [her]91-louisa renunciation of made dishes and wines at dinner , until fairly commanded by [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby to take them ; when [she]91-louisa said , ‘[0-i] Indeed [you]1792-mr. sparsit are very good , [sir]2713-sir ; ’ and departed from a resolution of which [she]91-louisa had made rather formal and public announcement , to ‘[1792-mr. sparsit] wait for the simple mutton . ’ [She]91-louisa was likewise deeply apologetic for wanting the salt ; and , feeling amiably bound to bear out [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby to the fullest extent in the testimony [he]92-mr. bounderby had borne to [her]91-louisa nerves , occasionally sat back in [her]91-louisa chair and silently wept ; at which periods a tear of large dimensions , like a crystal ear - ring , might be observed ( or rather , must be , for it insisted on public notice ) sliding down [her]91-louisa Roman nose . But [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s greatest point , first and last , was [her]91-louisa determination to pity [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . There were occasions when in looking at [him]92-mr. bounderby [she]91-louisa was involuntarily moved to shake [her]91-louisa head , as who would say , ‘[0-i] Alas , poor [Yorick]191-yorick ! ’ After allowing [herself]91-louisa to be betrayed into these evidences of emotion , [she]91-louisa would force a lambent brightness , and would be fitfully cheerful , and would say , ‘[191-yorick] [You]1792-mr. sparsit have still good spirits , [sir]2713-sir , [I]0-i am thankful to find ; ’ and would appear to hail it as a blessed dispensation that [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby bore up as [he]92-mr. bounderby did . One idiosyncrasy for which [she]91-louisa often apologized , [she]91-louisa found it excessively difficult to conquer . [She]91-louisa had a curious propensity to call [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ‘[1792-mr. sparsit] [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind , ’ and yielded to it some three or four score times in the course of the evening . [Her]91-louisa repetition of this mistake covered [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby with modest confusion ; but indeed , [she]91-louisa said , it seemed so natural to say [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind : whereas , to persuade [herself]91-louisa that [the young lady whom [she]91-louisa had had the happiness of knowing from [a child]339-a child]4293-the young lady whom she had had the happiness of knowing from a child could be really and truly [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , [she]91-louisa found almost impossible . It was a further singularity of this remarkable case , that the more [she]91-louisa thought about it , the more impossible it appeared ; ‘[127-miss gradgrind] the differences , ’ [she]91-louisa observed , ‘[127-miss gradgrind] being such . ’ In [the drawing - room]755-the drawing - room after dinner , [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby tried the case of the robbery , examined [the witnesses]4296-the witnesses , made notes of the evidence , found [the suspected persons]4297-the suspected persons guilty , and sentenced [them]4297-the suspected persons to the extreme punishment of the law . That done , [Bitzer]77-bitzer was dismissed to [town]427-town with instructions to recommend [Tom]75-tom to come [home]336-home by [the mail - train]4300-the mail - train . When candles were brought , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby murmured , ‘[127-miss gradgrind] Do n’t be low , [sir]2713-sir . Pray let [me]0-i see [you]2713-sir cheerful , [sir]2713-sir , as [I]0-i used to do . ’ [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , upon whom these consolations had begun to produce the effect of making [him]92-mr. bounderby , in a bull - headed blundering way , sentimental , sighed like some large sea - animal . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i can not bear to see [you]2713-sir so , [sir]2713-sir , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[2713-sir] Try a hand at backgammon , [sir]2713-sir , as [you]2713-sir used to do when [I]0-i had the honour of living under [your]2713-sir roof . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i have n’t played backgammon , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[0-i] since that time . ’ ‘[0-i] No , [sir]2713-sir , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , soothingly , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am aware that [you]2713-sir have not . [I]0-i remember that [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind takes no interest in the game . But [I]0-i shall be happy , [sir]2713-sir , if [you]2713-sir will condescend . ’ [They]4301-they played near a window , opening on [the garden]4227-the garden . It was a fine night : not moonlight , but sultry and fragrant . [Louisa]91-louisa and [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse strolled out into [the garden]4227-the garden , where [their]4301-they voices could be heard in the stillness , though not what [they]4301-they said . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , from [[her]350-ma’am place at [the backgammon board]4305-the backgammon board]4304-her place at the backgammon board , was constantly straining [her]350-ma’am eyes to pierce the shadows without . ‘[2713-sir] What ’s the matter , [ma’am]350-ma’am ? ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ; ‘[350-ma’am] [you]350-ma’am do n’t see a Fire , do [you]350-ma’am ? ’ ‘[350-ma’am] Oh dear no , [sir]2713-sir , ’ returned [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[2713-sir] [I]0-i was thinking of the dew . ’ ‘[0-i] What have [you]350-ma’am got to do with the dew , [ma’am]350-ma’am ? ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[350-ma’am] It ’s not [myself]0-i , [sir]2713-sir , ’ returned [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[2713-sir] [I]0-i am fearful of [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind ’s taking cold . ’ ‘[127-miss gradgrind] [She]127-miss gradgrind never takes cold , ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[2713-sir] Really , [sir]2713-sir ? ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . And was affected with a cough in [her]350-ma’am throat . When the time drew near for retiring , [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby took a glass of water . ‘[2713-sir] Oh , [sir]2713-sir ? ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[2713-sir] Not [your]2713-sir sherry warm , with lemon - peel and nutmeg ? ’ ‘[2713-sir] Why , [I]0-i have got out of the habit of taking it now , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[0-i] The more ’s the pity , [sir]2713-sir , ’ returned [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ; ‘[0-i] [you]2713-sir are losing all [your]2713-sir good old habits . Cheer up , [sir]2713-sir ! If [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind will permit [me]0-i , [I]0-i will offer to make it for [you]2713-sir , as [I]0-i have often done . ’ [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind readily permitting [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby to do anything [she]127-miss gradgrind pleased , [that considerate lady]4306-that considerate lady made the beverage , and handed it to [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[0-i] It will do [you]2713-sir good , [sir]2713-sir . It will warm [your]2713-sir heart . It is the sort of thing [you]2713-sir want , and ought to take , [sir]2713-sir . ’ And when [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby said , ‘[2713-sir] [Your]2713-sir health , [ma’am]350-ma’am ! ’ [she]350-ma’am answered with great feeling , ‘[2713-sir] Thank [you]2713-sir , [sir]2713-sir . The same to [you]2713-sir , and happiness also . ’ Finally , [she]350-ma’am wished [him]2713-sir good night , with great pathos ; and [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby went to bed , with a maudlin persuasion that [he]2713-sir had been crossed in something tender , though [he]2713-sir could not , for [his]2713-sir life , have mentioned what it was . Long after [Louisa]91-louisa had undressed and lain down , [she]91-louisa watched and waited for [[her]91-louisa brother]2889-her brother ’s coming [home]336-home . That could hardly be , [she]91-louisa knew , until an hour past midnight ; but in the country silence , which did anything but calm the trouble of [her]91-louisa thoughts , time lagged wearily . At last , when the darkness and stillness had seemed for hours to thicken one another , [she]91-louisa heard the bell at the gate . [She]91-louisa felt as though [she]91-louisa would have been glad that it rang on until daylight ; but it ceased , and the circles of its last sound spread out fainter and wider in the air , and all was dead again . [She]91-louisa waited yet some quarter of an hour , as [she]91-louisa judged . Then [she]91-louisa arose , put on a loose robe , and went out of [[her]91-louisa room]4309-her room in the dark , and up the staircase to [[[her]91-louisa brother]2889-her brother ’s room]4311-her brother ’s room . [His]2889-her brother door being shut , [she]91-louisa softly opened it and spoke to [him]2889-her brother , approaching [his]2889-her brother bed with a noiseless step . [She]91-louisa kneeled down beside it , passed [her]91-louisa arm over [his]2889-her brother neck , and drew [his]2889-her brother face to [hers]91-louisa . [She]91-louisa knew that [he]2889-her brother only feigned to be asleep , but [she]91-louisa said nothing to [him]2889-her brother . [He]2889-her brother started by and by as if [he]2889-her brother were just then awakened , and asked who that was , and what was the matter ? ‘[75-tom] [Tom]75-tom , have [you]75-tom anything to tell [me]0-i ? If ever [you]75-tom loved [me]0-i in [your]75-tom life , and have anything concealed from every one besides , tell it to [me]0-i . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t know what [you]75-tom mean , [Loo]100-loo . [You]75-tom have been dreaming . ’ ‘[0-i] [[My]0-i dear brother]1818-my dear brother : ’ [she]91-louisa laid [her]91-louisa head down on [his]1818-my dear brother pillow , and [her]91-louisa hair flowed over [him]1818-my dear brother as if [she]91-louisa would hide [him]1818-my dear brother from every one but [herself]91-louisa : ‘[0-i] is there nothing that [you]75-tom have to tell [me]0-i ? Is there nothing [you]75-tom can tell [me]0-i if [you]75-tom will ? [You]75-tom can tell [me]0-i nothing that will change [me]0-i . O [Tom]75-tom , tell [me]0-i the truth ! ’ ‘[75-tom] [I]0-i do n’t know what [you]75-tom mean , [Loo]100-loo ! ’ ‘[75-tom] As [you]75-tom lie here alone , [[my]0-i dear]3090-my dear , in the melancholy night , so [you]75-tom must lie somewhere one night , when even [I]0-i , if [I]0-i am living then , shall have left [you]75-tom . As [I]0-i am here beside [you]75-tom , barefoot , unclothed , undistinguishable in darkness , so must [I]0-i lie through all the night of [my]0-i decay , until [I]0-i am dust . In the name of that time , [Tom]75-tom , tell [me]0-i the truth now ! ’ ‘[75-tom] What is it [you]75-tom want to know ? ’ ‘[75-tom] [You]75-tom may be certain ; ’ in the energy of [her]4312-her love [she]4312-her took [him]75-tom to [her]4312-her bosom as if [he]75-tom were [a child]339-a child ; ‘[75-tom] that [I]0-i will not reproach [you]75-tom . [You]75-tom may be certain that [I]0-i will be compassionate and true to [you]75-tom . [You]75-tom may be certain that [I]0-i will save [you]75-tom at whatever cost . O [Tom]75-tom , have [you]75-tom nothing to tell [me]0-i ? [Whisper]192-whisper very softly . Say only “ yes , ” and [I]0-i shall understand [you]75-tom ! ’ [She]192-whisper turned [her]192-whisper ear to [his]75-tom lips , but [he]75-tom remained doggedly silent . ‘[75-tom] Not a word , [Tom]75-tom ? ’ ‘[75-tom] How can [I]0-i say Yes , or how can [I]0-i say No , when [I]0-i do n’t know what [you]75-tom mean ? [Loo]100-loo , [you]75-tom are [a brave , kind girl]1820-a brave , kind girl , worthy [I]0-i begin to think of [a better brother]1821-a better brother than [I]0-i am . But [I]0-i have nothing more to say . Go to bed , go to bed . ’ ‘[75-tom] [You]75-tom are tired , ’ [she]100-loo whispered presently , more in [her]100-loo usual way . ‘[75-tom] Yes , [I]0-i am quite tired out . ’ ‘[75-tom] [You]75-tom have been so hurried and disturbed to - day . Have any fresh discoveries been made ? ’ ‘[75-tom] Only those [you]75-tom have heard of , from — [him]75-tom . ’ ‘[75-tom] [Tom]75-tom , have [you]75-tom said to [any one]2994-any one that [we]1823-we made a visit to [those people]1824-those people , and that [we]1823-we saw [those three together]1825-those three together ? ’ ‘[75-tom] No . Did n’t [you]75-tom [yourself]75-tom particularly ask [me]0-i to keep it quiet when [you]75-tom asked [me]0-i to go [there]412-there with [you]75-tom ? ’ ‘[75-tom] Yes . But [I]0-i did not know then what was going to happen . ’ ‘[0-i] Nor [I]0-i neither . How could [I]0-i ? ’ [He]75-tom was very quick upon [her]100-loo with this retort . ‘[0-i] Ought [I]0-i to say , after what has happened , ’ said [[his]75-tom sister]644-his sister , standing by the bed — [she]644-his sister had gradually withdrawn [herself]644-his sister and risen , ‘[0-i] that [I]0-i made that visit ? Should [I]0-i say so ? Must [I]0-i say so ? ’ ‘[0-i] Good Heavens , [Loo]100-loo , ’ returned [[her]644-his sister brother]2889-her brother , ‘[100-loo] [you]100-loo are not in the habit of asking [my]0-i advice . Say what [you]100-loo like . If [you]100-loo keep it to [yourself]100-loo , [I]0-i shall keep it to _ [my_self]1827-my_self . If [you]100-loo disclose it , there ’s an end of it . ’ It was too dark for either to see [the other]1294-the other ’s face ; but [each]337-each seemed very attentive , and to consider before speaking . ‘[75-tom] [Tom]75-tom , do [you]75-tom believe [the man [I]0-i gave the money to]1828-the man i gave the money to , is really implicated in this crime ? ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t know . [I]0-i do n’t see why [he]1828-the man i gave the money to should n’t be . ’ ‘[0-i] [He]1828-the man i gave the money to seemed to [me]0-i [an honest man]1829-an honest man . ’ ‘[1828-the man i gave the money to] [Another person]1830-another person may seem to [you]75-tom dishonest , and yet not be so . ’ There was a pause , for [he]0-i had hesitated and stopped . ‘[1830-another person] In short , ’ resumed [Tom]75-tom , as if [he]0-i had made up [his]0-i mind , ‘[1830-another person] if [you]75-tom come to that , perhaps [I]0-i was so far from being altogether in [his]1828-the man i gave the money to favour , that [I]0-i took [him]1828-the man i gave the money to outside the door to tell [him]1828-the man i gave the money to quietly , that [I]0-i thought [he]1828-the man i gave the money to might consider [himself]1828-the man i gave the money to very well off to get such a windfall as [he]1828-the man i gave the money to had got from [[my]0-i sister]664-my sister , and that [I]0-i hoped [he]1828-the man i gave the money to would make good use of it . [You]75-tom remember whether [I]0-i took [him]1828-the man i gave the money to out or not . [I]0-i say nothing against [the man]3010-the man ; [he]1828-the man i gave the money to may be [a very good fellow]3878-a very good fellow , for anything [I]0-i know ; [I]0-i hope [he]1828-the man i gave the money to is . ’ ‘[1828-the man i gave the money to] Was [he]1828-the man i gave the money to offended by what [you]0-i said ? ’ ‘[1828-the man i gave the money to] No , [he]1828-the man i gave the money to took it pretty well ; [he]1828-the man i gave the money to was civil enough . Where are [you]0-i , [Loo]100-loo ? ’ [He]0-i sat up in bed and kissed [her]100-loo . ‘[100-loo] Good night , [[my]0-i dear]3090-my dear , good night . ’ ‘[100-loo] [You]0-i have nothing more to tell [me]0-i ? ’ ‘[0-i] No . What should [I]0-i have ? [You]0-i would n’t have [me]0-i tell [you]0-i a lie ! ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i would n’t have [you]0-i do that to - night , [Tom]75-tom , of all the nights in [your]0-i life ; many and much happier as [I]0-i hope they will be . ’ ‘[0-i] Thank [you]0-i , [[my]0-i dear]3090-my dear [Loo]100-loo . [I]0-i am so tired , that [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i wonder [I]0-i do n’t say anything to get to sleep . Go to bed , go to bed . ’ Kissing [her]3090-my dear again , [he]0-i turned round , drew the coverlet over [his]0-i head , and lay as still as if that time had come by which [she]3090-my dear had adjured [him]0-i . [She]3090-my dear stood for some time at the bedside before [she]3090-my dear slowly moved away . [She]3090-my dear stopped at the door , looked back when [she]3090-my dear had opened it , and asked [him]0-i if [he]0-i had called [her]3090-my dear ? But [he]0-i lay still , and [she]3090-my dear softly closed the door and returned to [[her]3090-my dear room]4309-her room . Then [the wretched boy]4319-the wretched boy looked cautiously up and found [her]3090-my dear gone , crept out of bed , fastened [his]0-i door , and threw [himself]0-i upon [his]0-i pillow again : tearing [his]0-i hair , morosely crying , grudgingly loving [her]3090-my dear , hatefully but impenitently spurning [himself]0-i , and no less hatefully and unprofitably spurning all the good in [the world]2766-the world . CHAPTER IX HEARING THE LAST OF IT [MRS . SPARSIT]92-mr. bounderby , lying by to recover the tone of [her]3090-my dear nerves in [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s retreat , kept such a sharp look - out , night and day , under [her]3090-my dear Coriolanian eyebrows , that [her]3090-my dear eyes , like a couple of lighthouses on [an iron - bound coast]4321-an iron - bound coast , might have warned [all prudent mariners]4322-all prudent mariners from that bold rock [her]3090-my dear Roman nose and [the dark and craggy region in [its]92-mr. bounderby neighbourhood]4323-the dark and craggy region in its neighbourhood , but for the placidity of [her]3090-my dear manner . Although it was hard to believe that [her]3090-my dear retiring for the night could be anything but a form , so severely wide awake were those classical eyes of [hers]3090-my dear , and so impossible did it seem that [her]3090-my dear rigid nose could yield to any relaxing influence , yet [her]3090-my dear manner of sitting , smoothing [her]3090-my dear uncomfortable , not to say , gritty mittens ( they were constructed of a cool fabric like a meat - safe ) , or of ambling to unknown places of destination with [her]3090-my dear foot in [her]3090-my dear cotton stirrup , was so perfectly serene , that [most observers]4324-most observers would have been constrained to suppose [her]3090-my dear a dove , embodied by some freak of nature , in the earthly tabernacle of a bird of the hook - beaked order . [She]3090-my dear was [a most wonderful woman]4325-a most wonderful woman for prowling about [the house]2875-the house . How [she]3090-my dear got from story to story was a mystery beyond solution . [A lady so decorous in [herself]3090-my dear]4327-a lady so decorous in herself , and so highly connected , was not to be suspected of dropping over the banisters or sliding down them , yet [her]3090-my dear extraordinary facility of locomotion suggested the wild idea . Another noticeable circumstance in [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was , that [she]3090-my dear was never hurried . [She]3090-my dear would shoot with consummate velocity from the roof to [the hall]2881-the hall , yet would be in full possession of [her]3090-my dear breath and dignity on the moment of [her]3090-my dear arrival [there]412-there . Neither was [she]3090-my dear ever seen by human vision to go at a great pace . [She]3090-my dear took very kindly to [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , and had some pleasant conversation with [him]162-mr. harthouse soon after [her]3090-my dear arrival . [She]3090-my dear made [him]162-mr. harthouse [her]3090-my dear stately curtsey in [the garden]4227-the garden , one morning before breakfast . ‘[100-loo] It appears but yesterday , [sir]2713-sir , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[0-i] that [I]0-i had the honour of receiving [you]2713-sir at [the Bank]3460-the bank , when [you]2713-sir were so good as to wish to be made acquainted with [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s address . ’ ‘[92-mr. bounderby] An occasion , [I]0-i am sure , not to be forgotten by [myself]0-i in the course of Ages , ’ said [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , inclining [his]162-mr. harthouse head to [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby with the most indolent of all possible airs . ‘[0-i] [We]1838-we live in a singular world , [sir]2713-sir , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[2713-sir] [I]0-i have had the honour , by a coincidence of which [I]0-i am proud , to have made a remark , similar in effect , though not so epigrammatically expressed . ’ ‘[0-i] A singular world , [I]0-i would say , [sir]2713-sir , ’ pursued [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ; after acknowledging the compliment with a drooping of [her]127-miss gradgrind dark eyebrows , not altogether so mild in its expression as [her]127-miss gradgrind voice was in its dulcet tones ; ‘[0-i] as regards the intimacies [we]1838-we form at one time , with [individuals]1841-individuals [we]1838-we were quite ignorant of , at another . [I]0-i recall , [sir]2713-sir , that on that occasion [you]2713-sir went so far as to say [you]2713-sir were actually apprehensive of [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind . ’ ‘[2713-sir] [Your]2713-sir memory does [me]0-i more honour than [my]0-i insignificance deserves . [I]0-i availed [myself]0-i of [your]2713-sir obliging hints to correct [my]0-i timidity , and it is unnecessary to add that they were perfectly accurate .
