[Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s talent for — in fact for anything requiring accuracy — with a combination of strength of mind — and [Family]193-family — is too habitually developed to admit of any question . ’ [He]2713-sir was almost falling asleep over this compliment ; it took [him]2713-sir so long to get through , and [his]2713-sir mind wandered so much in the course of its execution . ‘[2713-sir] [You]2713-sir found [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind — [I]0-i really can not call [her]127-miss gradgrind [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ; it ’s very absurd of [me]0-i — as youthful as [I]0-i described [her]127-miss gradgrind ? ’ asked [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , sweetly . ‘[0-i] [You]2713-sir drew [her]127-miss gradgrind portrait perfectly , ’ said [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse . ‘[2713-sir] Presented [her]127-miss gradgrind dead image . ’ ‘[127-miss gradgrind] Very engaging , [sir]2713-sir , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , causing [her]127-miss gradgrind mittens slowly to revolve over [one another]2898-one another . ‘[2713-sir] Highly so . ’ ‘[2713-sir] It used to be considered , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[2713-sir] that [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind was wanting in animation , but [I]0-i confess [she]127-miss gradgrind appears to [me]0-i considerably and strikingly improved in that respect . Ay , and indeed here _ is _ [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ! ’ cried [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , nodding [her]127-miss gradgrind head a great many times , as if [she]127-miss gradgrind had been talking and thinking of [no one else]947-no one else . ‘[92-mr. bounderby] How do [you]92-mr. bounderby find [yourself]92-mr. bounderby this morning , [sir]2713-sir ? Pray let [us]1845-us see [you]92-mr. bounderby cheerful , [sir]2713-sir . ’ Now , these persistent assuagements of [his]92-mr. bounderby misery , and lightenings of [his]92-mr. bounderby load , had by this time begun to have the effect of making [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby softer than usual towards [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , and harder than usual to [most other people from [[his]92-mr. bounderby wife]972-his wife downward]4333-most other people from his wife downward . So , when [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby said with forced lightness of heart , ‘[2713-sir] [You]2713-sir want [your]2713-sir breakfast , [sir]2713-sir , but [I]0-i dare say [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind will soon be here to preside at the table , ’ [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby replied , ‘[127-miss gradgrind] If [I]0-i waited to be taken care of by [[my]0-i wife]1090-my wife , [ma’am]350-ma’am , [I]0-i believe [you]2713-sir know pretty well [I]0-i should wait till Doomsday , so [I]0-i ’ll trouble _ [you]2713-sir _ to take charge of the teapot . ’ [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby complied , and assumed [her]2713-sir old position at table . This again made [the excellent woman]4335-the excellent woman vastly sentimental . [She]2713-sir was so humble withal , that when [Louisa]91-louisa appeared , [she]2713-sir rose , protesting [she]2713-sir never could think of sitting in that place under existing circumstances , often as [she]2713-sir had had the honour of making [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s breakfast , before [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind — [she]2713-sir begged pardon , [she]2713-sir meant to say [Miss Bounderby]194-miss bounderby — [she]2713-sir hoped to be excused , but [she]2713-sir really could not get it right yet , though [she]2713-sir trusted to become familiar with it by and by — had assumed [her]2713-sir present position . It was only ( [she]2713-sir observed ) because [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind happened to be a little late , and [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s time was so very precious , and [she]2713-sir knew it of old to be so essential that [he]92-mr. bounderby should breakfast to the moment , that [she]2713-sir had taken the liberty of complying with [his]92-mr. bounderby request ; long as [his]92-mr. bounderby will had been a law to [her]2713-sir . ‘[0-i] There ! Stop where [you]1850-you are , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[350-ma’am] stop where [you]1850-you are ! [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby will be very glad to be relieved of the trouble , [I]0-i believe . ’ ‘[0-i] Do n’t say that , [sir]2713-sir , ’ returned [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , almost with severity , ‘[2713-sir] because that is very unkind to [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . And to be unkind is not to be [you]2713-sir , [sir]2713-sir . ’ ‘[2713-sir] [You]1850-you may set [your]1850-you mind at rest , [ma’am.—You]1850-you can take it very quietly , ca n’t [you]1850-you , [Loo]100-loo ? ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , in a blustering way to [[his]92-mr. bounderby wife]972-his wife . ‘[1850-you] Of course . It is of no moment . Why should it be of any importance to [me]0-i ? ’ ‘[350-ma’am] Why should it be of any importance to [any one]2994-any one , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , [ma’am]350-ma’am ? ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , swelling with a sense of slight . ‘[92-mr. bounderby] [You]350-ma’am attach too much importance to these things , [ma’am]350-ma’am . By [George]71-george , [you]350-ma’am ’ll be corrupted in some of [your]350-ma’am notions here . [You]350-ma’am are old - fashioned , [ma’am]350-ma’am . [You]350-ma’am are behind [[Tom Gradgrind]75-tom ’s children]1858-tom gradgrind ’s children ’s time . ’ ‘[350-ma’am] What is the matter with [you]350-ma’am ? ’ asked [Louisa]91-louisa , coldly surprised . ‘[350-ma’am] What has given [you]350-ma’am offence ? ’ ‘[350-ma’am] Offence ! ’ repeated [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[350-ma’am] Do [you]350-ma’am suppose if there was any offence given [me]0-i , [I]0-i should n’t name it , and request to have it corrected ? [I]0-i am [a straightforward man]1859-a straightforward man , [I]0-i believe . [I]0-i do n’t go beating about for side - winds . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i suppose [no one]545-no one ever had occasion to think [you]350-ma’am too diffident , or too delicate , ’ [Louisa]91-louisa answered [him]350-ma’am composedly : ‘[0-i] [I]0-i have never made that objection to [you]350-ma’am , either as [a child]339-a child or as [a woman]892-a woman . [I]0-i do n’t understand what [you]350-ma’am would have . ’ ‘[350-ma’am] Have ? ’ returned [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘[350-ma’am] Nothing . Otherwise , do n’t [you]350-ma’am , [Loo Bounderby]100-loo , know thoroughly well that [I]0-i , [Josiah Bounderby]96-josiah bounderby of [Coketown]4-coketown , would have it ? ’ [She]91-louisa looked at [him]350-ma’am , as [he]350-ma’am struck the table and made the teacups ring , with a proud colour in [her]91-louisa face that was a new change , [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse thought . ‘[350-ma’am] [You]350-ma’am are incomprehensible this morning , ’ said [Louisa]91-louisa . ‘[350-ma’am] Pray take no further trouble to explain [yourself]350-ma’am . [I]0-i am not curious to know [your]350-ma’am meaning . What does it matter ? ’ Nothing more was said on this theme , and [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse was soon idly gay on indifferent subjects . But from this day , the Sparsit action upon [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby threw [Louisa]91-louisa and [James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse more together , and strengthened the dangerous alienation from [[her]91-louisa husband]2861-her husband and confidence against [him]350-ma’am with another , into which [she]91-louisa had fallen by degrees so fine that [she]91-louisa could not retrace them if [she]91-louisa tried . But whether [she]91-louisa ever tried or no , lay hidden in [her]91-louisa own closed heart . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was so much affected on this particular occasion , that , assisting [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby to [his]92-mr. bounderby hat after breakfast , and being then alone with [him]92-mr. bounderby in [the hall]2881-the hall , [she]91-louisa imprinted a chaste kiss upon [his]92-mr. bounderby hand , murmured ‘[1863-my benefactor] [[My]0-i benefactor]1863-my benefactor ! ’ and retired , overwhelmed with grief . Yet it is an indubitable fact , within the cognizance of this history , that five minutes after [he]92-mr. bounderby had left [the house]2875-the house in the self - same hat , [the same descendant of [the Scadgerses]195-the scadgerses and connexion by matrimony of [the Powlers]190-the powlers]4340-the same descendant of the scadgerses and connexion by matrimony of the powlers , shook [her]91-louisa right - hand mitten at [his]92-mr. bounderby portrait , made a contemptuous grimace at that work of art , and said ‘[1863-my benefactor] Serve [you]1864-you right , [you]1864-you Noodle , and [I]0-i am glad of it . ’ [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby had not been long gone , when [Bitzer]77-bitzer appeared . [Bitzer]77-bitzer had come down by [train]4341-train , shrieking and rattling over the long line of arches that bestrode [the wild country of past and present coal - pits]4342-the wild country of past and present coal - pits , with an express from [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge . It was a hasty note to inform [Louisa]91-louisa that [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind lay very ill . [She]94-mrs. gradgrind had never been well within [[her]94-mrs. gradgrind daughter]4343-her daughter ’s knowledge ; but , [she]94-mrs. gradgrind had declined within the last few days , had continued sinking all through the night , and was now as nearly dead , as [her]94-mrs. gradgrind limited capacity of being in any state that implied the ghost of an intention to get out of it , allowed . Accompanied by [the lightest of [porters]4345-porters]4344-the lightest of porters , fit colourless servitor at [Death]196-death ’s door when [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind knocked , [Louisa]91-louisa rumbled to [Coketown]4-coketown , over [the coal - pits]4346-the coal - pits past and present , and was whirled into its smoky jaws . [She]91-louisa dismissed [the messenger]4347-the messenger to [his]4347-the messenger own devices , and rode away to [[her]91-louisa old home]4348-her old home . [She]91-louisa had seldom been [there]412-there since [her]91-louisa marriage . [[Her]91-louisa father]335-her father was usually sifting and sifting at [[his]335-her father parliamentary cinder - heap in [London]8-london]4351-his parliamentary cinder - heap in london ( without being observed to turn up many precious articles among the rubbish ) , and was still hard at it in [the national dust - yard]4352-the national dust - yard . [[Her]91-louisa mother]670-her mother had taken it rather as a disturbance than otherwise , to be visited , as [she]670-her mother reclined upon [her]670-her mother sofa ; [young people]4354-young people , [Louisa]91-louisa felt [herself]91-louisa all unfit for ; [Sissy]76-sissy [she]91-louisa had never softened to again , since the night when [the stroller ’s child]4355-the stroller ’s child had raised [her]4355-the stroller ’s child eyes to look at [[Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s intended wife]4356-mr. bounderby ’s intended wife . [She]91-louisa had no inducements to go back , and had rarely gone . Neither , as [she]91-louisa approached [[her]91-louisa old home]4348-her old home now , did any of the best influences of [old home]4358-old home descend upon [her]91-louisa . The dreams of childhood — its airy fables ; its graceful , beautiful , humane , impossible adornments of [the world beyond]4359-the world beyond : so good to be believed in once , so good to be remembered when outgrown , for then the least among [them]4354-young people rises to the stature of [a great Charity in the heart]4360-a great charity in the heart , suffering [little children]4361-little children to come into the midst of it , and to keep with [their]4361-little children pure hands a garden in the stony ways of [this world]961-this world , wherein it were better for [all the children of [Adam]42-adam]4363-all the children of adam that [they]4363-all the children of adam should oftener sun [themselves]4363-all the children of adam , simple and trustful , and not worldly - wise — what had [she]91-louisa to do with these ? Remembrances of how [she]91-louisa had journeyed to the little that [she]91-louisa knew , by the enchanted roads of what [she]91-louisa and [millions of [innocent creatures]4365-innocent creatures had hoped and imagined]4364-millions of innocent creatures had hoped and imagined ; of how , first coming upon [Reason]197-reason through the tender light of Fancy , [she]91-louisa had seen [it]4366-it [a beneficent god]4367-a beneficent god , deferring to gods as great as itself ; not a grim Idol , cruel and cold , with its victims bound hand to foot , and [its big dumb shape set up with a sightless stare , never to be moved by anything but so many calculated tons of leverage]4368-its big dumb shape set up with a sightless stare , never to be moved by anything but so many calculated tons of leverage — what had [she]91-louisa to do with these ? [Her]91-louisa remembrances of [home]336-home and childhood were remembrances of the drying up of every spring and fountain in [her]91-louisa young heart as it gushed out . The golden waters were not there . They were flowing for the fertilization of the land where grapes are gathered from thorns , and figs from thistles . [She]91-louisa went , with a heavy , hardened kind of sorrow upon [her]91-louisa , into [the house]2875-the house and into [[[her]91-louisa mother]670-her mother ’s room]4372-her mother ’s room . Since the time of [her]91-louisa leaving [home]336-home , [Sissy]76-sissy had lived with [the rest of [the family]1017-the family]4374-the rest of the family on equal terms . [Sissy]76-sissy was at [[her]76-sissy mother]670-her mother ’s side ; and [Jane]99-jane , [[her]76-sissy sister]4377-her sister , now ten or twelve years old , was in [the room]2859-the room . There was great trouble before it could be made known to [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind that [[her]94-mrs. gradgrind eldest child]4379-her eldest child was [there]412-there . [She]91-louisa reclined , propped up , from mere habit , on a couch : as nearly in [her]91-louisa old usual attitude , as anything so helpless could be kept in . [She]91-louisa had positively refused to take to [[her]91-louisa bed]4381-her bed ; on the ground that if [she]91-louisa did , [she]91-louisa would never hear the last of it . [Her]91-louisa feeble voice sounded so far away in [her]91-louisa bundle of shawls , and the sound of another voice addressing [her]91-louisa seemed to take such a long time in getting down to [her]91-louisa ears , that [she]91-louisa might have been lying at the bottom of a well . [The poor lady]4382-the poor lady was nearer [Truth]198-truth than [she]91-louisa ever had been : which had much to do with it . On being told that [Mrs. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby was [there]412-there , [she]91-louisa replied , at cross - purposes , that [she]91-louisa had never called [him]92-mr. bounderby by that name since [he]92-mr. bounderby married [Louisa]91-louisa ; that pending [her]91-louisa choice of an objectionable name , [she]91-louisa had called [him]92-mr. bounderby [J]199-j ; and that [she]91-louisa could not at present depart from that regulation , not being yet provided with a permanent substitute . [Louisa]91-louisa had sat by [her]91-louisa for some minutes , and had spoken to [her]91-louisa often , before [she]91-louisa arrived at a clear understanding who it was . [She]91-louisa then seemed to come to it all at once . ‘[0-i] Well , [[my]0-i dear]3090-my dear , ’ said [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind , ‘[0-i] and [I]0-i hope [you]3090-my dear are going on satisfactorily to [yourself]3090-my dear . It was all [[your]3090-my dear father]2725-your father ’s doing . [He]2725-your father set [his]2725-your father heart upon it . And [he]2725-your father ought to know . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i want to hear of [you]3090-my dear , [mother]3242-mother ; not of [myself]0-i . ’ ‘[3090-my dear] [You]3090-my dear want to hear of [me]0-i , [[my]0-i dear]3090-my dear ? That ’s something new , [I]0-i am sure , when [anybody]2845-anybody wants to hear of [me]0-i . Not at all well , [Louisa]91-louisa . Very faint and giddy . ’ ‘[91-louisa] Are [you]3090-my dear in pain , [dear mother]1870-dear mother ? ’ ‘[91-louisa] [I]0-i think there ’s a pain somewhere in [the room]2859-the room , ’ said [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind , ‘[0-i] but [I]0-i could n’t positively say that [I]0-i have got it . ’ After this strange speech , [she]3090-my dear lay silent for some time . [Louisa]91-louisa , holding [her]91-louisa hand , could feel no pulse ; but kissing it , could see a slight thin thread of life in fluttering motion . ‘[3090-my dear] [You]3090-my dear very seldom see [[your]3090-my dear sister]2822-your sister , ’ said [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind . ‘[3090-my dear] [She]2822-your sister grows like [you]3090-my dear . [I]0-i wish [you]3090-my dear would look at [her]2822-your sister . [Sissy]76-sissy , bring [her]2822-your sister here . ’ [She]91-louisa was brought , and stood with [her]91-louisa hand in [[her]91-louisa sister]4377-her sister ’s . [Louisa]91-louisa had observed [her]91-louisa with [her]91-louisa arm round [Sissy]76-sissy ’s neck , and [she]91-louisa felt the difference of this approach . ‘[76-sissy] Do [you]3090-my dear see the likeness , [Louisa]91-louisa ? ’ ‘[3242-mother] Yes , [mother]3242-mother . [I]0-i should think [her]2822-your sister like [me]0-i . But — ’ ‘[76-sissy] Eh ! Yes , [I]0-i always say so , ’ [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind cried , with unexpected quickness . ‘[0-i] And that reminds [me]0-i . [I]0-i — [I]0-i want to speak to [you]91-louisa , [[my]0-i dear]3090-my dear . [Sissy]76-sissy , [[my]0-i good girl]1875-my good girl , leave [us]1876-us alone a minute . ’ [Louisa]91-louisa had relinquished the hand : had thought that [[her]91-louisa sister]4377-her sister ’s was a better and brighter face than [hers]91-louisa had ever been : had seen in it , not without a rising feeling of resentment , even in [that place]4386-that place and at that time , something of the gentleness of the other face in [the room]2859-the room ; [the sweet face with the trusting eyes , made paler than watching and sympathy made it , by the rich dark hair]4388-the sweet face with the trusting eyes , made paler than watching and sympathy made it , by the rich dark hair . Left alone with [[her]91-louisa mother]670-her mother , [Louisa]91-louisa saw [her]4377-her sister lying with an awful lull upon [her]4377-her sister face , like [one who was floating away upon some great water , all resistance over , content to be carried down]4390-one who was floating away upon some great water , all resistance over , content to be carried down [the stream]4391-the stream . [She]91-louisa put the shadow of a hand to [her]91-louisa lips again , and recalled [her]4377-her sister . ‘[76-sissy] [You]0-i were going to speak to [me]0-i , [mother]3242-mother . ’ ‘[3242-mother] Eh ? Yes , to be sure , [[my]0-i dear]3090-my dear . [You]3090-my dear know [[your]3090-my dear father]2725-your father is almost always away now , and therefore [I]0-i must write to [him]2725-your father about it . ’ ‘[3242-mother] About what , [mother]3242-mother ? Do n’t be troubled . About what ? ’ ‘[3090-my dear] [You]3090-my dear must remember , [[my]0-i dear]3090-my dear , that whenever [I]0-i have said anything , on any subject , [I]0-i have never heard the last of it : and consequently , that [I]0-i have long left off saying anything . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i can hear [you]3242-mother , [mother]3242-mother . ’ But , it was only by dint of bending down to [her]3242-mother ear , and at the same time attentively watching the lips as they moved , that [she]3242-mother could link such faint and broken sounds into any chain of connexion . ‘[3242-mother] [You]3090-my dear learnt a great deal , [Louisa]91-louisa , and so did [[your]3090-my dear brother]3871-your brother . Ologies of all kinds from morning to night . If there is any Ology left , of any description , that has not been worn to rags in [this house]3165-this house , all [I]0-i can say is , [I]0-i hope [I]0-i shall never hear its name . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i can hear [you]3242-mother , [mother]3242-mother , when [you]3242-mother have strength to go on . ’ This , to keep [her]3242-mother from floating away . ‘[3242-mother] But there is something — not an Ology at all — that [[your]3090-my dear father]2725-your father has missed , or forgotten , [Louisa]91-louisa . [I]0-i do n’t know what it is . [I]0-i have often sat with [Sissy]76-sissy near [me]0-i , and thought about it . [I]0-i shall never get its name now . But [[your]3090-my dear father]2725-your father may . It makes [me]0-i restless . [I]0-i want to write to [him]2725-your father , to find out for [God]126-god ’s sake , what it is . Give [me]0-i a pen , give [me]0-i a pen . ’ Even the power of restlessness was gone , except from the poor head , which could just turn from side to side . [She]3242-mother fancied , however , that [her]3242-mother request had been complied with , and that the pen [she]3242-mother could not have held was in [her]3242-mother hand . It matters little what figures of wonderful no - meaning [she]3242-mother began to trace upon [her]3242-mother wrappers . The hand soon stopped in the midst of them ; the light that had always been feeble and dim behind the weak transparency , went out ; and even [Mrs. Gradgrind]94-mrs. gradgrind , emerged from the shadow in which [man]2923-man walketh and disquieteth [himself]2923-man in vain , took upon [her]94-mrs. gradgrind the dread solemnity of [the sages]4393-the sages and [patriarchs]4394-patriarchs . CHAPTER X [MRS . SPARSIT]92-mr. bounderby ’S[92-mr. bounderby] STAIRCASE [MRS . SPARSIT]92-mr. bounderby ’S nerves being slow to recover [their]4395-their tone , [the worthy woman]4396-the worthy woman made a stay of some weeks in duration at [[Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby ’s retreat]4397-mr. bounderby ’s retreat , where , notwithstanding [her]4396-the worthy woman anchorite turn of mind based upon [her]4396-the worthy woman becoming consciousness of [her]4396-the worthy woman altered station , [she]4396-the worthy woman resigned [herself]4396-the worthy woman with noble fortitude to lodging , as one may say , in clover , and feeding on the fat of [the land]1392-the land . During the whole term of this recess from the guardianship of [the Bank]3460-the bank , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was a pattern of consistency ; continuing to take such pity on [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby to [his]92-mr. bounderby face , as is rarely taken on [man]2923-man , and to call [his]92-mr. bounderby portrait a Noodle to _ its _ face , with the greatest acrimony and contempt . [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , having got it into [his]92-mr. bounderby explosive composition that [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was [a highly superior woman]4401-a highly superior woman to perceive that [he]92-mr. bounderby had that general cross upon [him]92-mr. bounderby in [his]92-mr. bounderby deserts ( for [he]92-mr. bounderby had not yet settled what it was ) , and further that [Louisa]91-louisa would have objected to [her]91-louisa as [a frequent visitor]4402-a frequent visitor if it had comported with [his]92-mr. bounderby greatness that [she]91-louisa should object to anything [he]92-mr. bounderby chose to do , resolved not to lose sight of [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby easily . So when [her]1888-her nerves were strung up to the pitch of again consuming sweetbreads in solitude , [he]92-mr. bounderby said to [her]1888-her at the dinner - table , on the day before [her]1888-her departure , ‘[92-mr. bounderby] [I]0-i tell [you]1888-her what , [ma’am]350-ma’am ; [you]1888-her shall come down here of a Saturday , while the fine weather lasts , and stay till Monday . ’ To which [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby returned , in effect , though not of the Mahomedan persuasion : ‘[350-ma’am] To hear is to obey . ’ Now , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was not [a poetical woman]4403-a poetical woman ; but [she]1888-her took an idea in the nature of an allegorical fancy , into [her]1888-her head . Much watching of [Louisa]91-louisa , and much consequent observation of [her]91-louisa impenetrable demeanour , which keenly whetted and sharpened [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s edge , must have given [her]1888-her as it were a lift , in the way of inspiration . [She]1888-her erected in [her]1888-her mind a mighty Staircase , with a dark pit of shame and ruin at the bottom ; and down [those stairs]4404-those stairs , from day to day and hour to hour , [she]1888-her saw [Louisa]91-louisa coming . It became the business of [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s life , to look up at [her]1888-her staircase , and to watch [Louisa]91-louisa coming down . Sometimes slowly , sometimes quickly , sometimes several steps at one bout , sometimes stopping , never turning back . If [she]1888-her had once turned back , it might have been the death of [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby in spleen and grief . [She]1888-her had been descending steadily , to the day , and on the day , when [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby issued the weekly invitation recorded above . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was in good spirits , and inclined to be conversational . ‘[350-ma’am] And pray , [sir]2713-sir , ’ said [she]1888-her , ‘[2713-sir] if [I]0-i may venture to ask a question appertaining to any subject on which [you]2713-sir show reserve — which is indeed hardy in [me]0-i , for [I]0-i well know [you]2713-sir have a reason for everything [you]2713-sir do — have [you]2713-sir received intelligence respecting the robbery ? ’ ‘[350-ma’am] Why , [ma’am]350-ma’am , no ; not yet . Under the circumstances , [I]0-i did n’t expect it yet . [Rome]43-rome was n’t built in a day , [ma’am]350-ma’am . ’ ‘[350-ma’am] Very true , [sir]2713-sir , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , shaking [her]350-ma’am head . ‘[350-ma’am] Nor yet in a week , [ma’am]350-ma’am . ’ ‘[350-ma’am] No , indeed , [sir]2713-sir , ’ returned [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , with a gentle melancholy upon [her]350-ma’am . ‘[2713-sir] In a similar manner , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’ said [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[2713-sir] [I]0-i can wait , [you]350-ma’am know . If [Romulus]200-romulus and [Remus]201-remus could wait , [Josiah Bounderby]96-josiah bounderby can wait . [They]1897-they were better off in [their]1897-they youth than [I]0-i was , however . [They]1897-they had a she - wolf for [a nurse]1898-a nurse ; [I]0-i had only a she - wolf for [a grandmother]1899-a grandmother . [She]1900-she did n’t give any milk , [ma’am]350-ma’am ; [she]1900-she gave bruises . [She]1900-she was a regular [Alderney]44-alderney at that . ’ ‘[1900-she] Ah ! ’ [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby sighed and shuddered . ‘[1900-she] No , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’ continued [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[1900-she] [I]0-i have not heard anything more about it . [It]1903-it ’s in hand , though ; and [young Tom]75-tom , who rather sticks to business at present — something new for [him]75-tom ; [he]75-tom had n’t the schooling _ [I]0-i _ had — is helping . [My]0-i injunction is , Keep it quiet , and let it seem to blow over . Do what [you]350-ma’am like under the rose , but do n’t give a sign of what [you]350-ma’am ’re about ; or half a hundred of [’em]4405-’em[350-ma’am] will combine together and get [this fellow who has bolted , out of reach for good]1904-this fellow who has bolted , out of reach for good . Keep it quiet , and [the thieves]1905-the thieves will grow in confidence by little and little , and [we]1906-we shall have ’em . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Very sagacious indeed , [sir]2713-sir , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ Very interesting . [The old woman]901-the old woman [you]2713-sir mentioned , [sir]2713-sir — ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ [The old woman [I]92-mr. bounderby mentioned]4409-the old woman i mentioned , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , cutting the matter short , as it was nothing to boast about , ‘ is not laid hold of ; but , [she]901-the old woman may take [her]901-the old woman oath [she]901-the old woman will be , if that is any satisfaction to [her]901-the old woman villainous old mind . In the mean time , [ma’am]350-ma’am , [I]92-mr. bounderby am of opinion , if [you]350-ma’am ask [me]92-mr. bounderby [my]92-mr. bounderby opinion , that the less [she]901-the old woman is talked about , the better . ’[92-mr. bounderby] The same evening , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , in [her]1907-her chamber window , resting from [her]1907-her packing operations , looked towards [[her]1907-her great staircase]1908-her great staircase and saw [Louisa]91-louisa still descending . [She]91-louisa sat by [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , in [an alcove in [the garden]4227-the garden]1909-an alcove in the garden , talking very low ; [he]162-mr. harthouse stood leaning over [her]91-louisa , as [they]1911-they whispered together , and [his]162-mr. harthouse face almost touched [her]91-louisa hair . ‘ If not quite ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , straining [her]1907-her hawk ’s eyes to the utmost . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was too distant to hear a word of [their]1911-they discourse , or even to know that [they]1911-they were speaking softly , otherwise than from the expression of [their]1911-they figures ; but what [they]1911-they said was this : ‘ [You]92-mr. bounderby recollect [the man]3010-the man , [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse ? ’[1911-they] ‘ Oh , perfectly ! ’[1911-they] ‘ [His]3010-the man face , and [his]3010-the man manner , and what [he]3010-the man said ? ’[1911-they] ‘ Perfectly . And [an infinitely dreary person]4413-an infinitely dreary person [he]3010-the man appeared to [me]1911-they to be . Lengthy and prosy in the extreme . It was knowing to hold forth , in the humble - virtue school of eloquence ; but , [I]1911-they assure [you]92-mr. bounderby [I]1911-they thought at the time , “ [[My]1911-they good fellow]882-my good fellow , [you]882-my good fellow are over - doing this ! ” ’[1911-they] ‘ It has been very difficult to [me]1911-they to think ill of [that man]3019-that man . ’[1911-they] ‘ [[My]1912-he dear]3090-my dear [Louisa]91-louisa — as [Tom]75-tom says . ’[1912-he] Which [he]1912-he never did say . ‘ [You]1913-i know no good of [the fellow]4417-the fellow ? ’[1912-he] ‘ No , certainly . ’[1911-they] ‘ Nor of [any other such person]4418-any other such person ? ’[1911-they] ‘ How can [I]1913-i , ’[1913-i] [she]1913-i returned , with more of [her]1913-i first manner on [her]1913-i than [he]1912-he had lately seen , ‘ when [I]1913-i know nothing of [them]4419-they , [men]3039-men or [women]574-women ? ’[1913-i] ‘ [[My]1911-they dear]3090-my dear [Louisa]91-louisa , then consent to receive the submissive representation of [[your]91-louisa devoted friend]4423-your devoted friend , who knows something of several varieties of [his]4423-your devoted friend excellent fellow - creatures — for excellent [they]4419-they are , [I]1911-they am quite ready to believe , in spite of such little foibles as always helping [themselves]4419-they to what [they]4419-they can get hold of . [This fellow]1783-this fellow talks . Well ; [every fellow]4425-every fellow talks . [He]1783-this fellow professes morality . Well ; all sorts of humbugs profess morality . From [the House of Commons]2940-the house of commons to [the House of Correction]325-the house of correction , there is a general profession of morality , except among [[our]4428-our people]2977-our people ; it really is that exception which makes [[our]4428-our people]2977-our people quite reviving . [You]91-louisa saw and heard the case . Here was one of [the fluffy classes]4431-the fluffy classes pulled up extremely short by [[my]1911-they esteemed friend]4432-my esteemed friend [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby — who , as [we]4428-our know , is not possessed of that delicacy which would soften so tight a hand . [The member of the fluffy classes]4433-the member of the fluffy classes was injured , exasperated , left [the house]2875-the house grumbling , met [somebody who proposed to [him]4433-the member of the fluffy classes to go in for some share in [this Bank business]4436-this bank business]4435-somebody who proposed to him to go in for some share in this bank business , went in , put something in [his]4433-the member of the fluffy classes pocket which had nothing in it before , and relieved [his]4433-the member of the fluffy classes mind extremely . Really [he]4433-the member of the fluffy classes would have been [an uncommon]4437-an uncommon , instead of [a common , fellow]4438-a common , fellow , if [he]4433-the member of the fluffy classes had not availed [himself]4433-the member of the fluffy classes of such an opportunity . Or [he]4433-the member of the fluffy classes may have originated it altogether , if [he]4433-the member of the fluffy classes had the cleverness . ’[1911-they] ‘ [I]91-louisa almost feel as though it must be bad in [me]91-louisa , ’[91-louisa] returned [Louisa]91-louisa , after sitting thoughtful awhile , ‘ to be so ready to agree with [you]4433-the member of the fluffy classes , and to be so lightened in [my]91-louisa heart by what [you]4433-the member of the fluffy classes say . ’[91-louisa] ‘ [I]1914-i only say what is reasonable ; nothing worse . [I]1914-i have talked it over with [[my]1914-i friend]3004-my friend [Tom]75-tom more than once — of course [I]1914-i remain on terms of perfect confidence with [Tom]75-tom — and [he]75-tom is quite of [my]1914-i opinion , and [I]1914-i am quite of [his]75-tom . Will [you]1916-you walk ? ’[1914-i] [They]1914-i strolled away , among [the lanes]1915-the lanes beginning to be indistinct in the twilight — [she]91-louisa leaning on [his]1916-you arm — and [she]91-louisa little thought how [she]91-louisa was going down , down , down , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s staircase . Night and day , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby kept it standing . When [Louisa]91-louisa had arrived at the bottom and disappeared in [the gulf]1917-the gulf , it might fall in upon [her]91-louisa if it would ; but , until then , there it was to be , [a Building]1918-a building , before [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s eyes . And there [Louisa]91-louisa always was , upon it . And always gliding down , down , down ! [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby saw [James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse come and go ; [she]91-louisa heard of [him]162-mr. harthouse here and there ; [she]91-louisa saw the changes of the face [he]162-mr. harthouse had studied ; [she]91-louisa , too , remarked to a nicety how and when it clouded , how and when it cleared ; [she]91-louisa kept [her]91-louisa black eyes wide open , with no touch of pity , with no touch of compunction , all absorbed in interest . In the interest of seeing [her]91-louisa , ever drawing , with no hand to stay [her]91-louisa , nearer and nearer to the bottom of [this new Giant ’s Staircase]1919-this new giant ’s staircase . With all [her]91-louisa deference for [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby as contradistinguished from [his]92-mr. bounderby portrait , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby had not the smallest intention of interrupting the descent . Eager to see it accomplished , and yet patient , [she]91-louisa waited for the last fall , as for the ripeness and fulness of the harvest of [her]91-louisa hopes . Hushed in expectancy , [she]91-louisa kept [her]91-louisa wary gaze upon the stairs ; and seldom so much as darkly shook [her]91-louisa right mitten ( with [her]91-louisa fist in it ) , at the figure coming down . CHAPTER XI LOWER AND LOWER [THE figure]3314-the figure descended the great stairs , steadily , steadily ; always verging , like a weight in deep water , to [the black gulf at the bottom]1921-the black gulf at the bottom . [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom , apprised of [[his]75-tom wife]972-his wife ’s decease , made an expedition from [London]8-london , and buried [her]972-his wife in a business - like manner . [He]75-tom then returned with promptitude to the national cinder - heap , and resumed [his]75-tom sifting for the odds and ends [he]75-tom wanted , and [his]75-tom throwing of the dust about into the eyes of [other people who wanted other odds and ends]1923-other people who wanted other odds and ends — in fact resumed [his]75-tom parliamentary duties . In the meantime , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby kept unwinking watch and ward . Separated from [her]91-louisa staircase , all the week , by the length of [iron road dividing [Coketown]4-coketown from [the country house]1925-the country house]1924-iron road dividing coketown from the country house , [she]91-louisa yet maintained [her]91-louisa cat - like observation of [Louisa]91-louisa , through [[her]91-louisa husband]2861-her husband , through [[her]91-louisa brother]2889-her brother , through [James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , through the outsides of letters and packets , through everything animate and inanimate that at any time went near the stairs . ‘ [Your]92-mr. bounderby foot on the last step , [[my]92-mr. bounderby lady]1134-my lady , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , apostrophizing [the descending figure]1928-the descending figure , with the aid of [her]91-louisa threatening mitten , ‘ and all [your]92-mr. bounderby art shall never blind [me]92-mr. bounderby . ’[92-mr. bounderby] Art or nature though , the original stock of [Louisa]91-louisa ’s character or the graft of circumstances upon it,—her curious reserve did baffle , while it stimulated , one as sagacious as [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . There were times when [Mr. James Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse was not sure of [her]91-louisa . There were times when [he]162-mr. harthouse could not read the face [he]162-mr. harthouse had studied so long ; and when [this lonely girl]1929-this lonely girl was a greater mystery to [him]162-mr. harthouse , than [any woman of [the world]2766-the world with a ring of satellites to help [her]91-louisa]1930-any woman of the world with a ring of satellites to help her . So the time went on ; until it happened that [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby was called away from [home]336-home by business which required [his]92-mr. bounderby presence elsewhere , for three or four days . It was on a Friday that [he]92-mr. bounderby intimated this to [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby at [the Bank]3460-the bank , adding : ‘ But [you]92-mr. bounderby ’ll go down to - morrow , [ma’am]350-ma’am , all the same . [You]92-mr. bounderby ’ll go down just as if [I]92-mr. bounderby was [there]412-there . It will make no difference to [you]92-mr. bounderby . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Pray , [sir]2713-sir , ’[92-mr. bounderby] returned [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , reproachfully , ‘ let [me]92-mr. bounderby beg [you]2713-sir not to say that . [Your]2713-sir absence will make a vast difference to [me]92-mr. bounderby , [sir]2713-sir , as [I]92-mr. bounderby think [you]2713-sir very well know . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Well , [ma’am]350-ma’am , then [you]350-ma’am must get on in [my]92-mr. bounderby absence as well as [you]350-ma’am can , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , not displeased . ‘ [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , ’[92-mr. bounderby] retorted [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ [your]2713-sir will is to [me]92-mr. bounderby a law , [sir]2713-sir ; otherwise , it might be [my]92-mr. bounderby inclination to dispute [your]2713-sir kind commands , not feeling sure that it will be quite so agreeable to [Miss Gradgrind]127-miss gradgrind to receive [me]92-mr. bounderby , as it ever is to [your]2713-sir own munificent hospitality . But [you]2713-sir shall say no more , [sir]2713-sir . [I]92-mr. bounderby will go , upon [your]2713-sir invitation . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Why , when [I]92-mr. bounderby invite [you]350-ma’am to [[my]92-mr. bounderby house]3176-my house , [ma’am]350-ma’am , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , opening [his]92-mr. bounderby eyes , ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby should hope [you]350-ma’am want no other invitation . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ No , indeed , [sir]2713-sir , ’[92-mr. bounderby] returned [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby should hope not . Say no more , [sir]2713-sir . [I]92-mr. bounderby would , [sir]2713-sir , [I]92-mr. bounderby could see [you]2713-sir gay again . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ What do [you]350-ma’am mean , [ma’am]350-ma’am ? ’[92-mr. bounderby] blustered [Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ [Sir]2713-sir , ’[92-mr. bounderby] rejoined [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ there was wo nt to be an elasticity in [you]2713-sir which [I]92-mr. bounderby sadly miss . Be buoyant , [sir]2713-sir ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] [Mr. Bounderby]92-mr. bounderby , under the influence of this difficult adjuration , backed up by [her]1934-her compassionate eye , could only scratch [his]92-mr. bounderby head in a feeble and ridiculous manner , and afterwards assert [himself]92-mr. bounderby at a distance , by being heard to bully the small fry of business all the morning . ‘ [Bitzer]77-bitzer , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby that afternoon , when [[her]1934-her patron]3087-her patron was gone on [his]3087-her patron journey , and [the Bank]3460-the bank was closing , ‘ present [my]75-tom compliments to [young Mr. Thomas]75-tom , and ask [him]75-tom if [he]75-tom would step up and partake of a lamb chop and walnut ketchup , with a glass of India ale ? ’[75-tom] [Young Mr. Thomas]75-tom being usually ready for anything in that way , returned a gracious answer , and followed on [its]1937-its heels . ‘ [Mr. Thomas]75-tom , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ these plain viands being on table , [I]92-mr. bounderby thought [you]75-tom might be tempted . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ [Thank’ee]165-thank’ee , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ’[1268-the whelp] said [the whelp]1268-the whelp . And gloomily fell to . ‘ How is [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse , [Mr. Tom]75-tom ? ’[92-mr. bounderby] asked [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ Oh , [he]162-mr. harthouse ’s all right , ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom . ‘ Where may [he]162-mr. harthouse be at present ? ’[92-mr. bounderby] [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby asked in a light conversational manner , after mentally devoting the whelp to [the Furies]202-the furies for being so uncommunicative . ‘ [He]162-mr. harthouse is shooting in [Yorkshire]45-yorkshire , ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom . ‘ Sent [Loo]100-loo a basket half as big as [a church]4456-a church , yesterday . ’[75-tom] ‘ [The kind of gentleman]4457-the kind of gentleman , now , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , sweetly , ‘ whom one might wager to be a good shot ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ [Crack]203-crack , ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom . [He]75-tom had long been [a down - looking young fellow]1939-a down - looking young fellow , but this characteristic had so increased of late , that [he]75-tom never raised [his]75-tom eyes to any face for three seconds together . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby consequently had ample means of watching [his]75-tom looks , if [she]1940-she were so inclined . ‘ [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse is a great favourite of [mine]92-mr. bounderby , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ as indeed [he]162-mr. harthouse is of [most people]4458-most people . May [we]4459-we expect to see [him]162-mr. harthouse again shortly , [Mr. Tom]75-tom ? ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Why , _ [I]1268-the whelp _ expect to see [him]162-mr. harthouse to - morrow , ’[1268-the whelp] returned [the whelp]1268-the whelp . ‘ Good news ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] cried [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , blandly . ‘ [I]75-tom have got an appointment with [him]162-mr. harthouse to meet [him]162-mr. harthouse in the evening at [the station]911-the station here , ’[75-tom] said [Tom]75-tom , ‘ and [I]75-tom am going to dine with [him]162-mr. harthouse afterwards , [I]75-tom believe . [He]162-mr. harthouse is not coming down to [the country house]1925-the country house for a week or so , being due somewhere else . At least , [he]162-mr. harthouse says so ; but [I]75-tom should n’t wonder if [he]162-mr. harthouse was to stop here over Sunday , and stray that way . ’[75-tom] ‘ Which reminds [me]92-mr. bounderby ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby . ‘ Would [you]75-tom remember a message to [[your]75-tom sister]2822-your sister , [Mr. Tom]75-tom , if [I]92-mr. bounderby was to charge [you]75-tom with one ? ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Well ? [I]1942-the reluctant whelp ’ll try , ’[1942-the reluctant whelp] returned [the reluctant whelp]1942-the reluctant whelp , ‘ if it is n’t a long un . ’[1942-the reluctant whelp] ‘ It is merely [my]92-mr. bounderby respectful compliments , ’[92-mr. bounderby] said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ and [I]92-mr. bounderby fear [I]92-mr. bounderby may not trouble [her]2822-your sister with [my]92-mr. bounderby society this week ; being still a little nervous , and better perhaps by [my]92-mr. bounderby poor self . ’[92-mr. bounderby] ‘ Oh ! If that ’s all , ’[75-tom] observed [Tom]75-tom , ‘ it would n’t much matter , even if [I]75-tom was to forget it , for [Loo]100-loo ’s not likely to think of [you]75-tom unless [she]2822-your sister sees [you]75-tom . ’[75-tom] Having paid for [his]75-tom entertainment with this agreeable compliment , [he]75-tom relapsed into a hangdog silence until there was no more [India ale]24-india left , when [he]75-tom said , ‘ Well , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , [I]75-tom must be off ! ’[75-tom] and went off . Next day , Saturday , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby sat at [her]1943-her window all day long looking at [the customers coming in and out]1944-the customers coming in and out , watching [the postmen]1945-the postmen , keeping an eye on the general traffic of [the street]448-the street , revolving many things in [her]1943-her mind , but , above all , keeping [her]1943-her attention on [her]1943-her staircase . The evening come , [she]1943-her put on [her]1943-her bonnet and shawl , and went quietly out : having [her]1943-her reasons for hovering in a furtive way about [the station by which [a passenger]1948-a passenger would arrive from [Yorkshire]45-yorkshire]1947-the station by which a passenger would arrive from yorkshire , and for preferring to peep into [it]1947-the station by which a passenger would arrive from yorkshire round pillars and corners , and out of [ladies]3150-ladies ’ waiting - room windows , to appearing in [[its]1947-the station by which a passenger would arrive from yorkshire precincts]4463-its precincts openly . [Tom]75-tom was in attendance , and loitered about until [the expected train]4464-the expected train came in . [It]4464-the expected train brought no [Mr. Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse . [Tom]75-tom waited until [the crowd]4465-the crowd had dispersed , and the bustle was over ; and then referred to a posted list of [trains]4466-trains , and took counsel with [porters]4345-porters . That done , [he]75-tom strolled away idly , stopping in [the street]448-the street and looking up [it]448-the street and down [it]448-the street , and lifting [his]75-tom hat off and putting it on again , and yawning and stretching [himself]75-tom , and exhibiting all the symptoms of mortal weariness to be expected in one who had still to wait until [the next train]4469-the next train should come in , an hour and forty minutes hence . ‘[1943-her] This is a device to keep [him]1950-him out of the way , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , starting from the dull office window whence [she]4470-her had watched [him]1950-him last . ‘[1943-her] [Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse is with [[his]162-mr. harthouse sister]644-his sister now ! ’ It was the conception of an inspired moment , and [she]4470-her shot off with [her]4470-her utmost swiftness to work it out . [The station for [the country house]1925-the country house]4471-the station for the country house was at [the opposite end of [the town]317-the town]4473-the opposite end of the town , the time was short , [the road]326-the road not easy ; but [she]4470-her was so quick in pouncing on [a disengaged coach]4476-a disengaged coach , so quick in darting out of [it]4476-a disengaged coach , producing [her]4470-her money , seizing [her]4470-her ticket , and diving into [the train]4477-the train , that [she]4470-her was borne along the arches spanning [the land of coal - pits]4478-the land of coal - pits past and present , as if [she]4470-her had been caught up in a cloud and whirled away . All the journey , immovable in the air though never left behind ; plain to the dark eyes of [her]4470-her mind , as the electric wires which ruled a colossal strip of music - paper out of the evening sky , were plain to the dark eyes of [her]4470-her body ; [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby saw [her]4470-her staircase , with the figure coming down . Very near the bottom now . Upon the brink of [the abyss]4479-the abyss . An overcast September evening , just at nightfall , saw beneath its drooping eyelids [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby glide out of [[her]4470-her carriage]4480-her carriage , pass down the wooden steps of [the little station]4481-the little station into [a stony road]4482-a stony road , cross [it]4482-a stony road into [a green lane]4483-a green lane , and become hidden in a summer - growth of leaves and branches . One or two late birds sleepily chirping in their nests , and a bat heavily crossing and recrossing [her]4470-her , and the reek of [her]4470-her own tread in the thick dust that felt like velvet , were all [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby heard or saw until [she]4470-her very softly closed a gate . [She]4470-her went up to [the house]2875-the house , keeping within the shrubbery , and went round [it]2875-the house , peeping between the leaves at the lower windows . Most of [them]2875-the house were open , as they usually were in such warm weather , but there were no lights yet , and all was silent . [She]4470-her tried [the garden]4227-the garden with no better effect . [She]4470-her thought of the wood , and stole towards [it]2875-the house , heedless of long grass and briers : of worms , snails , and slugs , and all the creeping things that be . With [her]4470-her dark eyes and [her]4470-her hook nose warily in advance of [her]4470-her , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby softly crushed [her]4470-her way through the thick undergrowth , so intent upon [her]4470-her object that [she]4470-her probably would have done no less , if the wood had been a wood of adders . Hark ! The smaller birds might have tumbled out of their nests , fascinated by the glittering of [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s eyes in the gloom , as [she]4470-her stopped and listened . Low voices close at hand . [His]92-mr. bounderby voice and [hers]4470-her . The appointment _ was _ a device to keep [the brother]1621-the brother away ! There [they]2875-the house were yonder , by the felled tree . Bending low among the dewy grass , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby advanced closer to [them]2875-the house . [She]4470-her drew [herself]4470-her up , and stood behind a tree , like [Robinson Crusoe]205-robinson crusoe in [his]205-robinson crusoe ambuscade against [the savages]4487-the savages ; so near to [them]2875-the house that at a spring , and that [no great one]4488-no great one , [she]4470-her could have touched [them]2875-the house both . [He]92-mr. bounderby was [there]412-there secretly , and had not shown [himself]92-mr. bounderby at [the house]2875-the house . [He]92-mr. bounderby had come on horseback , and must have passed through [the neighbouring fields]4491-the neighbouring fields ; for [his]92-mr. bounderby horse was tied to the meadow side of the fence , within a few paces . ‘[0-i] [[My]0-i dearest love]1952-my dearest love , ’ said [he]92-mr. bounderby , ‘[0-i] what could [I]0-i do ? Knowing [you]1952-my dearest love were alone , was it possible that [I]0-i could stay away ? ’ ‘[1952-my dearest love] [You]1952-my dearest love may hang [your]1952-my dearest love head , to make [yourself]1952-my dearest love the more attractive ; _ [I]0-i _ do n’t know what [they]1953-they see in [you]1952-my dearest love when [you]1952-my dearest love hold it up , ’ thought [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ; ‘[1953-they] but [you]1952-my dearest love little think , [[my]0-i dearest]1954-my dearest love , whose eyes are on [you]1952-my dearest love ! ’ That [she]1952-my dearest love hung [her]1952-my dearest love head , was certain . [She]1952-my dearest love urged [him]92-mr. bounderby to go away , [she]1952-my dearest love commanded [him]92-mr. bounderby to go away ; but [she]1952-my dearest love neither turned [her]1952-my dearest love face to [him]92-mr. bounderby , nor raised it . Yet it was remarkable that [she]1952-my dearest love sat as still as ever [the amiable woman in ambuscade]4492-the amiable woman in ambuscade had seen [her]1952-my dearest love sit , at any period in [her]1952-my dearest love life . [Her]1952-my dearest love hands rested in one another , like the hands of a statue ; and even [her]1952-my dearest love manner of speaking was not hurried . ‘[0-i] [[My]0-i dear child]1955-my dear child , ’ said [Harthouse]162-mr. harthouse ; [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby saw with delight that [his]92-mr. bounderby arm embraced [her]1952-my dearest love ; ‘[0-i] will [you]1955-my dear child not bear with [[my]0-i society]1956-my society for a little while ? ’ ‘[1955-my dear child] Not here . ’ ‘[1955-my dear child] Where , [Louisa]91-louisa ? ‘ Not [here]354-here . ’[91-louisa] ‘ But [we]4494-we have so little time to make so much of , and [I]1958-the listener have come so far , and am altogether so devoted , and distracted . There never was [a slave]4495-a slave at once so devoted and ill - used by [[his]4495-a slave mistress]4496-his mistress . To look for [your]1955-my dear child sunny welcome that has warmed [me]1958-the listener into life , and to be received in [your]1955-my dear child frozen manner , is heart - rending . ’[1958-the listener] ‘ Am [I]91-louisa to say again , that [I]91-louisa must be left to [myself]91-louisa here ? ’[91-louisa] ‘ But [we]4494-we must meet , [[my]1957-my dear [Louisa]91-louisa]4497-my dear louisa . Where shall [we]4494-we meet ? ’[1957-my] [They]1957-my both started . [The listener]1958-the listener started , guiltily , too ; for [she]91-louisa thought there was [another listener among the trees]1959-another listener among the trees . It was only rain , beginning to fall fast , in heavy drops . ‘ Shall [I]91-louisa ride up to [the house]2875-the house a few minutes hence , innocently supposing that [its master]4499-its master is at [home]336-home and will be charmed to receive [me]91-louisa ? ’[91-louisa] ‘ No ! ’[91-louisa] ‘ [Your]1955-my dear child cruel commands are implicitly to be obeyed ; though [I]92-mr. bounderby am [the most unfortunate fellow in [the world]2766-the world]4501-the most unfortunate fellow in the world , [I]92-mr. bounderby believe , to have been insensible to [all other women]4503-all other women , and to have fallen prostrate at last under the foot of the most beautiful , and the most engaging , and the most imperious . [[My]92-mr. bounderby dearest]1954-my dearest [Louisa]91-louisa , [I]92-mr. bounderby can not go [myself]92-mr. bounderby , or let [you]91-louisa go , in this hard abuse of [your]91-louisa power . ’[92-mr. bounderby] [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby saw [him]1960-he detain [her]1961-her with [his]1960-he encircling arm , and heard [him]1960-he then and there , within [her]1961-her ( [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s ) greedy hearing , tell [her]1961-her how [he]1960-he loved [her]1961-her , and how [she]1961-her was the stake for which [he]1960-he ardently desired to play away all that [he]1960-he had in life . The objects [he]1960-he had lately pursued , turned worthless beside [her]1961-her ; such success as was almost in [his]1960-he grasp , [he]1960-he flung away from [him]1960-he like the dirt it was , compared with [her]1961-her . Its pursuit , nevertheless , if it kept [him]1960-he near [her]1961-her , or its renunciation if it took [him]1960-he from [her]1961-her , or flight if [she]1961-her shared it , or secrecy if [she]1961-her commanded it , or any fate , or every fate , all was alike to [him]1960-he , so that [she]1961-her was true to [[him,—the]1960-he man who had seen how cast away [she]1961-her was , whom [she]1961-her had inspired at [their]1963-they first meeting with an admiration , an interest , of which [he]1960-he had thought [himself]1960-he incapable , whom [she]1961-her had received into [her]1961-her confidence , who was devoted to [her]1961-her and adored [her]1961-her]1962-him,—the man who had seen how cast away she was , whom she had inspired at their first meeting with an admiration , an interest , of which he had thought himself incapable , whom she had received into her confidence , who was devoted to her and adored her . All this , and more , in [his]1960-he hurry , and in [hers]1961-her , in the whirl of [her]1961-her own gratified malice , in the dread of being discovered , in the rapidly increasing noise of heavy rain among the leaves , and a thunderstorm rolling up — [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby received into [her]1961-her mind , set off with such an unavoidable halo of confusion and indistinctness , that when at length [he]1960-he climbed the fence and led [his]1960-he horse away , [she]1961-her was not sure where [they]1963-they were to meet , or when , except that [they]1963-they had said it was to be that night . But [one of [them]1963-they]4142-one of them yet remained in the darkness before [her]1961-her ; and while [she]1961-her tracked [that one]1965-that one [she]1961-her must be right . ‘ Oh , [[my]92-mr. bounderby dearest love]1952-my dearest love , ’[92-mr. bounderby] thought [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ [you]1952-my dearest love little think how well attended [you]1952-my dearest love are ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby saw [her]1961-her out of the wood , and saw [her]1961-her enter [the house]2875-the house . What to do next ? It rained now , in a sheet of water . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s white stockings were of many colours , green predominating ; prickly things were in [her]1961-her shoes ; [caterpillars]1967-caterpillars slung [themselves]1967-caterpillars , in hammocks of [their]1967-caterpillars own making , from various parts of [her]1961-her dress ; rills ran from [her]1961-her bonnet , and [her]1961-her Roman nose . In such condition , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby stood hidden in the density of the shrubbery , considering what next ? Lo , [Louisa]91-louisa coming out of [the house]2875-the house ! Hastily cloaked and muffled , and stealing away . [She]91-louisa elopes ! [She]91-louisa falls from the lowermost stair , and is swallowed up in [the gulf]1917-the gulf . Indifferent to the rain , and moving with a quick determined step , [she]91-louisa struck into a side - path parallel with [the ride]1970-the ride . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby followed in the shadow of the trees , at but a short distance ; for it was not easy to keep [a figure in view going quickly through the umbrageous darkness]1971-a figure in view going quickly through the umbrageous darkness . When [she]1961-her stopped to close the side - gate without noise , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby stopped . When [she]1961-her went on , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby went on . [She]1961-her went by the way [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby had come , emerged from [the green lane]1972-the green lane , crossed [the stony road]1973-the stony road , and ascended the wooden steps to [the railroad]3601-the railroad . [A train]1975-a train for [Coketown]4-coketown would come through presently , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby knew ; so [she]1961-her understood [Coketown]4-coketown to be [[her]1961-her first place of destination]1976-her first place of destination . In [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby ’s limp and streaming state , no extensive precautions were necessary to change [her]1961-her usual appearance ; but , [she]1961-her stopped under the lee of the station wall , tumbled [her]1961-her shawl into a new shape , and put it on over [her]1961-her bonnet . So disguised [she]1961-her had no fear of being recognized when [she]1961-her followed up [the railroad steps]1977-the railroad steps , and paid [her]1961-her money in [the small office]1978-the small office . [Louisa]91-louisa sat waiting in a corner . [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby sat waiting in [another corner]1979-another corner . [Both]334-both listened to the thunder , which was loud , and to the rain , as it washed off the roof , and pattered on the parapets of the arches . Two or three lamps were rained out and blown out ; so , [both]334-both saw the lightning to advantage as it quivered and zigzagged on [the iron tracks]1982-the iron tracks . The seizure of [the station]911-the station with a fit of trembling , gradually deepening to a complaint of the heart , announced [the train]4477-the train . Fire and steam , and smoke , and red light ; a hiss , a crash , a bell , and a shriek ; [Louisa]91-louisa put into [one carriage]1985-one carriage , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby put into another : [the little station]4481-the little station a desert speck in the thunderstorm . Though [her]1961-her teeth chattered in [her]1961-her head from wet and cold , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby exulted hugely . [The figure]3314-the figure had plunged down the precipice , and [she]1961-her felt [herself]1961-her , as it were , attending on the body . Could [she]1961-her , who had been so active in the getting up of the funeral triumph , do less than exult ? ‘ [She]91-louisa will be at [Coketown]4-coketown long before [him]4-coketown , ’[92-mr. bounderby] thought [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby , ‘ though [his]4-coketown horse is never so good . Where will [she]91-louisa wait for [him]4-coketown ? And where will [they]4506-they go together ? Patience . [We]4507-we shall see . ’[92-mr. bounderby] The tremendous rain occasioned infinite confusion , when [the train]4477-the train stopped at [its]4477-the train destination . [Gutters]1989-gutters and pipes had burst , drains had overflowed , and [streets]1990-streets were under water . In the first instant of alighting , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby turned [her]1961-her distracted eyes towards [the waiting coaches]1991-the waiting coaches , which were in great request . ‘ [She]91-louisa will get into one , ’[1961-her] [she]1961-her considered , ‘ and will be away before [I]1961-her can follow in another . At all risks of being run over , [I]1961-her must see the number , and hear the order given to [the coachman]4508-the coachman . ’[1961-her] But , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby was wrong in [her]1961-her calculation . [Louisa]91-louisa got into [no coach]1992-no coach , and was already gone . The black eyes kept upon [the railroad - carriage in which [she]91-louisa had travelled]1993-the railroad - carriage in which she had travelled , settled upon [it]1993-the railroad - carriage in which she had travelled a moment too late . The door not being opened after several minutes , [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby passed it and repassed it , saw nothing , looked in , and found [it]1994-it empty . Wet through and through : with [her]91-louisa feet squelching and squashing in [her]91-louisa shoes whenever [she]91-louisa moved ; with a rash of rain upon [her]91-louisa classical visage ; with a bonnet like an over - ripe fig ; with all [her]91-louisa clothes spoiled ; with damp impressions of every button , string , and hook - and - eye [she]91-louisa wore , printed off upon [her]91-louisa highly connected back ; with a stagnant verdure on [her]91-louisa general exterior , such as accumulates on an old park fence in [a mouldy lane]1995-a mouldy lane ; [Mrs. Sparsit]92-mr. bounderby had no resource but to burst into tears of bitterness and say , ‘ [I]92-mr. bounderby have lost [her]91-louisa ! ’[92-mr. bounderby] CHAPTER XII DOWN [THE national dustmen]1996-the national dustmen , after entertaining [one another]2898-one another with a great many noisy little fights among [themselves]1996-the national dustmen , had dispersed for the present , and [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom was at [home]336-home for the vacation . [He]75-tom sat writing in [the room]2859-the room with the deadly statistical clock , proving something no doubt — probably , in the main , that [the Good Samaritan]206-the good samaritan was [a Bad Economist]2000-a bad economist . The noise of the rain did not disturb [him]75-tom much ; but it attracted [his]75-tom attention sufficiently to make [him]75-tom raise [his]75-tom head sometimes , as if [he]75-tom were rather remonstrating with the elements . When it thundered very loudly , [he]75-tom glanced towards [Coketown]4-coketown , having it in [his]75-tom mind that some of the tall chimneys might be struck by lightning . The thunder was rolling into distance , and the rain was pouring down like a deluge , when the door of [[his]75-tom room]3401-his room opened . [He]75-tom looked round the lamp upon [his]75-tom table , and saw , with amazement , [[his]75-tom eldest daughter]2002-his eldest daughter . ‘ [Louisa]91-louisa ! ’[75-tom] ‘ [Father]2723-father , [I]2002-his eldest daughter want to speak to [you]2723-father . ’[2002-his eldest daughter] ‘ What is the matter ? How strange [you]91-louisa look ! And good Heaven , ’[75-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]75-tom , wondering more and more , ‘ have [you]91-louisa come here exposed to this storm ? ’[2002-his eldest daughter] [She]2002-his eldest daughter put [her]2002-his eldest daughter hands to [her]2002-his eldest daughter dress , as if [she]2002-his eldest daughter hardly knew . ‘ Yes . ’[2002-his eldest daughter] Then [she]2002-his eldest daughter uncovered [her]2002-his eldest daughter head , and letting [her]2002-his eldest daughter cloak and hood fall where they might , stood looking at [him]75-tom : so colourless , so dishevelled , so defiant and despairing , that [he]75-tom was afraid of [her]2002-his eldest daughter . ‘ What is it ? [I]2002-his eldest daughter conjure [you]91-louisa , [Louisa]91-louisa , tell [me]2002-his eldest daughter what is the matter . ’[2002-his eldest daughter] [She]2002-his eldest daughter dropped into a chair before [him]75-tom , and put [her]2002-his eldest daughter cold hand on [his]75-tom arm . ‘ [Father]106-father , [you]75-tom have trained [me]2002-his eldest daughter from [[my]2002-his eldest daughter cradle]4510-my cradle ? ’[2002-his eldest daughter] ‘ Yes , [Louisa]91-louisa . ’[2002-his eldest daughter] ‘ [I]75-tom curse the hour in which [I]75-tom was born to such a destiny . ’[75-tom] [He]75-tom looked at [her]2002-his eldest daughter in doubt and dread , vacantly repeating : ‘ Curse the hour ? Curse the hour ? ’[75-tom] ‘ How could [you]75-tom give [me]2002-his eldest daughter life , and take from [me]2002-his eldest daughter all the inappreciable things that raise it from the state of conscious death ? Where are the graces of [my]2002-his eldest daughter soul ? Where are the sentiments of [my]2002-his eldest daughter heart ? What have [you]75-tom done , O [father]2723-father , what have [you]75-tom done , with the garden that should have bloomed once , in this great wilderness here ! ’[2002-his eldest daughter] [She]2002-his eldest daughter struck [herself]2002-his eldest daughter with both [her]2002-his eldest daughter hands upon [her]2002-his eldest daughter bosom . ‘ If it had ever been [here]354-here , its ashes alone would save [me]2002-his eldest daughter from the void in which [my]2002-his eldest daughter whole life sinks . [I]2002-his eldest daughter did not mean to say this ; but , [father]2723-father , [you]75-tom remember the last time [we]4514-we conversed in [this room]4066-this room ? ’[2002-his eldest daughter] [He]2003-he had been so wholly unprepared for what [he]2003-he heard now , that it was with difficulty [he]2003-he answered , ‘ Yes , [Louisa]91-louisa . ’[2003-he] ‘ What has risen to [my]2002-his eldest daughter lips now , would have risen to [my]2002-his eldest daughter lips then , if [you]75-tom had given [me]2002-his eldest daughter a moment ’s help . [I]2002-his eldest daughter do n’t reproach [you]75-tom , [father]2723-father . What [you]75-tom have never nurtured in [me]2002-his eldest daughter , [you]75-tom have never nurtured in [yourself]75-tom ; but O ! if [you]75-tom had only done so long ago , or if [you]75-tom had only neglected [me]2002-his eldest daughter , what [a much better and much happier creature]4517-a much better and much happier creature [I]2002-his eldest daughter should have been this day ! ’[2002-his eldest daughter] On hearing this , after all [his]2003-he care , [he]2003-he bowed [his]2003-he head upon [his]2003-he hand and groaned aloud . ‘ [Father]106-father , if [you]75-tom had known , when [we]4518-we were last together here , what even [I]2003-he feared while [I]2003-he strove against it — as it has been [my]2003-he task from infancy to strive against every natural prompting that has arisen in [my]2003-he heart ; if [you]75-tom had known that there lingered in [my]2003-he breast , sensibilities , affections , weaknesses capable of being cherished into strength , defying all the calculations ever made by [man]2923-man , and no more known to [his]2923-man arithmetic than [[his]2923-man Creator]4520-his creator is,—would [you]75-tom have given [me]2003-he to [the husband whom [I]2003-he am now sure that [I]2003-he hate]4521-the husband whom i am now sure that i hate ? ’[2003-he] [He]2003-he said , ‘ No . No , [[my]2003-he poor child]4522-my poor child . ’[2003-he] ‘ Would [you]75-tom have doomed [me]2004-i , at any time , to the frost and blight that have hardened and spoiled [me]2004-i ? Would [you]75-tom have robbed [me]2004-i — for [no one]545-no one ’s enrichment — only for the greater desolation of [this world]961-this world — of the immaterial part of [my]2004-i life , the spring and summer of [my]2004-i belief , [my]2004-i refuge from what is sordid and bad in the real things around [me]2004-i , [[my]2004-i school]4525-my school in which [I]2004-i should have learned to be more humble and more trusting with [them]4526-them , and to hope in [my]2004-i little sphere to make [them]4526-them better ? ’[2004-i] ‘ O no , no . No , [Louisa]91-louisa . ’[2004-i] ‘ Yet , [father]2723-father , if [I]2004-i had been stone blind ; if [I]2004-i had groped [my]2004-i way by [my]2004-i sense of touch , and had been free , while [I]2004-i knew the shapes and surfaces of things , to exercise [my]2004-i fancy somewhat , in regard to them ; [I]2004-i should have been a million times wiser , happier , more loving , more contented , more innocent and human in all good respects , than [I]2004-i am with the eyes [I]2004-i have . Now , hear what [I]2004-i have come to say . ’[2004-i] [He]2004-i moved , to support [her]2005-i with [his]2004-i arm . [She]2005-i rising as [he]2004-i did so , [they]2006-they stood close together : [she]2005-i , with a hand upon [his]2004-i shoulder , looking fixedly in [his]2004-i face . ‘ With a hunger and thirst upon [me]2005-i , [father]2723-father , which have never been for a moment appeased ; with an ardent impulse towards some region where rules , and figures , and definitions were not quite absolute ; [I]2005-i have grown up , battling every inch of [my]2005-i way . ’[2005-i] ‘ [I]2005-i never knew [you]2005-i were unhappy , [[my]2005-i child]1047-my child . ’[2005-i] ‘ [Father]106-father , [I]2005-i always knew it . In this strife [I]2005-i have almost repulsed and crushed [[my]2005-i better angel]4530-my better angel into a demon . What [I]2005-i have learned has left [me]2005-i doubting , misbelieving , despising , regretting , what [I]2005-i have not learned ; and [my]2005-i dismal resource has been to think that life would soon go by , and that nothing in it could be worth the pain and trouble of a contest . ’[2005-i] ‘ And [you]2005-i so young , [Louisa]91-louisa ! ’[2004-i] [he]2004-i said with pity . ‘ And [I]2004-i so young . In this condition , [father]2723-father — for [I]2004-i show [you]2723-father now , without fear or favour , the ordinary deadened state of [my]2004-i mind as [I]2004-i know it — [you]2723-father proposed [[my]2004-i husband]3766-my husband to [me]2004-i . [I]2004-i took [him]3766-my husband . [I]2004-i never made a pretence to [him]3766-my husband or [you]2723-father that [I]2004-i loved [him]3766-my husband . [I]2004-i knew , and , [father]2723-father , [you]2723-father knew , and [he]3766-my husband knew , that [I]2004-i never did . [I]2004-i was not wholly indifferent , for [I]2004-i had a hope of being pleasant and useful to [Tom]75-tom . [I]2004-i made that wild escape into something visionary , and have slowly found out how wild it was . But [Tom]75-tom had been the subject of all the little tenderness of [my]2004-i life ; perhaps [he]75-tom became so because [I]2004-i knew so well how to pity [him]75-tom . It matters little now , except as it may dispose [you]2723-father to think more leniently of [his]75-tom errors . ’[2004-i] As [[her]2007-her father]335-her father held [her]2007-her in [his]335-her father arms , [she]2007-her put [her]2007-her other hand upon [his]335-her father other shoulder , and still looking fixedly in [his]335-her father face , went on . ‘ When [I]2007-her was irrevocably married , there rose up into rebellion against the tie , the old strife , made fiercer by all those causes of disparity which arise out of [our]2009-our two individual natures , and which no general laws shall ever rule or state for [me]2007-her , [father]2723-father , until [they]4535-they shall be able to direct [the anatomist]4536-the anatomist where to strike [his]4536-the anatomist knife into the secrets of [my]2007-her soul . ’[2007-her] ‘ [Louisa]91-louisa ! ’[335-her father] [he]335-her father said , and said imploringly ; for [he]335-her father well remembered what had passed between [them]2009-our in [their]2009-our former interview . ‘ [I]335-her father do not reproach [you]2723-father , [father]2723-father , [I]335-her father make no complaint . [I]335-her father am here with another object . ’[335-her father] ‘ What can [I]2007-her do , [child]3827-child ? Ask [me]2007-her what [you]2723-father will . ’[2007-her] ‘ [I]335-her father am coming to it . [Father]106-father , chance then threw into [my]335-her father way a new acquaintance ; [a man such as [I]335-her father had had no experience of ; used to [the world]2766-the world]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world ; light , polished , easy ; making no pretences ; avowing the low estimate of everything , that [I]335-her father was half afraid to form in secret ; conveying to [me]335-her father almost immediately , though [I]335-her father do n’t know how or by what degrees , that [he]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world understood [me]335-her father , and read [my]335-her father thoughts . [I]335-her father could not find that [he]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world was worse than [I.]335-her father There seemed to be a near affinity between [us]4541-us . [I]335-her father only wondered it should be worth [his]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world while , who cared for nothing else , to care so much for [me]335-her father . ’[335-her father] ‘ For [you]2010-her , [Louisa]91-louisa ! ’[2010-her] [[Her]2010-her father]335-her father might instinctively have loosened [his]335-her father hold , but that [he]335-her father felt [her]2010-her strength departing from [her]2010-her , and saw a wild dilating fire in the eyes steadfastly regarding [him]335-her father . ‘ [I]2010-her say nothing of [his]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world plea for claiming [my]2010-her confidence . It matters very little how [he]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world gained it . [Father]106-father , [he]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world did gain it . What [you]106-father know of the story of [my]2010-her marriage , [he]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world soon knew , just as well . ’[2010-her] [[Her]2010-her father]335-her father ’s face was ashy white , and [he]335-her father held [her]2010-her in both [his]335-her father arms . ‘ [I]2010-her have done no worse , [I]2010-her have not disgraced [you]2010-her . But if [you]106-father ask [me]2010-her whether [I]2010-her have loved [him]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world , or do love [him]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world , [I]2010-her tell [you]106-father plainly , [father]2723-father , that it may be so . [I]2010-her do n’t know . ’[2010-her] [She]2010-her took [her]2010-her hands suddenly from [his]335-her father shoulders , and pressed them both upon [her]2010-her side ; while in [her]2010-her face , not like itself — and in [her]2010-her figure , drawn up , resolute to finish by a last effort what [she]2010-her had to say — the feelings long suppressed broke loose . ‘ This night , [[my]2013-i husband]3766-my husband being away , [he]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world has been with [me]2013-i , declaring [himself]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world [[my]2013-i lover]4544-my lover . This minute [he]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world expects [me]2013-i , for [I]2013-i could release [myself]2013-i of [his]4539-a man such as i had had no experience of ; used to the world presence by no other means . [I]2013-i do not know that [I]2013-i am sorry , [I]2013-i do not know that [I]2013-i am ashamed , [I]2013-i do not know that [I]2013-i am degraded in [my]2013-i own esteem . All that [I]2013-i know is , [your]2013-i philosophy and [your]2013-i teaching will not save [me]2013-i . Now , [father]2723-father , [you]2013-i have brought [me]2013-i to this . Save [me]2013-i by some other means ! ’[2013-i] [He]2013-i tightened [his]2013-i hold in time to prevent [her]2014-her sinking on the floor , but [she]2014-her cried out in a terrible voice , ‘ [I]2014-her shall die if [you]2013-i hold [me]2014-her ! Let [me]2014-her fall upon the ground ! ’[2014-her] And [he]2013-i laid [her]2014-her down there , and saw the pride of [his]2013-i heart and the triumph of [his]2013-i system , lying , an insensible heap , at [his]2013-i feet . * * * * * END OF THE SECOND BOOK BOOK THE THIRD _ GARNERING _ CHAPTER I ANOTHER THING NEEDFUL [LOUISA]91-louisa awoke from a torpor , and [her]91-louisa eyes languidly opened on [her]91-louisa old bed at [home]336-home , and [[her]91-louisa old room]2016-her old room . It seemed , at first , as if all that had happened since the days when these objects were familiar to [her]91-louisa were the shadows of a dream , but gradually , as the objects became more real to [her]91-louisa sight , the events became more real to [her]91-louisa mind . [She]91-louisa could scarcely move [her]91-louisa head for pain and heaviness , [her]91-louisa eyes were strained and sore , and [she]91-louisa was very weak .
